PETITION.TITLE: Freedom of Choice
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the Citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That we:
(1) Affirm the importance of quality education for all the children of this Commonwealth of Australia irrespective of their religion, nationality or sex;
(2) Support the rights of parents to have freedom of choice of the school for their child;
(3) Support the right of all non-government schools to maintain their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos;
(4) Support the freedom of choice in staffing of all Churches and religious organisations.
(5) Support freedom of religion and the right of all Churches and religious organisations to maintain their distinctive foundational ethos.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate oppose any attempts to introduce legislation that would jeopardise these freedoms and rights and which would force Schools, Churches and religious institutions to compromise their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill responds to the High Court's decision in Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs v Ah Hin Teoh, handed down on 7 April 1995. It follows a Joint Statement by the Attorney-General and the Minister for Foreign Affairs on 10 May 1995 on behalf of the Government.

The High Court decision raises the issue of the role of international law in Australian law. It raises a fundamental question about our system of parliamentary law-making in Australia: should it be by-passed to allow for treaties to have direct effect in Australian law? Or should, as the Government believes, the role of changing Australian law to conform with treaty obligations remain with the democratically elected Parliament of this country?

Before outlining the aim of the bill, and the reasons behind its enactment, it is useful to give a short description of the facts of the Teoh case, and the reasoning in the judgment of the High Court.

Mr Teoh was a Malaysian citizen who came to Australia on 5 May 1988 and was granted a temporary entry permit. On 9 July 1988 he married an Australian citizen. At the time of the marriage Mrs Teoh had four children. Later, Mr and Mrs Teoh had three more children.

In October 1988 Mr Teoh applied for and was granted a further temporary entry permit which allowed him to remain in Australia until 5 February 1989. Before that permit had expired he applied for a permanent entry permit, otherwise known as a grant of resident status. In November 1990, when his application for resident status was still pending, Mr Teoh was convicted of six counts of being knowingly concerned in the importation of heroin and of three counts of being in possession of heroin. He was sentenced to six years' imprisonment with a non-parole period of two years and eight months.

In January 1991, Mr Teoh was informed that his application for permanent resident status had been refused because he did not satisfy the requirement of good character. That requirement applies to all applicants over 16 years of age. One of the bases of assessment of good character is whether the applicant has a criminal record. It was decided that he did not meet the good character requirement.
On review, the Immigration Review Panel recommended that the delegate's decision to refuse permanent resident status be affirmed.

In reaching that decision, the Panel did not ignore the interests of the children. The decision recorded that Mrs Teoh and family were facing a very bleak and difficult future and would be deprived of a possible breadwinner as well as a father and husband if resident status was not granted. However, the applicant had committed a very serious crime and failed to meet the character requirements for the granting of permanent residency. The compassionate claims were not considered to be compelling enough for the waiver of policy in view of Mr Teoh's criminal record.

Mr Teoh then appealed to the Federal Court. At first instance, his claim was dismissed, but he appealed to the Full Federal Court which found in his favour. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs then appealed that decision to the High Court. The High Court decided in favour of Mr Teoh. The decision to deport Mr Teoh was stayed until the application for the grant of residence status was reconsidered and determined.

In reaching this decision, the High Court relied heavily on the Convention on the Rights of the Child, a treaty which has not been incorporated into Australian law. The High Court focused on Article 3(l) of the Convention on the Rights of the Child. That article provides that:

`In all actions concerning children, whether undertaken by public or private social welfare institutions, courts of law, administrative authorities or legislative bodies, the best interests of the child shall be a primary consideration.'

The Court found in effect, that the best interests of Mr Teoh's children had not been `a primary consideration' in the making of the decision not to grant him permanent resident status. The decision of the Immigration Review Panel shows, however, as I have indicated, that it was not the case that their interests were ignored. Nevertheless, this was not considered sufficient by the majority of the High Court.

In the Teoh case the High Court held that the ratification of a treaty by Australia creates a legitimate expectation that the Executive Government and its agencies will act in accordance with the treaty provisions, even if they have not been legislated into Australian law. If it is proposed to make a decision inconsistent with that legitimate expectation, it was held that procedural fairness requires that the person affected be given notice and an adequate opportunity to reply. A legitimate expectation amounts only to a procedural right to have the treaty considered, as opposed to a legal right to enforce the terms of the treaty. A decision maker can still decide the other way, so long as she or he has heard the applicant on the issue. However, that is still a significant right. The majority of the Court also held that this legitimate expectation could be displaced by a statutory or executive indication to the contrary.

Prior to the Teoh decision, the terms of treaties had not been considered to create rights or obligations in Australian law in the absence of legislation. The High Court confirmed this principle in Teoh. However, the Court distinguished between a substantive rule of law and a legitimate expectation that a decision maker will comply with the terms of a treaty. This distinction would have been likely to disappear in practice.

It is the Government's view that the High Court's decision leads to an untenable situation. It is the Government's role to represent Australia on the international plane and this includes international treaty making. However, any changes to the laws of this country which are necessary to implement a treaty and which affect the rights and duties of individuals are a matter for Parliament. In the Government's view, the Teoh decision provides a means of usurping this legitimate role of Parliament.

Furthermore, the new procedural right will have significant practical consequences in relation to the myriad of Commonwealth decisions made every day by large numbers of individual decision makers. A substantial allocation of resources would have been necessary. All government decision makers exercising discretionary decision making power would have needed to be educated about the numerous treaty obligations to which Australia is a party. Furthermore, by reason of the new procedural right, there would be likely to be a significant increase in the number of decisions appealed. Even on a re-hearing, there would not be a requirement that a decision maker act in accordance with any relevant international obligations. In the Government's view, it is wrong for treaties to have this effect domestically without the law being changed by Parliament.

Australia is a party to over 920 treaties. Australia does not normally become a party to a treaty unless and until it is satisfied that the laws and practices to give effect to that treaty are in place. Therefore the difficulty created by the High Court's decision is twofold: first to determine which treaties could be relevant to a particular decision. Secondly, it would be necessary for the decision maker to determine the precise meaning of a treaty provision in a particular context. This would not lead to consistency in the interpretation of treaties or in decision making. For example, it can be argued that the Convention on the Rights of the Child does not require a different outcome from that reached by the department in Mr Teoh's case. Certainly that was the view of McHugh J dissenting in that case.

Mr President, it has been suggested incorrectly that the bill winds back Australia's commitment to human rights. That ongoing commitment is demonstrated by the continuing importance of the role of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. One of the functions of the Commission as set out in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 is to hear and conciliate complaints about Commonwealth acts and practices which are alleged to breach human rights set out in the instruments scheduled to the act. Those instruments are: the Convention Concerning Discrimination in Respect of Employment and Occupation; the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights; the Declaration of the Rights of the Child; the Declaration on the Rights of Mentally Retarded Persons; and the Declaration on the Rights of Disabled Persons. In 1993 the Convention on the Rights of the Child was declared an instrument relating to human rights and freedoms under the act, as was the Declaration on the Elimination of All Forms of Intolerance and of Discrimination Based on Religion or Belief.

In addition to this mechanism, the Racial Discrimination Act 1975, the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 and the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 provide a legal framework in which the rights they contain are respected in Australia. The International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination is scheduled to the Racial Discrimination Act, and the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women is scheduled to the Sex Discrimination Act. Similarly, the Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment is scheduled to the Crimes (Torture) Act 1988.
These are the domestic remedies specifically provided by Parliament to deal with complaints of breaches of human rights.

I turn now to the terms of the bill itself. The bill is very narrowly focused. It will restore the situation which existed before the Teoh case. That is, if there are to be changes to procedural or substantive rights in Australian law resulting from adherence to a treaty, they will result from Parliamentary and not executive action. The bill gives effect to the statement by the majority of the High Court that a legitimate expectation arising out of entry into a treaty by Australia can be displaced by executive or legislative action. In this respect it gives legislative effect to the Joint Statement issued by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and myself on 10 May of this year.

The bill has a very confined field of operation: it only prevents a legitimate expectation from arising based on the fact that Australia is bound by, or a party to, a particular international instrument, or that an enactment reproduces or refers to a particular international instrument.

To that end, the bill will eliminate any expectation which might exist that administrative decisions, whether at the Commonwealth, State or Territory level, will be made in conformity with provisions of ratified but unimplemented treaties, or, that if a decision is to be made contrary to such provisions, an opportunity will be given for the affected person to make submissions on the issue. That is clause 5, the only substantive clause in the bill. As I will outline below, the bill will not affect other uses of international law in Australia. For instance, the bill will not affect the use of international law by the courts in the interpretation of ambiguous statutory provisions; nor will it affect their use of international law as a legitimate and important influence on the development of the common law.

The reason the bill is expressed to extend to State and Territory decisions is based on the reasoning of the majority judgment of the High Court in the Teoh case. The Court found that it was the Commonwealth act of ratification of a treaty which gave rise domestically to the legitimate expectation that administrative decision makers would comply with the terms of those treaties, or, if they did not intend to do so, that they would hear submissions on them. It is not certain from the judgment whether the administrative decisions affected by that Commonwealth act are only those of the Commonwealth Government, or whether they are also those of the State and Territory administrations.

Since ratification of a treaty is a Commonwealth executive action, it is entirely appropriate for the Commonwealth to legislate to control the effect of that action in Australian domestic law generally. The bill does not prevent any State which wishes to do so from passing a law or taking its own executive actions in relation to treaties accepted by Australia which might themselves create a legitimate expectation. In that case, the legitimate expectation would flow from the State law, and not the Commonwealth executive act of ratification.
Clauses 6, 7 and 8 of the bill put it beyond doubt that Parliament is not affecting the way in which treaties may otherwise have some relevance in Australian law.

Clause 6 provides that the bill will not affect the operation of treaty provisions which have been incorporated into Australian law. An example is certain of the provisions of the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations which form part of Australian law as provided for in the Diplomatic Privileges and Immunities Act 1967.

Clause 7 provides that the bill does not affect the operation of an enactment in so far as it provides for remedies against, or any procedures for redress of grievances in respect of, breaches of international instruments binding on Australia, or to which Australia is a party. In particular, the bill does not affect the operation of procedures available under the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986.

Clause 8 provides that the bill does not affect the operation of an enactment in so far as it provides that compliance with an international instrument is a relevant consideration in making an administrative decision. Nor does the bill make compliance with an international instrument an irrelevant consideration in making an administrative decision where that would otherwise be consistent with the scope and object of the particular statutory provision.

As I mentioned earlier and as the explanatory memorandum makes it clear the use of treaties by the courts both in statutory interpretation and in the development of the common law will not be affected by the bill.

Chief Justice Mason and Justice Deane referred to two uses of treaties in relation to statutory interpretation in their joint judgment in the Teoh case. The first is that "64 where a statute or subordinate legislation is ambiguous, the courts should favour that construction which accords with Australia's obligations under a treaty or international convention to which Australia is a party. . . ". The second is that ". . . a statute is to be interpreted and applied, as far as its language permits, so that it is in conformity and not in conflict with established rules of international law." The bill does not affect either of these canons of statutory interpretation.

Chief Justice Mason and Justice Deane also stated in the Teoh case that "[t]he provisions of an international convention to which Australia is a party, especially one that declares universal fundamental rights, may be used by the courts as a legitimate guide in developing the common law". In making this statement their Honours relied upon a number of earlier judgments to the same effect made by Judges of the High Court. They also relied upon a 1988 decision of Justice Kirby, President of the New South Wales Court of Appeal, in Jago v. Judges of district of New South Wales in which he stated that "[a] more relevant source of guidance in the statement of the common law of this State may be the modern instruments of human rights found in international instruments, prepared by experts, adopted by organs of the United Nations, ratified by Australia and now part of international law."

The bill does not affect the future use of treaties to which Australia is a party as a source of guidance in the development of the common law. They will remain, in the words of the current Chief Justice of the High Court a legitimate and important influence on the development of the common law. This influence of treaties on the development of the common law is to be distinguished from simply importing the terms of an unincorporated convention into Australian law without legislation.

The bill will apply to administrative decisions, made on or after 10 May 1995, including such decisions reviewing, or determining an appeal in respect of, decisions made before that day. This reflects the Government's belief that by reason of the Joint Statement issued on that date by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Attorney-General, no legitimate expectations will have arisen on the basis of an international instrument after 10 May 1995, and the legislation is designed to reinforce this.

Mr President, the Government's decision to legislate in the way I have indicated has been criticised as inconsistent with Australia's commitment to meet its treaty obligations. The Government has reaffirmed its commitment in this regard. It does wish to ensure that its treaty commitments are met, including in administrative decision making. However, for the reasons indicated, it does not believe the Teoh decision is the way to do this.

In order to determine whether there are in fact problem areas in administrative decision making in terms of compliance with treaty obligations, the Attorney-General announced on 5 July this year that his Department will carry out a review. This review, in consultation with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and other Government departments, will initially identify areas of possible concern in relation to the compliance in administrative decisions with the human rights obligations set out in instruments attached to Commonwealth human rights legislation.

The aim of this review is to ensure that full and proper consideration is given to those obligations in the decision making process. The reason for the review is to double check that relevant treaty obligations are being taken into account in administrative decision making, and therefore that Australia is fully implementing the international obligations towards its people that it has voluntarily assumed on the international plane. I say `double check' because international obligations have always been considered very seriously in Australian law and practice.

The review will involve use of existing resources and the Government has not, therefore, set any timetable for its completion. If there are areas where we are not adequately meeting our treaty obligations we wish to know about them. We can then do something to remedy the situation. This review process will be much more effective than development of the doctrine of legitimate expectation to cover treaties in ensuring that proper regard is had to our treaty commitments.
The bill involves no direct financial implications. Its enactment may, however, provide savings in relation to costs of legal action that might otherwise have been brought.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter before us this morning, I think, is one of the most important ever to be considered for referral to a references committee of this Senate. It involves many tens, possibly thousands, of people who have received over the years a wide variety of products made by the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. I have over a considerable period of time presented evidence that many of those people have become ill, that many of those people have become infected with life-threatening diseases and that, indeed, some of those people have died.

PARA.TAB: I presented to the Senate at various times evidence which shows that the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories was aware of dangers associated with some of its products and that it and the Commonwealth department of health ignored warnings in relation to the preparation and distribution of those products and, indeed, continued to distribute products in contravention of the Code of Good Manufacturing Practice.

In that situation I believe this Senate has a responsibility to inquire into matters of such great moment and to report in an inquisitorial way—and that word perhaps suggests overtones of some nastiness because we think of the Spanish inquisition. If the Senate refuses this request, it will force large numbers of people to choose the alternative route, which is the adversarial route.

In relation to the preparation of pituitary hormones, the Senate would know by now that well over 2,500 people received pituitary hormones, either fertility hormones or growth hormones, at various stages over approximately 20 years from the mid-1960s to the mid-1980s. Because some of those people have died of the disease which is known as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, CJD, the Senate would know that a very large number of other people who have been in receipt of those hormones are now suffering very severe psychiatric illness.

One has heard of one family in which the wife received fertility hormones and then succeeded in producing several children but, as a consequence of the subsequent emergence of CJD in other recipients of these hormones, both the wife and the two children are now under constant psychiatric care. One has heard about other people who have not developed CJD but who have been under so much pressure in relation to the receipt of these hormones that they have committed suicide. In addition to the five deaths that have already occurred among these approximately 2,600 people, we have a very large number of people who feel they essentially have the sword of Damocles hanging over them, who feel themselves very much under threat, and who feel themselves absolutely affronted by what CSL did over that long period of time.

If this Senate does not accept an inquiry, it will force those people who are already under this considerable pressure, some of whom are very likely to die, because we know that CJD is a disease with a long latency but when it appears it progresses inexorably to death and quite rapidly, into an adversarial situation in which both the government and CSL will bring out the very best and most expensive lawyers to argue against claims for compensation for the damage these people have suffered. That is absolutely unconscionable.

I appeal very strongly to both the government and the opposition to choose this alternative route—that is, to bring it before a Senate committee in an inquiry type context to allow those scientists who have evidence, some of which I have presented here and I will go back to that in a moment, to come forward under parliamentary privilege and provide the evidence in a non-threatening environment. That should be the very foundation which will allow these people who have been so damaged to mount their cases.

I point out that, while I have put before the Senate a considerable amount of evidence of damage occasioned by CSL, that is not the same as the evidence which could be brought forward under parliamentary privilege by a large number of scientists who want that protection to bring evidence before a Senate inquiry. That would establish a foundation. Those people, in a fair and open way, could then go into the courts knowing what the evidence is on which they may draw.

Maybe I could head off one of the arguments that other senators may use against this proposal by adding that, whereas it is true that the direct evidence which comes before the Senate under such a process cannot be used in a court of law—the Hansard is not evidence which can be used—that evidence can be independently derived within the court. That evidence is then perfectly valid and can be used. It provides the knowledge base which will allow these people to avoid that very arduous, very damaging adversarial process to which many of them are already committed. We are not in any sense denying those people the ability to adduce that evidence in the courts later, and we are not in any sense, by bringing this before a Senate inquiry, acting in a prospective sub judice manner.

In relation to blood products, as I have pointed out in many speeches in this place, there is abundant evidence that the CSL, over a considerable period of time, was mixing blood which had originated in a large number of countries and that that information was kept from very significant recipients of some of those blood products. On 11 October last year, almost a year ago, I raised the issue of the large number of people with haemophilia who had become infected with hepatitis C.

I drew attention to the fact that, while there were only 30,000 cases of hepatitis C infection known throughout the whole of Australia—in other words, the incidence is very low at one person in 500—among the 1,600 sufferers of haemophilia, 85 per cent are suffering from hepatitis C infection. In other words, the people who have this genetic defect of not being able to make Factor VIII and who have received that Factor VIII prepared from mixed plasma—plasma which has come in from other countries and which CSL should have known was infected with hepatitis C—have suffered that very high infection rate because of their need for repeated doses of Factor VIII.

I also drew attention to the fact that it is in the written record between CSL and the Red Cross that this mixing was going on. I drew attention to the fact that on 12 March 1986 the Red Cross wrote to CSL asking it not to mix plasma from foreign sources with plasma from Australia. I pointed out that Mr Neville McCarthy from CSL wrote back on 27 March 1986 defending the practice and saying that no other practice would produce the cheap product.

He was arguing that they needed these very large batches, which they could only get by mixing the plasma from different sources, in order to get high yields and therefore produce a product at lower cost. As a consequence, CSL would continue with the practice of mixing plasma from different countries. In response to that letter, the Red Cross wrote back on 2 May 1986, saying that in view of its legal advice—legal advice to the Red Cross in relation to the safety of its products—it would refuse to continue to use CSL products. That is all in the record.

What we also know of that situation is that plasma was coming in from Hong Kong. We know that a hepatitis C infection in Hong Kong was so widespread that no records were being kept of blood donors in Hong Kong. No testing was being done for hepatitis C in the plasma. Everybody accepted that the plasma would be infected with hepatitis C, so what is the point in testing it? That, in fact, was then being mixed with the Australian plasma from which the Factor VIII was being prepared. Is it any wonder that 85 per cent of people with haemophilia in Australia are infected with hepatitis C?

Following that speech I gave in the Senate back in October last year, I then did an interview on ABC regional radio. Mr Jack Wood from CSL spoke in the same program, as well as a spokesperson from the Haemophilia Foundation of Australia. What was interesting about that interview was that the spokesperson from the haemophilia association said that they did not know. They had been asking for decades what the source of the plasma was which was the basis of the preparation of the Factor VIII which was being received by haemophilia sufferers in Australia. They had been asking for so long, and they had been denied that information.

This is precisely the sort of thing that we are going to get when these poor people come into court and have to argue their case. We are going to get denial and obfuscation—coming from probably some of the highest paid QCs in this country—by both the government and CSL in defending their position.

That situation can be extended to a range of other products. CSL have claimed that there is no evidence of harm arising as a consequence of many of their blood products out in the community. The question that needs to be asked is: have they actually gone back and looked in detail for many of the effects which one might find? The answer there is: no, nobody has looked. The Red Cross does not keep records of people who have received blood transfusions. The Red Cross simply would not know how to follow up those people who have received those products. So the lack of evidence means that nobody has actually looked. This, of course, is precisely the sort of argument that one finds from many of the large chemical companies, the large agricultural chemical companies and the large pharmaceutical companies, when they want to try to deny that their products cause any damage whatsoever.

I have also raised before the Senate a considerable amount of evidence in relation to Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease—a disease which, as I mentioned earlier, is of delayed onset. One does not know exactly what happens to these people who have received pituitary hormones. Although this is not due to CSL, some people have received corneal graphs and some people have received other products—and I will mention that again in a moment—and subsequently, many years later, developed Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. We do not know what happens in that latency period. Nonetheless, when the small number of people who then go on to develop this disease do so, that disease is rapidly fatal. There is no cure and no treatment for it. It is a rapid, neurologically brain destroying disease which leads to death, usually within the course of some months.

I have put evidence before the Senate that, in relation to the preparation of this product, the Commonwealth department of health was warned not to go ahead with the preparation of these hormones. It was warned not to go ahead with the preparation of these hormones because there was a long history of what at that stage were known as slow virus diseases. Some of these diseases were present in sheep. At about the time or shortly before the time CSL began the preparation of these hormones, the processes of kuru, a disease in Papua New Guinea, had been well worked out and understood. The danger that similar agents may exist which could be transmitted through tissue, particularly tissue closely associated with the brain such as pituitary tissue, was clearly evident by the early 1960s.

As I have said in this place, it was also known that those agents were remarkably resistant to most of the sterilising agents available. Very often one sterilises these agents by adding formalin. Sometimes one sterilises them by judiciously heating them to a certain temperature. In both those cases it was known that these infective agents, whatever they were—we did not understand at that stage exactly what they were—were remarkably resistant to those agents and it would be extremely difficult to ensure the sterility of the material going into the preparation of the hormones or indeed, after the preparation, the sterility of the material before it was dispensed for patient use.

Despite that, we find again that pituitary glands were collected from a wide variety of sources. Pituitary glands were not only collected in Australia; they were collected from Papua New Guinea. I have put evidence before the chamber that some of those pituitary glands were actually putrid. They were physically infected with bacteria, yet they went into batches for the preparation of these hormones. That was an atrocious practice to carry on.

I have produced evidence to the Senate that the separation of these hormones was carried out by chromatographic method. It was known that these agents eluted from chromatographic columns before the hormones came out. In other words, every fraction—whether it be the growth hormone; whether it be the two fertility hormones which were of interest in the preparation of these materials—which came out after that separation, after that initial elution from the chromatography column, would be infected with those agents if those agents were present.

Again for that reason, senior scientists went to the Commonwealth department of health and said, `This is too dangerous. Do not go ahead with this preparation.' Yet, the Commonwealth department of health instructed CSL and CSL went ahead with the preparation of these agents. The consequences we now know: five people have died from CJD. We know it is a disease with a long latency. We have no idea how many more people will die between now and possibly 2005-2015, whenever the latency period runs out.

In relation to the preparation of the hormones, I have produced extensive evidence which again is based on the information which has come to me from scientists who want the opportunity to come forward and under parliamentary privilege put evidence into the formal record that CSL did not develop a code of good manufacturing practice, which would have required that the whole process of manufacture—from the selection of the material which went in to the detail of the processes, including the sterility, the packaging and the distribution of the product—be worked out, codified, written down and independently monitored, checked and signed off before the first preparation of these hormones began.

What do we find? We find that in CSL's case, throughout the whole 20 years it developed no code of good manufacturing practice. It continued to change the method of manufacture. It put experimental batches out into the community. It put out infected batches—now grossly infected with bacteria. It put out batches in which the ampoules of the hormones were not even sealed. It had no control over the efficacy, the potency or any of those things which related to a code of good manufacturing practice. This was developed only at the very tail end of the program, just before the program ceased to be applied.

All of that material needs to be put before a Senate inquiry. It is quite unconscionable to expect that these people, the scientists and those concerned—there are many seeking to take legal action against CSL and the Commonwealth—should have to go into an adversarial situation with those very heavy legal costs and heavy legal arguments against them to establish that basic data.

One of the arguments that may well be presented is that it might be damaging to CSL to have this information come out in this way. Whether this Senate inquiry occurs or not, this information is going to get into the public domain. The question of whether this knowledge becomes public is not at issue. The question is simply when and by what route—whether it is going to be by a fair, inquisitorial and non-adversarial route or whether it is going to be by the unfair and adversarial route.

At the time of the sale of CSL, the government provided an indemnity to CSL in relation to certain of its past practices. I have put before the Senate that CSL officers have actually come to my office in Adelaide and attempted to dissuade me from going down the course which I am now pursuing. In the course of that interview, I asked in some detail about the extensiveness of those indemnities provided by government. They said to me that, while the indemnities given at the time of the sale of CSL were not fully comprehensive, nonetheless there was an indemnity given to CSL in 1985 and that that indemnity continued to obtain. When I asked the senior executive officer of CSL if I could have a copy of that indemnity, he did not provide it to me, claiming that it was commercial-in-confidence.

I find that situation also extremely alarming and worrying. Firstly, I would have thought that an indemnity which potentially involved the public in a very considerable amount of expense should be in the public domain. Secondly, I wonder very much about the legality of an indemnity given to a wholly owned government instrument, as it was in 1985, then carrying forward to what is now a totally differently constructed organisation, now in private ownership.

If either government or opposition, particularly opposition, is concerned on the question of indemnity, I simply point out that if those indemnities are indeed valid, if those indemnities are comprehensive, then of course CSL has nothing to fear from the disclosure of this information. I point out again that it will be the government that will have to pick up the tab anyway, one way or another. I suggest that if those indemnities are not comprehensive the government will have to provide another indemnity for CSL.

In that interview with several of the CSL officers I was also told that, in relation to albumin, one of the blood products which CSL makes, there was no risk—and this came up when I asked them why they did not make the semi-synthetic factor 8 for haemophilia sufferers. They said, `Well, even if you make this, certainly the factor 8 is not likely to be infected, but we then mix it with albumin so it might be infected.' CSL said to me—and this was only several months ago—that albumin was, indeed, a completely safe product.

We have learned that recently a liver transplant was conducted, I believe in France, in which the patient subsequently received a preparation of concentrated albumin—this is a plasma expander which is used frequently in surgery. It was subsequently found that the person who had donated the albumin, or one of the people who had contributed to that albumin, died subsequently of CJD; and the person who had received the albumin also died of CJD. The natural background incidence of CJD is only one in a million people. So the odds of that occurring by chance alone are extremely remote. Almost certainly the recipient developed the CJD as a direct consequence of the preparation of albumin which he had received from a person who was infected with CJD.

The significance of this lies in the fact that recently we have seen in Canada the withdrawal on two occasions of very large amounts of blood products, because it has been subsequently found that one of the contributors to those blood products had developed CJD. So this whole issue goes well beyond the past in relation to the risks associated with blood products, or with pituitary hormones, and extends very much into the future and the way in which we continue to prepare these sorts of products.

Of course, what we find again, when we look back to CSL—and this is also related to the inquiry—is that some of the officers, some of the scientists within CSL who were associated with that long period of the preparation of pituitary hormones are still there in CSL in senior positions. One must doubt very much whether those people are competent and whether those people can be trusted to continue to make products which will be safe for the Australian public. So it has a prospective element to it as well. I see that my time has expired, so I will complete my comments in my concluding remarks. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that Senator Coulter has pursued this matter over a long period of time, and I respect his integrity and what he is hoping to achieve. But I have considered this matter on behalf of the opposition, and I have told Senator Coulter that the opposition will not be supporting his reference.

PARA.TAB: I believe that it is fair to explain our reasons for not supporting his reference, because it is a very complex problem. I also think it would be useful if I went over the history of this issue, in part. Then, when it appears in the Hansard or if anybody is listening to this broadcast, they will understand its background. We have heard one side of the issue and it is only fair, both to listeners and to Senator Coulter, to explain in detail why the opposition is not supporting this motion.

The Commonwealth Serum Laboratory was established by the government in 1916 to help with the pharmaceutical needs of an isolated nation then at war. Following an approach from the endocrine society, CSL in 1964 became involved in the preparation of hormones derived from pituitary glands removed at the time of autopsy. Between 1965 and 1985 over 170,000 pituitary glands were collected by CSL—approximately 8,500 glands each year, mostly from public hospitals. A total of 2,100 people received pituitary hormone treatment—1,400 for infertility and 700 for short stature.

I should mention at this stage that Senator Coulter has made no reference whatsoever to the enormous benefit that accrued to those people who had infertility problems or children with short stature. He has not even mentioned one word in that regard. But, to go back to that era, it was a major breakthrough in the management of these people and it was worldwide. Australia was not in isolation in this regard; it was a worldwide development. That was in 1965 to 1985.

It was not until 1971 that the issue of the danger of unconventional slow viral infections transmitted by hormones from collected glands was raised. The first suspected case of person-to-person transmission of CJD was not reported until 1974. The first case of CJD in a pituitary hormone recipient in Australia was not reported until 1988. So the first report did not occur here until 1988. CJD, or Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, is a rare and fatal brain disease. The program was then suspended in 1985 and gland collection ceased in 1986.

Subsequently a study was undertaken to track down the recipients, using Medicare, electoral and Department of Social Security records as well as contacting the last known treating medical practitioner. Eighty-eight per cent of recipients have been traced. Bear in mind that it was unknown at that time what was going to occur. To date, five cases of CJD in hormone recipients have been reported. It should also be borne in mind that CJD does occur sporadically and there are in fact some familial patients. Eighteen people die of CJD each year in this regard—not hormone recipients, but due to those other factors. The disease is characterised by long incubation periods measured in years and decades, and it is fatal. The average incubation time is 12 to 15 years—longer than AIDS.

This research and development was supported by the endocrine society and it, in turn, was supported by the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists, the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons, the Royal Australian College of Physicians and the AMA. So it is all very well to say that scientists were opposing it, speaking in retrospect. But, if we go back to the era when that was developed, every scientific body of any stature in this country supported the development of this program. It is all very well to go back with a `retrospectiscope' and make allegations; but at the time this program was developed every scientific body supported it.

In May 1993 the government commissioned an inquiry into the use of pituitary derived hormones in Australia and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. The inquiry was conducted by Professor Margaret Allars of the Faculty of Law, Sydney University, and the report was tabled in parliament on 9 June 1994. CSL became a public company in June 1994 and the government gave an indemnity regarding past actions. I have been in touch with CSL. They state and have produced evidence to support that they have received an indemnity from the government. I have spoken to the department and they, in turn, have said that an indemnity has been given.

The Commonwealth government has already settled compensation claims by the families of women who have died of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease following administration of hormone products. Again, if I can digress a little to explain it a bit more fully: CJD belongs to a group of transmissible neurodegenerative diseases called unconventional slow viruses or spongiform encephalopathies. Human diseases in this group include diseases apart from CJD. There is Kuru, as Senator Coulter has mentioned, in New Guinea; Gerstmamm-Staussler syndrome; and fatal familial insomnia.

Other diseases in this group actually affect animals. They include scrapie occurring in sheep and goats; transmissible mink encephalopathy occurring in mink; chronic wasting disease occurring in mules, deer and elk; bovine spongiform encephalopathy occurring in cattle; and feline spongiform encephalopathy occurring in cats. I mention all that just to give you the broad spectrum of the fact that we are not just dealing with the disease of humans; we are dealing with an extremely complicated disease where the cause is unknown. It is not as if there is a known cause.

This group of diseases has a number of unique characteristics. Firstly, they are both infections and genetic, as I mentioned. Secondly, they do not cause a detectable immune repose characteristic of conventional viral infections. In other words, there is no test that you can get done to see whether this disease is present or not. Thirdly, they are associated with the presence of abnormal forms of a protein found in its normal form in most organs and cells of the body. That is why this protein is called a prion protein. Nobody is too sure what it is, in fact. Other distinctive characteristics include long incubation periods measured in years and decades and a high resistance to chemical inactivation. The disease is fatal. I mention the chemical inactivation aspect because initially it was thought that formalin inactivation was sufficient, but this prion protein even escapes that.

Information about the link between CJD and pituitary hormone therapy was first conveyed to the Commonwealth department of health by Professor Raiti of the United States National Pituitary Agency. Interestingly enough, Sam Raiti is a Queensland graduate in medicine who graduated with me in 1956 and who subsequently went to the US. I have spoken to him about this matter. He conveyed that information back to Australia at that time.

We have got a situation in which this disease not only is conveyed by some extraordinary fashion through the blood products but also can be transmitted by transplantation. In Germany, it was first found that a product was produced where people had serious head injuries and the dura mater, which covers the brain, was defective after a head injury and had to be replaced. Dura mater transplants were used to cover these defects. It was found many years later that some of these dura mater transplant people also developed CJD.

CJD, as I mentioned, is a worldwide problem. The other aspect that needs to be considered is that nobody knows whether these 2,100 people with pituitary hormones who have had blood transfusions might be transmitting this prion protein by being a blood donor. We just do not know. We are not going to know because there is nothing available to us at the moment to determine whether or not 10, 15 or 20 years down the track somebody who has had pituitary hormone may have got this prion protein in their blood and then transmitted it to an unwitting recipient further down the track.

That might sound horrific, but when this scare occurred in Canada—this is the problem associated with an inquiry of this nature—they had to recall and destroy half the blood products of Canada. The ramifications of this are of immense proportions when you consider that we have to weigh the public good in the overall situation against the likely benefit by a retrospective inquiry into a disease of which we still do not know to this day the scientific basis.

There is another very major aspect in relation to this—that is, the litigation problem. As Senator Coulter has mentioned, there are in excess of 120 stress claims pending in the Supreme Court of Victoria by former patients treated with human pituitary gonadotrophin and human growth hormones of pituitary origin. These claims are novel in that none of the plaintiffs has contracted the disease. We are talking about stress claims or claims in relation to having been the recipient of a treatment and, as Senator Coulter said, psychological aspects of the result of this treatment.

If you want to bring the whole of medicine and the whole treatment aspects into total disarray in this country, you start doing retrospective inquiries into what may or may not have occurred 30, 40 or 50 years ago and say that there are compensable claims. Professor Fiona Stanley, in the latest edition of Australian Medicine, wrote a very good article about litigation. Unfortunately, I do not have it with me or I would be pleased to read some excerpts from it. She said that there are certain things that occur. Because she is more involved in child health, it relates to children's diseases. She said that people have to accept that there are certain things that occur in relation to babies. For instance, a certain percentage of babies that are born with spasticity are part of the reproductive process and it has nothing to do with whether the babies are born by natural means or by caesarean section. The fact that miscarriages occur are part of the reproductive process and are not induced by trauma or other things in many respects.

We are looking here at exciting a debate, if you like, which could have the ramifications of causing an absolute explosion in medical indemnity. We have no way of resolving this. As an aside, it has reached the stage where we have lawyers telling doctors how to treat some neurological diseases because cases have been taken to court. I think this could lead to an extension of the same nightmare that is occurring in some places in the world with regards to medical litigation, particularly in the USA.

There are very valid reasons why the opposition sees no benefit in this inquiry. I understand that the government has addressed this. The Tito report is due to be handed down soon in relation to medical litigation. Senator Coulter mentioned the possibility of a blood product being transmitted during liver transplants. Do you want all the liver transplants that have occurred in this country? Do you want all the renal transplants—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not the liver; it was the concentrated plasma.
—Yes, the blood product used. They are classic examples of blood products. Do you want every coronary bypass recipient, where they have received a blood product?
—He ought to know what the risks are.

—Senator Coulter, you are exemplifying what I am pointing out. Do you want every patient who is ever treated in this country that has had a blood product indemnified against any possibility of the transmission of CJD or any other product—you mentioned hepatitis C—some time in the future because of an unknown basis of a disease at this point in time?
—You are wrong, senator. They did know before 1971, but I will explain that later on.

—The point that I am making is well taken by what Senator Coulter has said himself. There are very strong reasons to make against the establishment of such an inquiry. An inquiry has already been established. It has brought down its findings. It has been stated that its terms of reference were not sufficient to cover this particular aspect, but that is debatable.

PARA.TAB: One has the utmost sympathy for the fact that this has occurred—that five of the 2,100 people have developed CJD, and it is a fatal disease. One has the utmost sympathy for them, and for their families. We know that a similar sort of thing occurred in relation to AIDS. It was very identifiable in that case—haemophiliacs developed AIDS as a result of the use of products, through no fault of their own or anybody's at that time, because the AIDS virus was not known to exist. In this case, the difference is that we do not even know what causes CJD. The other distinction, of course, is that it exists in the community in any case.

In summary, the opposition does not support the reference to the community affairs committee. But if any other evidence is produced that could persuade us that there is greater benefit to the community as a whole in pursuing this matter, we would be happy to re-look at the situation. At the moment we see no benefit in pursuing this matter in the interests of the rest of the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Both Senator Coulter and Senator Herron have made very thoughtful and very informative contributions. I must say it is quite a change from what often goes on in this place. Senator Herron, I was watching the faces of the Hansard reporters as you read through those diseases and conditions. Not only Hansard, but certainly the rest of us, would be very pleased to have a slightly slowed down description of Kuru, spongiform encephalopathies, et cetera. I am not sure that Hansard ever needs my assistance, but I was fascinated to note that. It would be of great assistance, because you brought together for the record some information that would be helpful for anybody who has an interest in this whole area.

PARA.TAB: I emphasise the point that Senator Herron made, too—that while I also very much appreciate the point of view that Senator Coulter has put, he did not give the balanced view of how many other people have actually benefited from all those CSL products, not just the growth hormones or pituitary hormones but all the other products which have enabled a lot of people to enjoy a better quality of life.

None of this should take away from what Senator Coulter was saying regarding the significant percentage of people who have used products produced by the CSL. I am not wanting to say it is therefore proven that those products were causal, but to some extent that is a given, I think. It does not take away from the point you were making, but I do think it is better balanced by saying that these are very unfortunate things, we would prefer they did not happen, et cetera. But it is also important to say how many other people have benefited from CSL products—a point which Senator Herron made which needs to be reiterated.

This has been a very interesting journey. The CJD journey is probably the most interesting. I have actually found almost more to read about it in magazines like Scientist, Nature and the New Yorker, which is one of the best public health journals in the world. I do not know whether you know that, Senator Herron, but some of the best public health investigative journalism that I have read has occurred in the columns of the New Yorker. There are others, of course.

There is this notion of seeing the connection between a disease that is affecting cows, sheep—cats, it seems, too—and humans. It is very mysterious. I suppose what we are looking at is this recognition now that it is probably not a viral transmission but a protein transmission. But we need to know of what sort, how it holds up and whether it is denatured by heat as opposed to not being denatured by chemical matter.

I think Senator Coulter's contributions were very helpful in terms of the basic information that is needed in this area. That being said, the motion is opposed by the government—and I think Senator Coulter was clear about that. We do not feel, for many of the same reasons made by Senator Herron, that a committee inquiry is warranted.

The matters which Senator Coulter raised are largely historical. They go back to times when issues relating to CJD, HIV and hepatitis were not known or fully understood—although I suppose it would be best to say `particularly hepatitis C'. When the dangers caused by these diseases were recognised as a problem, appropriate action was taken by CSL and the Red Cross to minimise the risks involved.

The issues raised by Senator Coulter have already been extensively addressed in the hearing of the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee held on 17 November 1994 and in the responses supplied by the department to questions raised at that hearing. The responses were published in the Senate Hansard of 9 February 1995.

Australia enjoys access to extremely high quality plasma products which are prepared through the use of the latest technology and through codes of good manufacturing practice, which minimise the risks of the likelihood of viral transmissions. All of the latest standards for blood collection and the manufacture of plasma products have been introduced by the Red Cross and CSL.

At the hearings of the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee in November 1994, Senators Patterson and Lees tabled a series of extensive written questions relating to Catherine Beauchamp's report entitled Red Alert: Is Regulation Working for Imported and CSL Blood Products. Written answers to the questions were provided in February 1995 following lengthy consultation with the CSL and the Therapeutic Goods Administration and were published in the Hansard of 9 February 1995. Senator Coulter has raised these concerns in recent speeches in the adjournment debate.

The privatising of CSL was conducted by the assets sale task force in the Department of Finance. The task force acted with the advice of relevant and appropriately skilled consultants. The sale prospectus was duly authorised under the Corporations Law by the board of CSL Ltd. I am advised that the prospectus was pre-vetted under the Australian Securities Commission procedures. The Australian National Audit Office is in the concluding stages of an efficiency audit into the sale of CSL, and it would be appropriate to await its report before spending additional taxpayers' money on an inquiry by the Senate Community Affairs References Committee.

I make the following comments in response to Senator Coulter's points. The CSL has attempted to meet the high standards for the preparation of plasma products, vaccines and other biological products. The standards have changed over the years in the light of experience and have been introduced as required through the code of good manufacturing practice—GMP—and through adoption of the requirement to the British Pharmacopoeia.

Since the implementation of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989, which came into effect through the therapeutic goods regulations on 15 February 1991, CSL has held a licence to manufacture therapeutic goods in accordance with the code of GMP—good manufacturing practice. CSL has been subject to a TGA audit and has been generally found to operate at an acceptable level of manufacture. When some audits have been rated as marginal, CSL has carried out the necessary action to bring the ratings to acceptable. CSL has not aided or frustrated the formulation of the code of GMP. CSL has not opposed inspections by TGA auditors or created any special problems for TGA within the overall process of regulation.

Prior to the implementation of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989, CSL was treated like all other manufacturers and suppliers of therapeutic goods. The company did have a special relationship with the department prior to privatisation because it was indeed part of the department and, as a corporation, answered to the minister through the normal processes.

CSL has a long history in manufacturing biological products in Australia. The company itself has possessed most of the expertise related to the products it has manufactured. Discussions have taken place between the department and the company over many issues relating to the quality, safety, efficacy and availability of products for the Australian market. There is no evidence that information was available to conclude that the manufacture of any product should not have been undertaken at any given time.

In the light of experience, some products have been modified and some have been dropped from the product range. When discussions have taken place, there is no case known where advice has been ignored. There have been cases where products have been recalled from the market, but this has been the result of discussions and mutual agreement and is part of the overall drug regulation process.

Subject to a number of conditions, the Commonwealth has provided a range of indemnities to CSL for pre-sale operations and they cover pituitary gland products, blood products derived from human placentas, AIDS-related claims, pertussis vaccine and asbestos-related claims. The indemnities do not apply to claims caused by, or arising from, a deliberate or reckless failure by CSL to comply with any statutory or common law requirements as the manufacturer of therapeutic products.

The last point in the terms of reference refers to other matters. Neither the department nor I can comment about what that would particularly cover. While the contribution I have made on behalf of the government addresses somewhat different points from those raised by Senator Herron, I think together the points raised do make a very good defence for why government will not proceed with the inquiry at this point.

In particular, I reiterate the importance of knowing. I think, as Senator Herron said, a retrospective judgment is very easy to make but it does not necessarily give us more truth or more accuracy. Particularly when you have diseases with such long lead times as CJD or HIV, I think historical backing up is particularly fraught.

As those areas are covered by indemnity by government, I think it is important that we do not in any way create a situation of health care in this country where people would be afraid to provide health care or people would be afraid to accept it. I think Senator Coulter interjected on Senator Herron, `What people need to know is the risk.' I think most of us would agree that there is an important element of need to know, and as much as possible patients should be provided with that kind of information. But I am not at all sure how you would see the inquiry contributing to information being able to be provided to patients.
I want to conclude my remarks by saying that, while the government is not minded to support this inquiry, I do strongly support the suggestion that people read Professor Fiona Stanley's article.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to put on the record that the Greens (WA) will be supporting the motion of reference to a committee. I can count, like most people in the Senate, and realise that the indications are that the motion will fail. However, I am pleased to hear that Minister Crowley did mention that a better time for this might be when the audit by the Auditor-General's office has been completed.

PARA.TAB: Maybe that is an indication that, once the efficiency audit has taken place as a result of the sale, the government would be prepared to support an inquiry into this matter. It perhaps indicates the very real concern that is felt amongst the community in terms of the whole privatisation debate, levels of accountability and the very fact that a very large proportion of the community do believe that the government has a role to play.

Selling off assets for the sake of selling off assets is not necessarily a particularly wise thing to do. It seems to be driven by ideology more than commonsense. When public interest suffers in order to provide a seemingly improved bottom line, then we have to ask these questions. It is a disappointment that these questions cannot be dealt with in such an inquiry at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—Picking up the first point made by Senator Herron, it is simply not true that I have not spoken in this chamber of the benefits which have been received by those who have received a range of CSL products. Indeed, if Senator Herron wishes to look back at the Hansard, he will see that I specifically mentioned one of the women who has died of CJD as a result of receiving pituitary hormones—
—I meant today, John.

—This debate goes on over some time, senator. This woman, before she died, said that had she known of the risk she nonetheless would have gone ahead and received the hormones because to her having children, spending the first years of life with those children, was more important than her own life. I find that an extremely moving decision by that person. There may well have been other people in that same category who, had a risk been pointed out to them, would have decided to accept the risk. That is the important point.

PARA.TAB: Linked with that, both you and the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) this morning have misled the Senate in a very important and significant way. Both of you have tried to imply that the knowledge that there was a risk associated with the preparation of these products was not available to the Commonwealth department of health, was not available to CSL, before it got into the process of preparation of these hormones.

You yourself, Senator Herron, have pointed out that there are a wide range of similar agents that cause delayed neurological diseases which, when they finally appear in their active form, are rapidly fatal. Some affect humans, some affect a wide range of other animals. Knowledge of diseases of this general class began to appear in the 1930s, not in 1971. One such disease was scrapie in sheep. I want to restate some of the material that I have already read into the record.

In 1934-35 a vaccine prepared against another disease of sheep, louping ill, was used in the United kingdom to vaccinate sheep. The vaccine was prepared from the brains and spleens of sheep and was treated with formalin to sterilise it—a point that both of you have picked up—and to ensure that it did not transmit either this disease or indeed any other disease. This was and still is very largely a practice which is used in the preparation of vaccines.

While the sheep that received the vaccine were protected from louping ill—in other words, the efficacy of the vaccine was ensured—some 18 months to two years later they began to develop scrapie. In short, a vaccine which had been correctly prepared, in which the active agent had been successfully killed and which conferred proper immunity as intended, nonetheless transmitted another fatal neurological disease in an unexpected manner. I point out this was 1934-35.

In 1936 French research showed that scrapie could be transmitted from sheep to goats. Thus we have transmission between species. Thus, 30 years before CSL put human pituitary hormones prepared from human pituitary glands collected at autopsies into the marketplace, we began to collect knowledge of a class of infectious neurological diseases which were transmissible, which were caused by a presumed virus and in which the infectious particle was resistant to formalin—

SPEECH.PARA: one of the most significant agents used in the preparation of products of this kind.

PARA.TAB: For many years the disease kuru, which has also been mentioned earlier by me and Senator Herron, has afflicted some of the tribes in New Guinea. The work of Gadjusec and others in Australia in the late 1950s and early 1960s showed that this was also caused by what came to be known as a slow virus. Kuru was transmitted through the eating of human nervous tissue. It occurred among people who were cannibals.

There is a long latency between the eating of this material and the appearance of the symptoms, but once they appear there is a steady, inexorable progression of mental deterioration leading to death. Remember, this work was in the late 1950s and early 1960s, several years before CSL started to prepare its pituitary hormones.

In 1958, Gadjusec was working on kuru in Australia. He visited England and saw some of the work on scrapie. He published work on kuru in 1959 in the Lancet. By 1963, kuru was shown to be a transmissible disease, and the agent responsible for its transmission was shown to be resistant not only to formalin but to ultraviolet light, phenols and to autoclaving.

In other words, here we had knowledge, years before CSL got into the preparation of pituitary hormones, of a transmissible disease in humans that caused these neurological diseases after a latency period and which was resistant to all these commonly used agents. This knowledge did not come afterwards, it came well beforehand.

Some of the work on kuru—this is highly significant—by Gadjusec was actually done in the CSL laboratories, and CSL scientists at the time must therefore have been well aware of the work going on with kuru, the infectious nature of the causative agent and the nature of the disease process.

By 1966, CJD had been shown to be a transmissible disease and, by 1970, CJD had been transmitted in the laboratory to a range of other primates. That sets the background against which CSL entered the business of preparing pituitary hormones. By the early 1960s—

TALK.START.PARA: —But they didn't know it was transmitted by blood products.

—We are talking about pituitary hormones now, Senator. By the early 1960s, it was known that there was a group of transmissible infectious diseases affecting nervous tissue, brain and spinal cord, in which the active disease appeared many years or decades after first infection. Moreover, the agents responsible for these diseases were very resistant to all the normal sterilising agents and there was no treatment for these diseases once they manifested themselves. The diseases were then fairly rapidly progressing, with death the inevitable result.
—You are misleading the Senate.
—I am not misleading the Senate.
—Yes, you are, because it was not known it was transmissible by blood products at that stage.

—We are talking about the transmission through the preparation of pituitary hormones—and it was known. This particular disease was not known but we did know that there was a whole range of diseases which were transmissible. Even now, there may be other diseases which are transmissible about which we do not know. By God, I hope that, in our ignorance, we do not go on assuming that we can do these things without at least forewarning people that there may be a risk.

PARA.TAB: There probably are diseases of this very class which we do not yet understand. What we did know then was that there was a range of these sorts of diseases that were transmissible, that you could not kill, and therefore there was a risk associated with the preparation—

TALK.START.PARA: —Therefore you shouldn't use any blood products.

—We are not talking about blood products, we are talking about pituitary hormones. It was very likely that there would be other diseases which would be discovered which would show similar characteristics. We can never be sure that all the diseases have been discovered.

PARA.TAB: In June of 1963, CSL was asked, as Senator Herron said, to investigate the manufacture of pituitary hormones. These have been made on a small and experimental scale by individuals working out of university laboratories.

Three of the many pituitary hormones were of particular interest: the growth hormone, the follicle stimulating hormone, and the luteinising hormone. The latter two are responsible for the formation and ripening of the Graafian or egg follicle in the ovary and the formation of the corpus luteum which maintains pregnancy—the fertility hormones. The use of these two had been shown to be effective in treating some cases of infertility in women.

Growth hormone had been shown to be effective in stimulating the growth of stunted children. I do not doubt that there are stunted children today who, even understanding the risks, would feel that the use of these agents in their case is worth the risk.

The work at CSL was undertaken. The bulk production of these hormones involved the collection of pituitary glands from human cadavers, the making up a batch of such glands and the extraction of the hormones from these glands. As it turned out, some 1,300 glands were combined before the extraction process was applied. So if even one of these pituitary glands was infected with one of these agents, in our humble acceptance of our ignorance, we should have at that stage accepted the fact that there would be other agents yet to be discovered.

TALK.START.PARA: —But did you write to CSL then? You were a medical scientist. Did you write to them then when you were a scientist?

—I was not working in this particular field. I am not omniscient, and neither are you. I am saying that the people in CSL knew, and they were warned; and the people in the Commonwealth department of health knew, and they were warned. Thus, it was likely that the inclusion of a single gland which was infected with one of these slow virus agents would have infected the whole batch. Also, it would be essentially impossible to sterilise either the batch or any of the separated hormones. By the very nature of these agents, it would be impossible to tell whether any particular pituitary gland was infected.That is another important point, because no care was taken by CSL in relation to the sources from which these pituitary glands were collected.

PARA.TAB: I believe that there was enough knowledge; in fact, I do not even have to assert that. I will assert that, if this reference were put before the committee, a scientist would come forward and produce letters which he presented to the Commonwealth department of health, warning them not to go ahead with this preparation for all the reasons that I have mentioned: that there may well be an agent present; you would not know whether the agent was present; you would not be able to sterilise; and all the preparations which were made by this method would become infected if the agent were present and, therefore, there was the danger of transmitting one of these diseases. That is the very point.

It may well be that even with that evidence, and CSL presenting the evidence of benefit, in a Senate situation or in a court situation, people might say, `Well, it was reasonable for CSL to go ahead under these circumstances.' But let the evidence be put on the table. Let it be put on the table in a Senate committee situation and not in this adversarial situation, where we will hear the eminent and expensive QCs for the government, for the Commonwealth department of health and for CSL defending against these individuals who feel so much threatened by the impact that these diseases may have on them.

I believe in another important respect the minister has misled the Senate this morning. She talked about the TGA. The TGA did not even come into existence until long after the episode with the preparation of pituitary hormones. The imposition of good manufacturing practice by the TGA is totally irrelevant to the period that we are considering, the mid-1960s to the mid-1980s.

Prior to the formation of the TGA—and evidence of this could be given to this Senate inquiry, if it were to get up, by scientists who were involved in the attempt to prepare a code of good manufacturing practice—CSL resisted the development of a code of good manufacturing practice and did that quite consistently, as I said earlier, up until the mid-1980s, for the very good reason that they were not observing any code of reasonable manufacturing practice, let alone good manufacturing practice, with respect to the preparation of these pituitary hormones.

When you have batches which are infected and which are defective, and you bring them back into the laboratory, and then you mix those batches back with fresh material and put them out again for patient use, is that a code of good manufacturing practice? That is not good manufacturing practice. It happened not only with respect to this; it happened, Senator Herron, also with respect to the preparation of antivenenes.

TALK.START.PARA: —How did they know they were infected with CJD? How did they know. What test?
—I would like the scientists concerned to come before your committee and tell you precisely—this is the whole point of the debate this morning—
—There was no test.
—I am now talking about gross bacterial infection—I am not talking about CJD—and materials being brought back, reprocessed and sent out for patient use. That is what CSL was doing.

PARA.TAB: Senator Herron also mentioned the Allars report. Professor Allars reported, as I said in the Senate on 10 May 1995, that the terms of reference of her inquiry did not allow her to examine CSL's product liability, and information in CSL's material therefore could not be properly assessed. The point is that the terms of reference of the Allars inquiry were such that there were many matters—I have gone into considerable detail in relation to these—regarding the code of good manufacturing practice, or the failure of the code of good manufacturing practice, which Professor Allars could not go into, did not go into and did not report upon. So the essential aspects to this inquiry are, to some extent, outside the terms of reference of the Allars inquiry. Therefore, the Allars inquiry is not entirely relevant to what we are discussing this morning.

I conclude by saying that when some months ago I attempted to get this inquiry into place, I was told by various members of the opposition that the person I should speak to is Dr Michael Wooldridge, the shadow minister for health. So I went around to see Dr Wooldridge in his office. He said to me, `I have looked at this issue quite closely but some time ago and I am a little bit rusty on it. I would like you to tell me exactly why you want this inquiry.' So I spent about three-quarters of an hour with Dr Wooldridge running through in considerable detail much of the material that I have run through this morning. His response to me in relation to a Senate inquiry on this matter was—I think I am quoting him quite fairly and accurately—that, if CSL were still in public ownership, he would have no qualms whatsoever about having a Senate inquiry but now that CSL is in private hands he is very worried about the share price of CSL.

This is what lies behind the opposition's opposition to this reference. Dr Wooldridge is the pretender to the ministry of health, and here he is placing a higher priority on the share price of CSL than he is on the health and the welfare of the people of Australia. I find that absolutely—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Coulter is imputing motives to Dr Wooldridge when he has no opportunity to reply to that. I think that it is not, under one standing order anyway, within the capability of a senator in this chamber to cast aspersions on the integrity of a person in another chamber. I ask Senator Coulter to withdraw that imputation.

—On the point of order: what I am doing is accurately reporting to the Senate what Dr Wooldridge said to me. I am not imputing any motives whatsoever. Dr Wooldridge is quite capable in that other place of standing up, if he wishes to, and making a personal explanation to put that also into the Hansard record.
