I am reporting exactly what happened and not imputing any motives whatsoever.

—On the point of order: Senator Coulter recounted a conversation, but then subsequently said that this was the reason the opposition was opposing. I refute that completely. I never mentioned it in my speech, and I am replying on behalf of the opposition. It was a direct attack on the integrity of Dr Wooldridge and I ask him to withdraw it.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—On the point of order: I listened most carefully because there was certainly at least danger that a member of another chamber of this parliament, the House of Representatives, was being reflected upon in the words that you were including in your speech, Senator Coulter. The last point Senator Herron made is not strictly a point of order. He was making a clarification of the opposition's position, refuting what you said, and he has the right to stand at the end of your speech to make that brief addition or clarification. However, I did feel that the words you were using, from a private conversation, were imputing motives to a member of another house. I would simply ask you, Senator Coulter, to clarify that you are not imputing motives to a member of another house. Then I would ask you to continue your speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not imputing motives to a member of another house. I will move on, then, and deal with this issue of the share price of CSL as an issue in its own right. If the indemnities which have been given to CSL are indeed comprehensive and robust, then there need be no worry. It will not affect the share price of CSL for the simple reason that all CSL and the government have to do is say, `Indemnities are in place. Whatever the costs are, the government is going to pick up the tab. CSL does not have to pick up any of this cost whatsoever.' Consequently, the share price will not be affected.

PARA.TAB: If, on the other hand, the indemnities could be inadequate—I believe that they may well be inadequate, and this is one of the other things the Senate inquiry could tease out because I have been prevented from seeing those claimed 1985 indemnity documents—and the share price starts to fall, as they well might do, then of course the government would have to very quickly ensure that those indemnities were modified and fresh indemnities given to CSL which would in fact cover it completely for any claims which go back to that earlier period when CSL was in public ownership.

The other interesting aspect of this is something the minister said when she pointed out quite correctly that CSL would not be covered, even under the indemnities, for any recklessness on its behalf in the preparation of its products. What I have said this morning, what scientists would say if they could come before this Senate committee that I am attempting to establish, and what scientists will probably say in the courts is that CSL was indeed reckless and did not observe proper standards of behaviour as scientists working in laboratories in relation to the sterility of their equipment, to mention another thing. Between batches they evidently did not sterilise their chromatography columns.

Under those circumstances, there may well be an effect on the share price of CSL. It may well be that CSL is not covered under its indemnity, nor could it be covered under its indemnity. That bears very much on the issue Senator Margetts has raised in relation to privatisation.

I simply say that this is not a matter of whether this information comes out; it is simply a matter of how and when this information comes out. I believe that it is absolutely unconscionable, and I repeat, unconscionable, for this Senate to ignore the wishes of such a large number of people—over 600 of them around Australia just in the CJD support groups alone—who want this inquiry up, and that it should force those people to go into the threatening, adversarial environment of the courts, against very powerful forces, to establish that they have a legitimate claim.

I conclude where I began: this is pre-eminently an issue that should come before a Senate inquiry; it is not an issue that should go first to the courts. It may well go to the courts afterwards, but it is pre-eminently an issue that is appropriate and correct for a Senate committee to inquire into. I would urge the Senate to support this reference.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Before putting the motion moved by Senator Coulter, I make the interesting observation that there have been three medical graduates who have contributed to this debate: the mover, Senator Dr Coulter; the Minister for Family Services, Senator Dr Crowley; and the spokesman for the opposition and the Chairman of the Senate Community Affairs References Committee, Senator Dr Heron.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I will make a very brief statement. I must say that I am not so qualified as my colleagues in that respect. I had hoped to speak on this matter, but I did not get down in time to do so. But, lest there is not going to be a division called, I indicate my support for the reference of this matter to a Senate select committee.

—by leave—I raise the point that at no time during the debate in the party room was the matter of CSL shares raised at all. It may well have been—we have only Senator Coulter's word that it was—raised by Dr Wooldridge in a private conversation, but it was one point in three-quarters of an hour of conversation, according to Senator Coulter. So, with respect, I think it reflects on Senator Coulter that he reports a private conversation in this chamber which is unverified.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Austudy Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1995 No. 132 and made under the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973, be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: The regulations to which I refer are those which the government formulated and gazetted on 8 June 1995. These regulations may represent—I say this quite deliberately—a new additional total expenditure and savings means test for Australia's social security system. Under this regulation, Austudy benefits are to be withdrawn from students in self-employed families unless the parents pass a new means test on their total expenditure and savings as well as on their income and assets.

PARA.TAB: The new expenditure means test includes benefits received from relatives. No other group in the community is subject to such a means test. The government has brought in these regulations with a commendable objective in mind with which I believe no-one has any disagreement, and that is to overcome rorts in the Austudy area. No-one questions the stopping of welfare abuses, but families who are paying full Australian tax have a right to feel abused if their children are denied equal access to benefits for which they are paying.

It is also unclear why the self-employed should be subject to a new means test on total expenditure and savings by a government which at the last election opposed expenditure taxation as it felt it was unfair. That is rather ironic, I would have thought. Will the government apply the same treatment to other pensions and benefits? If gifts from relatives are to be counted as a recipient family's means, why is the government double-dipping by not allowing income tax deductions to relatives making such gifts, and I will come back to that issue in a moment.

By all means, let us have a debate about proper targeting of social payments, but change should be consistent, fair and equitable. If the government is saying that there will be a social wage compensation for higher taxes on families, let us hear now whether it intends to extend the new expenditure and savings means test. Will mothers in families with a self-employed spouse or those receiving a bequest under a parent's will be subject to the additional expenditure and savings means test on their family payments or on their home child-care allowance? Will every pensioner receiving gifts from adult children be deemed out of his or her pension? These are issues which the government must answer. Obviously, they extend beyond the portfolio with which we are dealing now—the narrow area of Austudy. In the time that I have been here very often a precedent has been established and then it is referred to and the precedent is used in other areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —So this is a political point?

—Precisely. I am worried about the possibility of this being the thin end of the wedge. These Austudy regulations are an enormous precedent for the whole area of social expenditure. The government must be challenged to declare its intentions. If it admits that it would not be fair to apply the new additional expenditure and savings means test to all families and to all social benefits, let it explain why it is selectively attacking one class of families receiving Austudy.

PARA.TAB: Let me go to some of the particularities that require specific answers from the government. The new designated parents for the purposes of these regulations are defined in regulation 12L of the Austudy regulations. Regulation 12L(1)(a) includes business migrants and regulation 12L(1)(b) includes persons who have an interest in an asset located outside Australia or a proprietary company or an unlisted public company or a trust. I notice that in a speech on the matters of public interest debate on 20 September Senator Baume had something to say about what that could encompass. I will not refer to those because, no doubt, he will do so in his submission to the Senate.

A trust could cover a wide range of persons. It could cover persons who are PAYE taxpayers and people who are on wages and salaries. Theoretically, every worker has an interest in a trust. Superannuation funds are trusts. It is all right for the government to say, `They are not meant to be covered', but as far as I can see, they are. It is not what the desire of the government is; it is what is included in law. Once these regulations become law, they will be treated as such by the persons who may be disadvantaged by them or by an interpretation of them. These are the things that we have to come to grips with.

The regulation states that a designated parent derives income from a source outside Australia and is a self-employed person or is a partner in a partnership. So the self-employed are being targeted. I heard Senator Boswell, on behalf of the National Party—I think it was on behalf of the opposition—yesterday or the day before, waxing quite eloquently. I enjoyed his speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —And enthusiastically.

—And enthusiastically. He was absolutely right about what he was saying. He was saying the government was discriminating, in the other area which he was talking about, against the self-employed, against all of those people in country towns. I think he mentioned people selling tractors, the automobile industry, the small businesses, the small emporiums and so forth in country towns—self-employed people. These people are going to be disadvantaged and discriminated against by these regulations, except, as it says in 12L(1)(d):

SPEECH.PARA: . . . (except a primary producer to whom subregulation 19(2) applies).

Of course, the government, in a political decision, exempts primary producers. They are a powerful lobby group. I believe they should not be included in this new expenditure and savings means test. But here we have, under the regulations, in one rural community, the self-employed, who happen to be selling a tractor to the farmer, covered by the strictures of these regulations, while the farmer is not. It would be interesting to hear the government's explanation for that apparent discrepancy.

PARA.TAB: I ask the government: do they think farmers are so stupid that they do not realise that once you get this through for the self-employed, even though you exempt farmers on this occasion, you will grab them in the next round? They are not silly enough that they cannot see the writing on the wall.The next point I want to raise is this whole question of 12N, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes of subregulation 12K(1), the actual means of a designated parent for the period of eligibility are taken to be the total expenditure and savings made in that period by the parent and his or her family.

That is a very broad definition of expenditure and savings. I know the government intends it to be limited to domestic expenditure but it is not defined as such. It is not limited to domestic expenditure. The government must be clear and have these regulations say precisely what are the total expenditure and savings they mean. At present it appears to be unlimited.

PARA.TAB: Does this mean that the self-employed are to be tested on gross income, with no allowance for tax deductible expenditure, which represents a cost of earning income? What happens if family A and family B make gifts to each other? Do those gifts get counted as means of both families, though neither family is net better off?
The next subparagraph, 12N(3), states:

If the Secretary reasonably believes that a transaction engaged in by a person, other than the parent or a member of his or her family, is a transaction engaged in for the benefit of the parent or a member of his or her family, the Secretary must impute a value to the transaction, for the purpose of this regulation, that the Secretary considers to be the fair market value, as if the parent or member of his or her family had expended the amount.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two things about that clause and about 12N as a whole. Gifts by a grandparent of a self-employed family will be covered. If a grandparent gives money for education or whatever to the son or the daughter of a self-employed person, that would be taken into account for the purpose of assessment as part of that designated parent's total expenditure and saving; but only if that designated parent is self-employed, not if the designated parent was a farmer or a PAYE taxpayer. Why that discrimination? Don't you see the ludicrous nature of that?

PARA.TAB: It happens quite frequently that a grandparent is taxed on that part of the income which he or she is transferring to the family for the education of the children. They are taxed there. That is going to be taken into account and virtually taxed, for the purpose of Austudy, against the designated parent. The grandparent cannot claim that as a taxation deduction. That is the government double dipping. If you are going to acknowledge transfers for one particular purpose adverse to the recipient you should give a concessional benefit to the person making the donation. You cannot have it both ways. I know that is a more fundamental matter than the narrow Austudy area, but it is very vital. It is a matter, I believe, of social justice.

The real problem is that families are not treated logically or fairly. If a payment is to be regarded as a particular person's means or income—in this case, the designated parent—then the donor should not be taxed or income tested on that particular private income transfer. The transfer is within a particular family—an extended family, in this case.

The other thing is that the Social Security Act exempts family gifts—for example, from grandparents to families. If the new total expenditure and savings means test is right and proper for one class of family for one social welfare scheme, as the government is suggesting it is in this scheme, how long will it be before it is applied to all other pensions and benefits and all recipients of government payments?

I would like to point out one particular area. When it comes to regulations 12N(2) and (3), the ones I have been discussing, how is the secretary going to be able to exercise his statutory duty under those regulations to deem a market value for transactions when there are literally hundreds of millions of unrequited interfamily transactions each year? Take just one example: is the secretary going to assess the value of child care provided by grandparents for self-employed families with Austudy students? That is what it literally means. I am sure the government does not mean that, but that is what the Austudy regulations, as they are being discussed here, literally mean.

If grandparents are baby-sitting for the spouse of a self-employed person and that spouse wants to assist in the business, is that gift going to be assessed by the secretary? Will the secretary have to issue copious rulings like the tax office to declare what are acceptable birthday or Christmas gifts in the case of a designated parent who is self-employed? These are the sorts of things that the government needs to address. I think it is important for the Senate to exercise its power in this regard, because we do have a responsibility for seeing that regulations are fair, just and equitable.

To my mind, this regulation does not meet that test. I believe the government should withdraw the regulation and have another go at it. I am only one person in this chamber, but I feel quite strongly about that, particularly where I am coming from, because I believe the whole taxation system so far as families are concerned is quite discriminatory, in any event. I do not say that it is discriminating; it is discriminatory against families.

As I say, I am only one person in here. I believe the onus really is on others who may be giving consideration to these regulations. First of all, the onus is on the government, I believe, to withdraw the regulations, tighten them up and put them in a form which will not be capable of being administered in a dictatorial fashion.

TALK.START.PARA: —And so that it meets the minister's statements. It does not meet the minister's statements.

—As Senator Baume says, it does not even meet the minister's statements. I disagree, frankly, with some of the minister's policies on this particular matter. But in so far as it is intended to overcome the rorts of the situation, then it is not going to do that unless there is an el supremo in the department who is going to administer these regulations in the manner that that person deems to be appropriate.
—Not more deeming!
—Yes, it will be a deeming matter.
—An omnipresent bureaucrat.

—Yes. That is a problem for the administration of the law in this country. I suggest the government does withdraw it and at least, as Senator Baume said, gives us another range of regulations which will implement what the minister meant, and then we can have another look at it. I understand that this morning there will be discussion around the chamber and then at some particular stage the minister may move the adjournment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Harradine, the opposition has quite a number of reservations about this particular measure before the chamber at the moment. Everyone, I believe, in this chamber would support the proper targeting of Austudy—people who receive this sort of benefit should be the people who are entitled to receive the benefit. But we have very grave concerns about the way in which the government is now proposing to determine that.

PARA.TAB: The opposition, together with members of the government and the Democrats, held a major inquiry into Austudy earlier this year. Our report came out in June. This report was a result of our concerns in estimates hearings last year about the way in which Austudy is administered, and what is proposed today is another nightmare set of regulations which, we believe, may be impossible to administer.

This department has a very poor record, in terms of the Ombudsman, in the way in which it goes about administering the regulations it already has under its jurisdiction. Last year there were seven major complaints to the Ombudsman about the way in which Austudy regulations were administered. Half the complaints about DEET to the Ombudsman were in relation to Austudy regulations.

We took evidence on these problems right round Australia. We did this because when we put the proposition to the head person in Austudy about the Ombudsman's report she said, `Well, that is just the Ombudsman's opinion. Who is the Ombudsman?' It was that sort of arrogance that we took exception to and that is the reason we set up the inquiry.

Having taken evidence right around the country on this matter, we then came up with 22 recommendations in this report for the tightening up of Austudy. One of those recommendations referred to this matter under consideration. We received quite a lot of anecdotal evidence about the rorting of Austudy and the inadequacy of the current way in which government determines whether people are eligible or ineligible through their tax arrangements. Much evidence was given to us—and I must say it was not scientific evidence; it was anecdotal evidence—that the Austudy system was being rorted under the current arrangements and certainly should be tightened up.

We had evidence given by quite a number of students in different parts of the country about this matter. We decided that we would make a recommendation that would tighten that up. One of those examples in the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: I had a boy that was in the same volleyball team as my son. His parents lived everywhere, travelled overseas. He was getting AUSTUDY and so was his brother; they both had units because their parents had bought them a unit. They both had cars. He was getting AUSTUDY and so was his brother.
Another example states:

The one I teach with is married. They have a business; they have a second house that they rent, and she is getting AUSTUDY. I asked my students, just before I came on Friday, who was getting AUSTUDY. Of the ones getting AUSTUDY, each child's parents owned a business, and then the ones who were not getting it are the ones that are poor.

It was that sort of evidence that the government is responding to in this report. It is anecdotal. There is no suggestion and no studies have been done to prove that it is widespread. One fears that what the government is doing here yet again is taking an ant-sized problem and hitting it with a sledgehammer, with a set of regulations that are going to have horrendous compliance implications.

PARA.TAB: We did not like the way in which it was done under the current tax arrangements. We suggested that the government go away and try to come up with a new scheme so that people could arrange their affairs through the tax system and not get Austudy unfairly. I still believe that principle is quite sound but we have before us a proposal that I wonder how on earth people could comply with fairly. I wonder how on earth a government could actually administer such regulations.

Currently, there is one Austudy official for every 100 students on Austudy. The reason for that is the complexity of the regulations—the overpayments, the requirements to repay. The whole system really needs to be redesigned from scratch because it has grown in such a way that it has become an administrative nightmare. And what the government has proposed is yet another administrative nightmare.

Under the regulations, the government has come up with a notional parent with which actual parents are compared. A notional parent is someone on PAYE income. When they compare someone who is self-employed with the notional parent, if they are earning less than the notional figure, they are obviously entitled to Austudy. But to determine that, the government has come up with this rather harebrained scheme of actually measuring people's expenditure.

The mind boggles as to how you are actually going to do that. Are you going to require people to bring in all their receipts from K-Mart and all their bankcard slips? Will everyone have to keep receipts of every item of expenditure? What if you pay cash and do not receive a receipt? Will you have to ask for a receipt?

I have spent three study periods overseas as an academic under a scheme where you had to prove what you spent. So I actually had to do that but, fortunately, it was for only about three months. It used to take me an hour to an hour and a half every night recording expenditure in the right column, and checking the receipts. This government is now proposing that parents who are often very poor and who might not have a high level of education—they certainly will not be tax accountants and would not be able to afford to employ a tax accountant to do this for them—will have to keep every receipt.

This government has actually ruined small business in this country because of its regulations and the compliance costs associated with them. Now it is going one better and is doing this to parents, to the ordinary people out there who really have much better things to do with their time than fill out a whole lot of forms for the government and keep records of a whole lot of receipts.

We need to tighten up Austudy. We have a unanimous Senate report that says that we need to tighten up and target Austudy better and that we need to come up with another system than the one currently based on income tax. But when I looked at this proposal this morning I was absolutely horrified at the way in which the government is proposing to do that.

This proposal would be an incredibly costly exercise. It will take up a lot of the time of parents. Who is going to check all this? Will you have to employ another army of bureaucrats to check everyone's expenditure? As I mentioned earlier, there is already one public servant for every 100 Austudy recipients. What will this measure change that ratio to?

The government needs to look at our report again, look at the 22 recommendations, and try to come up with a system that does not require people to understand such complex sets of regulations and does not take up their time and money in compliance. We need a system that is fair and equitable. The government has a very long way to go on this issue before it satisfies the parents and students who are entitled to Austudy and should be receiving it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think anyone in this chamber would deny that there is evidence, a lot of it anecdotal, that Austudy is being rorted. People who are well-off have been able to cheat the system to the disadvantage of taxpayers of Australia and to the anger of many people who have honestly stated what their income is, on the basis of their tax returns and taxable income, and have failed to get Austudy for their children, yet see their neighbours' children going off to whatever educational institution and receiving Austudy unfairly while they do not—unfairly as a result of cheating.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Minister Free) said that he was going to introduce regulations that were aimed at stopping families `with complex company or other financial structures'—they were his words—from rorting the system. If that is the objective, surely we have to look at the gap, the horrendous gap, between the objective and what the bureaucracy has provided him with as the answer. This is the test of good government. The test of good government is that, when you set out to resolve a problem, you can tell whether the advice you get from the bureaucracy is self-serving, incompetent or meeting an agenda which, frankly, is not acceptable—which is what this government has done in this case—or, if you are an effective and efficient government, sorting the wheat from the chaff in terms of advice and doing what is right and sensible.

This government has been here too long. It does not know the difference between wheat and chaff—that is one option—or it, in fact, shares the agenda of the bureaucracy that provided this empire building answer, a wrong and offensive answer, to this problem. Once again, this answer is aimed at belting small business, little family partnerships, the battlers in the independent area, particularly those at the lower end of the scale and those who send their children to Catholic systemic schools, which is the major element of the non-state system.

This seems to me to be aimed against people who are least able to protect themselves. They are the people—many of whom have lost their jobs in `the recession we had to have'—who have started off independently, struggling to run their own businesses, their own little partnerships. It might be a house cleaning partnership, husband and wife; it might be a lawn mowing partnership. If you are in a partnership, you get donged by this mallet—this incredible imposition by this government—because it has accepted without question advice of an empire building bureaucracy.

In future, instead of the simple system we had in the past—which was being rorted, and I acknowledge that up-front—where, if you are a PAYE earner, you have clear, evident taxable income and so on and you can see what it is, a new hoop has to be jumped through by anyone—and I read from section 12L—`who has an interest in an asset'—it does not matter what size—`located outside Australia and its external territories'. That may well be properly aimed at many migrants, particularly business migrants who have perhaps come to Australia and have hidden assets overseas or assets overseas which really indicate that they are much better off than maybe the local situation indicates. How you fix that is a matter that we can, once again, examine if we have a proper examination of it, but there has been no proper examination so far.

What is worse, this section mentions anyone who has an interest—no matter how large—in a proprietary company. How many families have proprietary companies—particularly little family businesses like corner stores—for the purpose of having limited liability? Having a proprietary company is no indication of wealth—none at all. Some proprietary companies are owned by wealthy people and so on, but having a proprietary company is, of itself, no indication of wealth and no cause in itself for forcing people to jump through these new hoops.

Senator Harradine has mentioned what I mentioned the other day, and that is this section mentions anyone who has an interest, no matter how big or small, in a trust or a similar arrangement. As Senator Harradine pointed out, superannuation funds are effectively trusts, and that is obviously a nonsense. The section also mentions anyone who `derives income from a source outside Australia'. I think that is an issue that is worthy of detailed examination.

But how about this: this section also mentions anyone who `is a self-employed person except a primary producer'. There are so many self-employed persons. For example, many truck drivers are self-employed persons. Are these some kind of new elite that have to be clobbered by this government? I find this absolutely incredible. As I said, there is no suggestion that these self-employed people should be rich. Even worse, there is no requirement whatsoever that the objectives that the minister stated—that is, having a complex company or other financial structure—should be met. Is being self-employed a complex financial structure? What bureaucrat dreamt up this response to the minister's proper concerns?

The section also mentions `a partner in a partnership'—for example, a husband and wife in partnership in a cleaning business. They are rich, terrible people. They have to be hassled. They have to be made to jump through these new hoops that Senator Tierney outlined.

A very substantial volume of expense, both in time and money, will be involved in people making application in the future. Imagine the cost of compliance is this area—an area where this government has adopted one of the most arrogant possible approaches we could see. As long as the cost of compliance is not too large to the government, it does not matter what the cost of compliance is to the Australian citizen, particularly if he or she is a small business person, is self-employed, is in a partnership or is, in fact, not in the great Labor mafia, if you like, of a trade union, where they would be part of the trade union and often big business and big government organisations, which can happily speak to each other.

The people who are on the outer in Australia under this government are people like the self-employed, those in partnerships and those who might have a little family company. They are the people who are the enemy, apparently, of this government. They are certainly the enemy in relation to these regulations. These regulations are aimed at these battlers in Australia, many of whom have become self-employed because their employment was terminated under the recession we had to have—Mr Keating's recession.

We have to look at this and say, `Okay. The government has a problem. It has set out to resolve it in the wrong way,' but let us recognise this: there is no discretion in these regulations. If you have an interest in, you are classed to be a designated parent and the designated parent has to, with no qualifications, jump through this additional hoop. I would not be in favour of providing legislation or regulations where there is discretion if it is possible to do it in another way.

Wherever you have discretion you have uncertainty, and uncertainty before the law is one of the worst elements of the law. But the lack of discretion here makes it intolerable. In other words, should we not look for a better way of solving the problem than the self-serving, empire building way that the bureaucracy has managed to con past this government? I would suggest that there are better ways.

Taking expenditure, of itself, can be totally misleading. Expenditure can mean lots of things. Under the tax act, for example, you are allowed to depreciate capital items you buy. In other words, a partnership involved in house cleaning might outlay a couple of thousand dollars on a hot-shot vacuum cleaner, but that can be depreciated in terms of diminishing income over some years—say, five years or whatever the life of the thing is under depreciation arrangements. In other words, it does not count as a lump expenditure in that sense.

There is nothing in these regulations which applies the same sort of concept. Under this, expenditure is expenditure is expenditure. We have to establish just what it means. There is nothing in these regulations to do so. In other words, you are going to be worse off because of the interpretation of expenditure here than if you had the normal tax application of this concept applied.

Clearly, on almost every ground, the way the government has been advised—it has accepted that advice—to resolve this problem is the wrong way. How shall we do it better? I mentioned the tax act a minute ago. This raises an interesting question. Who are the government really targeting? Are they really targeting whom the minister says they are targeting; that is, those people who have rorted the system, who have relied on complex company and other financial structures improperly to get Austudy?

Let us look at the ways they could really target them. I mentioned the tax act. Section 260 of the tax act has a system where it says, basically, that anyone who is involved in an artificial structure aimed at getting a tax benefit to which they should not be entitled should have that benefit put aside and in fact would be subject to penalties. In other words, they are targeting people who have complex company or other financial structures that have, as a result, a benefit going to the person who set them up to which they would otherwise not be entitled. In other words, it is aimed specifically at the problem.

I am not going to argue whether section 260 necessarily works properly in all cases. In fact, at one stage the High Court appeared to be of the view that section 260 was dead; it has now taken the contrary view and said that it is alive. But the fact is that section 260 provides the sort of approach that concentrates on people who are rorting the system, instead of belting everyone, including the honest people, the great bulk of honest people who are not rorting the Austudy system but who get belted anyway. And for what reasons do they get belted? They get belted because they are in a partnership, or because they have a proprietary company, or because they are self-employed. That is why they get belted under this system—not because they have been targeted as having some complex company or other financial structure. If, in fact, there are rorting arrangements going on, how about the government coming back to us with a system aimed at that?

We have received no evidence whatsoever and nothing by way of explanatory memorandum from this government to demonstrate that there has been rorting of an enormous volume by a self-employed person, or a partner in a partnership, or someone owning a proprietary company. Firstly, we have not seen the evidence. Secondly, we have not seen why rorters could not be targeted by the sort of specific targeting legislation that the Tax Act provides.

I would suggest that a similar prohibition—a prohibition on taking advantage of arrangements which have as a purpose the minimising of income for benefit purposes—is the direction in which we should be looking. Also, we should be looking at imposing penalties, as the tax act does, for breaching this arrangement, for entering into crooked deals because that would provide a serious deterrent.

Under the present system we do not have a deterrent, except in the sense that we are putting off people who are probably entitled to a benefit from applying in the first place. By having the sort of deterrent of targeting, as section 260 does, you would be providing a deterrent to cheats; whereas, under the present system, the government is providing a massive deterrent to honest Australians simply by making it so much harder for them to jump through the hoop.

The fact is that these regulations fail hopelessly on almost every score, except that—and this might sound ridiculous—they will work. They will work because of their unfair impact on honest, decent Australians whose families are entitled to the support of Austudy. They will work because of their added need for bureaucracy to ensure they work—in other words, a greater inefficiency in the delivery of a benefit. And they will work in a way that is to the detriment of Australia. What we have to find is a system that will work to the benefit of Australians, particularly those battlers who are at the bottom end of the income scale and yet who are caught up in this rough-house approach of the government.

I am concerned that there is another agenda, indeed, involved in this. If it is the view that there are too many people attending schools in the private school system who are receiving Austudy, and that attending a private school is evidence of the richness of a family, I would say that is just disgraceful nonsense that clearly has an agenda which I find totally unacceptable. There are many families in Australia who sacrifice themselves enormously because they want to send their child or children to the non-state school system. Whether that judgment is right or wrong is beside the point. The fact is, they do it.

As Senator Harradine would know, many of them do it because they have other social imperatives. Many people feel the need to send their children to the Catholic systemic system, for example, which one could hardly ever accuse of being a rich system. In fact, I think most studies I have seen recently indicate that, in terms of class sizes and resources, the Catholic systemic system is under-resourced, as against most state systems. If that is one of the criteria being used to justify this kind of broad hit at people who are self-employed, then it is an appalling one. Unless there is clear evidence to indicate why this kind of approach should be followed by the government, and none has been presented, then in my view this should be totally reviewed. There is no need for massive urgency.

I notice the regulations are supposed to come into force on 1 October; but they come into force on 1 October in relation to a year that begins, I think, on 1 January 1996. I understand that there would be a need to get forms printed and so on some time in advance. But I say to the government that there is no way I would find it acceptable that this kind of regulation, which goes so far beyond the statement of the minister, should be allowed to rush through—although it has certainly met the requirements of the parliament in terms of how long it should be before the parliament—without these very serious matters that have been raised here being adequately responded to.

I stress: it is no good for the minister or the bureaucracy to say, `Just because you're categorised as a designated parent doesn't mean you have to follow all these things.' I hate to tell you that unfortunately, under these regulations, it does. No matter how small your investment in a proprietary company is, no matter whether the trust you are in is a superannuation fund and therefore you have no control over it—it does not really indicate massive expenditure or any kind of, as I say, complex company or other financial structure—there is no discretion in the regulations. You have to do it. If you fail to do it, you suffer the consequences of apparently not being entitled to Austudy.

Wrongly trying to solve the serious problem by hammering, in this unfair way, those Australians who are low income earners but happen to be self-employed is totally unacceptable. I do not know how much of the $29 million a year savings are going to be at the expense of these low income earners. The government has not provided us with any kind of indication of the extent to which the $29 million is to be saved from, say, people who have assets overseas who are rorting the system that way. We have no indications from the government about where the $29 million a year will come from. This gap between what the minister said in his explanation and what is actually in the regulations, as I said the other day, is an absolute disgrace. The absence of explanation is an absolute disgrace.

I do regret that it has taken a fair while—in fact, I think it was the last day before this was moved, and I commend Senator Harradine for moving disallowance—but I would hope that out of this we can get some regulatory arrangements which do block off the people who are ripping off Austudy, because they have to be stopped. It is unfair and a disgrace that people are ripping off their neighbours, if you like, by getting Austudy to which they are not entitled. But because the objective is good does not mean that every action you take to achieve that objective is good. That is one of the lessons that maybe some elements of the bureaucracy here should understand.

These regulations are an unfair attack on small business, the people at the lower end of the income scale in many instances, without honing in effectively and in a concentrated way on those people who are ripping off the system. I believe that the government should look again at this system. I assure them that the opposition would cooperate strongly in examining better ways of achieving what is an excellent objective—that is, protecting Austudy from rip-off. This is not the way to do it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not the first time that this chamber has considered the disallowance of Austudy regulations in various forms. We have had Austudy regulations which have been ill-prepared and ill-targeted and which have deserved rejection or at least postponement. The authors have had to reconsider the implications and the effects of such regulations. This is not the first time that I have stood here to describe the reality of proposed regulations to those who have proposed them.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tierney mentioned earlier the report presented in June 1995 by the Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee which inquired into Austudy. I was a member of that committee which travelled extensively, received numerous submissions and conducted inquiries around Australia into Austudy. That committee made 24 recommendations. I remind the Senate that recommendation 12 states:

SPEECH.PARA: That training in AUSTUDY for CES officers be substantially upgraded. Student Assistance Centres must be funded to provide, to all CES offices, outreach training services, including training in the use of the STEPS computer system, using the Reference Based Training packages developed for Student Assistance schemes. Such training should also be accessible by DSS officers on request.
Furthermore, recommendation 11 states:

That: (a) all CES offices display signs that oral advice regarding AUSTUDY must be confirmed in writing; and (b) the SAC "Recording of Advice" forms used by all CES staff when dealing with AUSTUDY clients.

The reason for these recommendations is that we found during our inquiry numerous examples of complaints—they were representative of the criticisms that were made throughout Australia and which I assume have been received by most senators—that advice given about Austudy and how an applicant might fare after having made an application was subsequently found to be inaccurate. The applicant, of course, was the person who most often suffered by having incorrectly filled out an application form. It is not difficult to fill the form out incorrectly. Anybody who has looked at the form and attempted to fill it out would find it easy to agree with me.

PARA.TAB: A number of people get themselves into hot water by having incorrectly filled out such a form or by taking the advice of one of the officers and filling it out in a certain way only to find that their circumstances are not as they were when first assessed. They then find themselves in a situation in which they owe the government money because they either have received overpayment or have not advised anyone of the change in their circumstances within a certain period. There are many thousands of people who have found themselves in these situations. A representative number of those people complained to our inquiry that they thought this was just as much a result of the inaccurate advice they had been given as it was to their own connivance or contrivance to avoid the requirements.

This is where the problem is and this is where such regulations as those we have before us now for disallowance lead us to. The more complicated we make it, the more need there is for recommendation 12 of the committee's report to be taken seriously—that is, that greater training needs to be conducted.

During this short debate I have heard with interest many senators suggesting that the increased complications by these regulations would be almost impossible to administer because the effect of this set of regulations would not be to resolve the problem of the abuse and rorting of Austudy. The result would be to abuse the families who are already contributing a proper amount of tax and who are trying to comply with the system as it is. That is what the effect would be. The danger, as mentioned by Senator Harradine, would be that the government will apply this concept to other pension and welfare recipients. We have no denial of that from the government. We have no indication that that is not what the intention is. If we had a government that was heading down that track, I wonder what the country is heading towards.

As far as I am concerned, a lot of the problem in this area revolves around the unanswered question of what is an independent student. The failure of the government to adequately answer this question has led us to a situation which is quite ludicrous. Instead of actually answering that question and providing us with a commonsense measurement which can be endorsed by the community of what an independent student is, we have the families brought in in various measures of deeming what a family is, what a family contributes, what a family earns, how much they should contribute and where they ought to live. These sorts of immeasurable aspects have been brought into this debate and have complicated the regulations to such an extent that it is almost indecipherable to a normal person.

It is this failure to recognise the reality of how families conduct themselves and how they relate in the real world which has led us to a bureaucratic maze. It is a maze that does not fit ordinary or normal families. In previous debates we were talking about independence and how old people had to be or how long they should have stayed away from home or how many months they were supposed to have been working before they could truly be defined as independent. I recall bringing to this chamber the great revelation that my mother, for example, bought my underpants until I was 35. I think quite a number of males in Australian society rely on their mothers to continue supporting them in certain ways. My grandmother bought my pyjamas until I was 40. It is only recently that she has discontinued that practice. I am pleased to say that she is still alive, but she does not consider it relevant to do that for me any more.

Families do conduct themselves and do exchange gifts in a private way which is no business of this government at that level. At the level of exchange of substantial gifts which are contrivances to avoid government processes and government schemes, yes. But what worries me is that there is little indication of this set of regulations that it would not impose itself into those sorts of private arrangements which are perfectly normal. Earlier Senator Harradine was talking about section 12N. I immediately thought of a fairly normal thing that happens in my state of Tasmania. Grandfather arrives with his ute for the weekend and the family goes off and collects some firewood. Perhaps it is worth $87.50 for the weekend's effort. Somehow or other this government will impose itself into this relationship and see whether receipts have been issued, whether the weekend's effort has been properly documented and what the deemed income to the particular recipient might be in terms of the total family income. For goodness sake, get out of that area; you do not belong there. I am talking about bureaucrats, governments and regulations.

It is normal family intercourse and that is what it ought to remain. It is certainly not the business of government. These gifts and arrangements are simply manifestations of natural, normal family life. Unless it is very careful, this government could stand accused of denying families the opportunity to behave as families. If this government seriously believes that families will comply with this nonsense by issuing receipts and keeping records of such interchanges as I have suggested, then reality has escaped this government completely.

Reality has escaped this government previously in this area of Austudy and its regulations, when there was an attempt to redefine those students who had married under a certain age as not really being independent, even though they had set up their own family, even though they had moved away from physical or geographical dependence upon their parents. But no; this government attempted to deem that under a certain age, as far as Austudy was concerned, they were not really independent. What a cheek! I am glad to say that this chamber recognised it as such and was able, after a long struggle, thankfully, to defeat this bureaucratic proposition.

I warn the government that to continue this denial of reality and spending too much time in a bureaucratic haze of unreality will be revealed to the population. Unless it discontinues such propositions, people will wake up and realise how stupid these propositions are. I think Senator Harradine should be congratulated on making this move to alert the nation to the stupidity, inconsistency and danger of the proposition. If we adjourn this discussion and send the government away to come up with something that is a little more realistic, we will be serving the country well. I support such a move.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will agree to defer consideration of the matter until the first day of sitting after this week; in other words, in a fortnight's time. All who have spoken support the government's intention to ensure that Austudy benefits are tightly targeted to those most in need. It is therefore worth taking some time in the next two weeks to further discuss the details of how this is best achieved.

PARA.TAB: However, I must stress on behalf of the government that it is essential that these regulations are determined on our first sitting day in October. Austudy application forms for the 1996 academic year are due to be sent to hundreds of thousands of students in mid-October. That timetable is essential if students are to receive their first Austudy payment on 3 January. The opposition, particularly, needs to be aware of the risk of putting students in a very difficult position if they hold up decisions about Austudy income support arrangements to help genuinely needy students with their 1996 studies.

Therefore, on behalf of the government, I will seek an adjournment of this matter, noting the need of all interested senators to make themselves available over the next two weeks in order to attempt to negotiate an outcome on these regulations. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.
Ordered that the resumption of the debate be made an order of the day for the first day of sitting in October.
Consideration resumed from 26 September.
The ACTING CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)—Order! The committee is considering the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill 1995 and the amendment moved by Senator Vanstone.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a number of comments pursuant to the debate that took place yesterday. Senator Boswell raised a number of issues, some of which concerned me personally. I wish to put on the record that, contrary to the statements made by Senator Boswell, I did run a small business for some 15 years. I commenced that business, and in its latter years it employed up to 200 tradesmen. It is on the basis of the experience I gained from that—for example, we had to meet the payroll and operate in the building trade, which is one of the roughest industries in Australia—that I say again that audits are a useful management tool for small business.

PARA.TAB: I also wish to point out to Senator Boswell that there is one very large community in the small business area that depends on adequate information about the companies it deals with—these are the creditors, the people who want to get paid. Before creditors offer services and supply goods, they want to be sure that the companies they deal with have the capacity to pay them when the goods and services are provided.

I think it is utterly misleading to say that this is an anti small business measure, when small business is big enough under two of the three criteria to be classed as a large business and therefore conduct audits and supply financial statements. On the contrary—this is a measure that assists small businesses to conduct their business in a proper, safe and secure manner. I believe that we need to monitor—and this has been put into the legislation—how these provisions will actually work in practice before we jump to the conclusion that we are imposing an unbearable load on small business. As I said, I believe that this will be largely of benefit to small business.

What the committee also did—and what Senator Boswell does not seem to be able to appreciate—was to strengthen the powers of the ASC to provide exemptions on a number of criteria, which include the criteria where a business finds it is an unreasonable burden in all the circumstances. But there are many other criteria.

I note that these amendments were debated twice by committees. We had a public review with witnesses appearing before those committees. We had the coalition, as the coalition, approve—vote for—the recommendations. Senator Boswell should take his concerns to his Liberal colleagues who, with their business experience, have made the judgment that, on balance, what is in the bill is useful and sensible.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —During the heat of the debate yesterday I did make some disparaging remarks about Senator Spindler, and I do apologise. If he tells me he did run a business, then I certainly accept his word on that. But, nevertheless, that does not alter my commitment to opposition to this bill.

PARA.TAB: I know where Senator Spindler is coming from. I think he is putting the cart well and truly before the horse. Senator Spindler was saying that the creditors of companies need some protection. Senator Spindler, you are trying to take the risk out of business. Business is risk. It is a matter of judgment and it is a matter of taking decisions, and the people who make the right decisions win.

My problem with your proposition is that you are going to load business down with a $25,000 to $30,000 audit fee to protect the creditors. Let me tell you of my experience. In my 20 years of business, I lost something like $350 in bad debts, because my decision was that I dealt with the people that were there yesterday, were there today and I knew would be there tomorrow. There was no loss of revenue, but you cannot make business so foolproof that you take all the risk out of it. If you did that, you would make business so tied up with red tape that it could not survive.

I do appeal to you again, because I do understand where you are coming from. I said yesterday that, out of every 100 businesses that start, in eight years time 92 or 93 will have gone out of business—some will be bought out, some will be taken over, some will go broke and some will actually grow. They go through a process. Some grow and develop, and employ people. Eventually, they will have 50 employees and have a turnover of $10 million, which is not an excessive amount of turnover, not a lot of turnover. Then, if we were to pass this legislation, we would come along and impose a $30,000 fee on that business to monitor or audit what is theirs. It is not a public business. There is not anyone else's money in it. It is their business.

You say an audit fee will help. How does it help any differently from getting a tax accountant to go and do your tax? He prepares a profit and loss statement. He prepares a balance sheet. He does cost flows. How will this extra additional cost of $30,000 to $40,000 assist small business when every year he goes to his accountant—

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise two aspects of the dealings of Australia Post which are of concern to me and I would hope are shared by other Australian citizens. Yesterday, I visited the general post office in the centre of Canberra. On other occasions I have visited this establishment and I have thought it was a busy and important part of Australia Post's activities.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday was a fine sunny day but one on which there was a cold snowy blast coming from the Brindabellas along the footpaths of Canberra. I was surprised to see a desk outside Australia Post, the GPO, in Canberra. On the desk were half a dozen telephone books and two people were attempting to find telephone numbers in those books. I thought this was a strange place for such a basic function of the post office to be located.

Inside the post office I noticed that considerable floor space was devoted to the display of items for sale. Those items for sale included boxes of computer disks, computer paper, Australian Tax Office employment declaration forms, passport application forms, Citibank credit card application forms, matchbox cars and replicas, and preschool reading books. The Canberra Times was for sale in its own special box and there were bundles of fax paper. These things were in addition to those things you would expect to see in an Australia Post establishment, things such as greeting cards, gift wrapping, pens, pencils, sticky tape and writing pads—the sorts of things that have become common place in a post office and probably appreciated by the customers.

There were 16 people—I counted them—at the check-out, which was a sort of supermarket check-out. There is no actual counter any more. They all had in their hands postal articles—things such as parcels and long rolls with posters inside them. They were seeking to put stamps on them and put them into the system. None of the people lined up had boxes of computer disks to buy and none of them were anxiously awaiting service to have their Citibank credit card application form considered.

There were five staff. They were very busy and there was one person roving about helping people. While I was there, the rover answered two inquiries from people. Both of them wanted to know where they could buy a stamp. They were in the post office and they wanted to know how to buy a stamp! They were directed to the multi-stamp packages that were hanging up along a wall with the other items for sale. The smallest package you could buy contained five 45c stamps. One of the people wanted to buy one stamp. Guess where he was directed to? Outside to the franking machine to get one of the frama labels. I think it is pretty poor that we have come to this situation. I will leave those comments there.

The other matter I want to raise with regard to Australia Post is the fact that philatelists are being poorly served, again, by the way things have been organised in this new corporate, profit seeking, efficient, and economically rationalist Australia Post. The small, outlying territories of Australia—Christmas Island and the Cocos Islands, at least—for some time have been deriving a proportion of their income from servicing philatelists throughout the world. Part of the fascination that philatelists have with collecting is getting a first day cover stamped from, for example, the Cocos Islands or Christmas Island. As members of parliament, we are often told about new issues of stamps from places like that.

It disappoints me, as a philatelist, to learn that the bureaus on that island will no longer be servicing the demands of philatelists because they have been rationally relocated to Melbourne; it is much more efficient to do it that way. When, as a collector, you get a first day cover and a stamp with a cancellation on it from Christmas Island, that is not really where it comes from anymore; it comes from Melbourne. True philatelists, who see some value in collecting things that originate from various remote parts of the world, are no longer impressed by these items of trade. The number of people who want to collect those things is therefore declining.

That needs to be recognised in terms of employment prospects on Christmas Island, the Cocos Islands, and other places like them, and in terms of the genuineness with which Australia Post seeks to meet the needs of collectors who—as was mentioned in a report presented to parliament some years ago—have contributed a considerable amount to the history, development and profitability of Australia Post. Those are the two matters I wish to raise and I hope other people are interested in them as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this matter of public interest debate this afternoon I want to address matters of grave concern to my constituents back in Western Australia—public inquiries and royal commissions. We seem to be in the season of public inquiries, judicial inquiries and royal commissions with the number of demands for inquiries that abound daily through our media. As I have mentioned in this place before, there is demand for an inquiry into what is colloquially known as Wanneroo Inc. The demands have increased since I last addressed this matter in this chamber a month or so ago, to the extent that the local federal member of parliament, Mr Paul Filing, Independent, has come out publicly and said that there should be an inquiry into the matter.

PARA.TAB: One of the persons who would be questioned very closely in such an inquiry, if it were held, is a local state member of parliament, Mr Wayde Smith, about whom certain allegations have been floating. He in turn has said that the time has probably come for a public inquiry. There have been a number of other notable individuals in Wanneroo who have also come out and said yes, there must be an inquiry. I think there is pressure to bring one about very shortly. Interestingly enough, another local state member of parliament, Mrs Cheryl Edwardes, is not one of the people who is on the record as calling for the inquiry. But the tempo is building up.

There was also mention in our media about an inquiry into our police force. I have not had time to read all of the article but I noticed in the West Australian more comment about the need for an inquiry into the Western Australian police force. Honourable senators, particularly those from New South Wales, would know what is coming out of the Wood royal commission in that state. I am certainly hopeful that that will not be replicated in my state of Western Australia.

There have also been demands for an inquiry into the operations of the office of the Deputy Public Prosecutor, a person who seems to get himself into the media quite frequently. Apparently the judiciary has said not too kind things about that particular office.

Then we have the ongoing charade known as the Easton royal commission, which is costing our unfortunate Western Australian taxpayers something in the region of $4.5 million. Today is the last day, or so we are told, on which the commission will take public evidence. Unfortunately, it probably will not be the last we hear of that particular inquiry.

We have been advised that next week the commission will be hearing closing submissions from the lawyers who have taken part in that inquiry. I assume, and I would hope, that the lawyers for both the prosecution and the defence will be given the opportunity to put their closing statements at that time. I say `prosecution' and `defence' because it seems that has been the way this particular royal commission has been conducted, with a defence and a prosecution, which is somewhat different from what royal commissions or judicial inquiries should be about.

I think that Commissioner Marks probably could end this charade now. He could hand down his report now without waiting for those closing comments. I do not think he needs to wait until the closing date that has been suggested, the extended reporting date of 17 November, to bring down a report. I am firmly of the view, and I have said it before, that the royal commissioner could bring down his report now; or he could have given his report at the time when he was appointed to the royal commission, when he first accepted to act as the commissioner on the terms of reference from the Liberal Party Premier of Western Australia, Mr Richard Court.

The editorial in last weekend's Weekend Australian of 23-24 September 1995 said that the commission had reached a point where no useful political, legal or moral purpose is being served by it and called for the WA government to take steps to terminate it. I do not think that that is going to happen. I do not think that the Premier, Mr Court, is going to see sense, but I would hope that Mr Marks could and, in doing so, salvage some of his own credibility by winding up this discredited Easton royal commission. I say `discredited', and I say that advisedly. It has been discredited not only by politicians on this side of the parliament or this side of the political fence, but also by what has come from the commissioner's own mouth. Commissioner Marks has acknowledged that the commission has lost its way. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have put myself in a position which is irrecoverable in some sense because this inquiry has become almost impossible to control in an objective sense.

Mr Marks still has an opportunity to grab control of it. He can wind up this discredited farce; and, as a representative of the people of Western Australia, I call on him to release his findings and his report and his verdict. He has the quarter of a million bucks. He can put that in the bank and then start making attempts to live with himself from here on in.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this matters of public interest debate to talk about the need for governments and the community as a whole to acknowledge the significant contribution that older Australians have made, and continue to make, to their community, and the need to make a commitment to the needs of seniors in our community. This is particularly pertinent because next Sunday, 1 October, is the United Nations International Day of Older Persons—a day on which the world's attention will focus on the important contribution older people make to the societies in which they live.

PARA.TAB: Older people make up a significant and rapidly increasing segment of our community. In June 1994, there were 2,109,109 Australians aged 65 years and over. That represents 11.82 per cent of the population. Over the next 35 years, the number of people in that age group will increase to 2.52 million or over 20 per cent of the population—that is, one in every five Australians will be over 65 years of age. I might hasten to add here that I have a vested interest because I will be—hopefully, if I am still alive then—one of those people in that age group, but that is not the only thing that motivates me.

With increased life expectancy, old age is becoming a long period of life. Ninety per cent of 40-year-olds can expect to reach 65 years of age, when men can expect to live for another 15 years and women another 19 years. So, compared with the beginning of this century, retirement can span several decades.

Older people are generally active, interested and talented; only eight per cent of older people are seriously impaired. To belie the myths that are out there about older people, a very small proportion—about four per cent to six per cent—of them live in residential institutions for older people. As Senator Crowley said here yesterday, most older people are living out in the community and caring for themselves, and some with some assistance. It is a myth to think that the majority of older people are in residential care. It is a very small proportion of them.

With advances in medicine and treatment, and increased knowledge of preventative medicine, older people can live a longer, enthusiastic, and healthy life and continue to make a contribution to society for a very long time. Older people contribute to our community in significant ways. Some participate in the paid work force. Unfortunately, if you are an Australian public servant, you cannot do that beyond the age of 65 years because this government has been reluctant to keep the promise it made in 1990 to extend the retirement age for people in the Public Service. The government has also refused to deal with my private member's bill and Mr Connolly's private member's bill relating to this issue. For those who are fortunate enough to work in private enterprise or are self-employed, they are able to stay on and participate in the paid work force.

Other older people are doing unpaid work as carers; many of them as carers of other older people, or carers of young people with disabilities, or carers of their own children with disabilities. Many older people are also carers of grandchildren and work as voluntary workers in their community. We see examples over and over again of older people playing roles in hospitals, community organisations, Meals on Wheels and many other activities.

We need to recognise that there are a number of issues which are of great concern for seniors today. I have emphasised before, and I repeat again, the importance of understanding that older Australians are not a homogeneous group with static needs, but a diverse and dynamic group. Any discussion of older people must recognise that they come from a wide variety of cultural, educational and professional backgrounds, with very different financial circumstances, physical capabilities, lifestyles, opinions and expectations. They range from the very active and involved to the very frail aged, from those capable of looking after themselves in their old age to those who need, because of ill health or dementia, assistance.

Reflecting this diversity, there are a number of issues that concern older people. These include: age discrimination in the work force; compulsory retirement on the basis of age; retirement incomes and superannuation; social security issues; health issues including health funding, health insurance, access to health and waiting lists in hospitals; and community care that enables real choice for older people when they need assistance to remain in their own homes. Those who care for older people also have concerns. Many of them are old themselves, in particular, older women. There are issues associated with residential accommodation and its funding, and issues of mental health such as the increasing number of people with dementia and Alzheimer's disease.

At a general level, the policy challenge for governments is to provide the elderly with opportunities to contribute according to their interests, abilities and needs, whether that is by involving them in decision making, encouraging income earning or voluntary activities, or providing recreational, educational and social activities. At the same time, governments must ensure that income security and appropriate and affordable support and care is available to those elderly who require them.

With regard to retirement incomes, we have seen this government deal those who have attempted to provide for themselves, either by supplementing their pension or those who are providing for themselves by fully supporting themselves, quite an incredible blow with respect to the treatment of unrealised capital gains on shares as income for the purpose of assessing a pension. We saw how, with pressure from the Senate—from the opposition and with the assistance of the Democrats—the government was forced to do a review that looked at trying to address the inequities and the difficulties that pensioners were facing, especially when the share market was increasing, with a totally unpredictable income.

That pressure resulted in a company called Ageing Agendas undertaking a review of pensions income and assets tests. It highlighted concerns that the current retirement income policy arrangements were far too complex, that they did not cater for different situations of people and did not provide enough incentives for retirees to make the best use of their resources.

Increasingly, older people have arranged their financial affairs to qualify for the pension and no-one can blame them for that. The financial incentives of getting a pension, the stability and the predicability and security encourage people to reduce their incomes to qualify for at least some pension and to hold assets which are exempted from the assets test.

For those people who did not earn very much during their working lives there is little doubt that the age pension discourages savings. Why save if the government will provide a similar amount in retirement if a person has not saved? We have also seen people on fixed retirement incomes with fixed superannuation annuities who are suffering under quite difficult situations on the same income as a pensioner and are not able to get some of the same benefits.

Many people who are better off choose to retire early on their own savings but there is no encouragement to maintain those savings. Many of them dissipate their savings and claim the pension once the age of pension eligibility has been reached. There needs to be a total review of the issues surrounding pensions and provision of retirement incomes for older people. Ageing Agendas did this in part but it was basically only looking at the assets and incomes test.

We must remember that although some self-funded retirees—those who fully or partially support themselves in retirement—have been more fortunate than others, many of them have been frugal and have saved. They feel that they have been penalised for this in some ways. Many of them are concerned that a pensioner gets a pensioner concession card and they do not, that the pensioner does not pay tax until their income exceeds $10,720 a year, whereas the self-funded retiree pays tax on each dollar over $5,400 and by the time they get to $10,720 they will have paid about $1,000 in tax.

I remind senators that in the 1993 election the government promised pensioners that they would be taken out of the tax system. It was only five days after the election that Dr Blewett, the then Minister for Social Security, had the gall to say that they had made a mistake. Every piece of publicity that every Labor Party candidate put out right up to the election stated that pensioners would be taken out of the tax system, but that was one of the first promises that was broken only five days after the election.

Another promise that was broken to older people was the promise about the l-a-w tax cuts. There they were in law. In another typical pea and thimble trick, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) delayed the tranche of those tax cuts and then the second disappeared into the never-never for a lot of people. Some of them will get it back in superannuation in the never-never, but what happened to tax cuts for self-funded retirees? They do not get superannuation. So before the last election pensioners were told they were going to be taken out of the tax system and self-funded retirees were told they were going to get tax cuts. Both groups have been let down by the Labor Party.

The Labor government's treatment of self-funded retirees is nothing short of an absolute disgrace. These people have contributed billions of dollars to taxation over their working lives. They continue to pay tax and they have been treated this way by the government, in particular, about the tax cuts that they were anticipating.

The government has done much to undermine the certainty and lifestyle of many seniors. In the area of superannuation, we have seen continual changing of the goalposts with complicated and constantly changing sets of rules and, with the compulsory superannuation guarantee charge, there is increasing uncertainty that there will be adequate superannuation for the majority of Australians. It is no wonder that people in this situation contemplate ways to dispose of their assets and then enter tax free retirement as a charge on taxpayers.

The other area where the government has failed to address the issue pertaining to older people is the area of retirement incomes for women. Women live longer than men. They have a much longer period in which to support themselves following retirement or the death of a spouse. For women, the situation in regard to superannuation is grim. It is generally acknowledged that, because of the broken work patterns of women, lower incomes and the effect of taxes and charges on superannuation accounts, many women will be severely disadvantaged in their senior years. The government has not addressed the issue of women and their particular needs with regard to superannuation retirement incomes.
