It is a sad reflection on the government that it has not done anything to address that issue over 13 years of Labor in power.

In the area of the incomes and assets test, the government has failed to undertake a comprehensive review and the entire system needs to be overhauled. It has also failed to address the urgent need for adequate funding arrangements for nursing homes and hostels. Its own committee, chaired by Professor Gregory, has indicated that $500 million is required to bring nursing homes and hostels up to current standards. What did the government give in the last budget? It gave $36 million over three years. That is not even going to touch the sides. Over the last 13 years, this government has let that capital run down.

The other area where the government has failed and failed dismally is the area of provision of care for people with dementia. It set up dementia specific facilities and then decided that it was not going to fund them. We have seen one close down and others have said that it is impossible for them to continue with the current funding. They have to cross-subsidise. They say that, if there were some funding between nursing homes and hostels, they could manage. When those hostels close down, the people will inevitably go into a nursing home. They will cost the taxpayer more and they will not have the quality of life that they have now. Why the government has refused to address that issue is beyond my comprehension. As we approach 1 October, which is United Nations International Day of Older Persons—a day to celebrate and to recognise older people—this government needs to look squarely at its failure to meet the needs of older Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate on matters of public interest, I rise to speak about the appalling road system in northern New South Wales. This Labor government should take warning that key marginal seats will fall because of its failed roads policy in northern New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: Minister Brereton is the architect of yet another disaster. In New South Wales, he funded the tunnel, the Darling Harbour scheme and the monorail. He has now turned his talents to the federal scene and we have had some evidence of this with the industrial relations policy, the airport runways and the neglected road system, particularly the Pacific Highway between the cities of Sydney and Brisbane. Sydney is the largest city in Australia. By 2040 Brisbane will be the second largest. Yet, between these two major cities, we have nothing more than a goat track. There has been an appalling lack of progress on this road over the last 13 years.

The real state of this road came home to me during the two trips that I undertook on it this year. One trip was in relation to the black spot road funding program and the other trip was with Senator Campbell and his youth bus.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, with the black T-shirts.

—Yes. When we undertook the trip by bus, it had been 14 years since I had travelled on the road by bus. I was amazed by how dangerous it seemed as we approached bridges—Senator Campbell will remember this—and where trucks at the other end of the bridge stopped because they realise that, if you put a bus and a truck side by side on these 1920s bridges, you are in danger of a major accident.

PARA.TAB: How much improved roadway is there between the cities of Newcastle and Brisbane? This is the worst stretch of the Pacific Highway. In this vast area, which takes 14 hours to drive, there is a grand total of 64 kilometres of divided road. There is a massive backlog in spending on roads in northern New South Wales. Our candidates in the area—Bob Baldwin in Paterson, Anne Hunter in Page and Keith Johnson in Richmond—are well aware of this and they have targeted the main black spots in their own electorates. Our candidates are driving home to the electors of Richmond, Page and Paterson how poorly treated they are in terms of road funding.

How long will it take to fix the problem? The federal Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics found that $4 billion is needed to fix the Pacific Highway problem. The road could stay in this condition for another 40 years at the present rate of improvement. It remains the worst interstate road link in Australia. If the highway is left in its present condition, injury and death will escalate.

It is estimated that, over the coming 10 years, there will be 10,000 injuries and some 2 1/2 thousand deaths on this road. Surely that is a reason for putting some priority on it. We all remember the horror of one major accident, the Kempsey bus crash in 1989. Reg and Dorothy Kelly of Clybucca Flat, in recalling this event, told their story to the Sun-Herald on 23 July 1995. They called for an urgent upgrade of the Pacific Highway before the tragedy and deaths that they witnessed can be repeated. They recalled in the article the horror of the morning of the crash. Standing on their verandah they could see the accident scene from a distance. As they drew closer, the full extent of the carnage became clear; bloody survivors were clambering from the wreckage of the two coaches.

Thirty-five people died and 41 were injured in this crash. Mrs Kelly has called on the federal government to take urgent action to build a divided highway as she believes that this is the only means of preventing more deaths. After this major accident the government did put a little bit more money towards the road, such was the public outrage. The government introduced a black spot program and put up $1 billion in funding. What has happened since? If you move on to two years after that time in 1988, the money was dwindling away, and, after four years, the program totally disappeared from the federal government's budget. Nothing is being spent on black spots. The road needs $4 billion in expenditure and yet nothing is being spent on black spots. This is an absolute disgrace. There are 80 major black spot problem areas that remain untouched and some of the work is not scheduled until the end of the century. This issue went from public consciousness when the Keating government started to cut spending, but the issue has not gone away and the public knows that another smash is quite possible.

Since 1985, the highway has claimed more lives than any other major Australian road. This year there have been 16 fatal accidents and 20 lives lost between Hexham and the Queensland border, the worst stretch of road. This is the human cost of the Keating government's failed road policy of under-expenditure on regional roads in this country. Poor and deteriorating rural and regional road infrastructure is the rule, not the exception. The roads of the north coast of New South Wales and the Pacific Highway in particular make a notorious case study of ALP neglect.

Here is a catalogue of how Labor exercises duty of care to road users over the last 13 years. The Australian Automobile Association, in its 1995-96 budget submission, made some telling points. The association said that Labor must use this budget to reverse the deterioration of Australian road infrastructure. The last 15 years has witnessed an escalation of the tax take by governments from fuel excise and imposts on motorists, while road infrastructure investment has languished. The impact in regional centres such as Maitland, Grafton and Lismore are many—injury and death, extra time travelled, extra fuel costs on travel, inefficient use of energy and fuel resources, impacts that are adverse to the environment, regional growth being stunted, inflated regional costs for business and reduced export opportunity.

The federal fuel tax on every litre of petrol puts 33c back in federal coffers but, of that 33c, only 7c is spent on roads. The return of just another 7c a litre would see measurable improvements in our roads. It would reduce road trauma and death, increase employment opportunities and lift regional growth. We are, according to a recent finding, an extremely wealthy nation. We should, on the basis of all being worth $1.1 million, have enormous resources to fix this problem. But, instead, what we have in our country are death traps.

The Bureau of Transport, Communications and Economics figures on road related revenue and expenditure show clearly why Australian roads are below best practice. In 1982-83, the Liberal government had road taxes and charges at $3.9 billion. Road expenditure in that year was $4.3 billion. We were spending more than we were raising. Under Keating, the road taxes and charges collected in the most recent financial year are $11 billion. The expenditure was $5 billion. That is a spending of under half the money that is collected for roads on roads. The rest of it goes back into general revenue.

The Business Council of Australia, in a 1994 paper entitled `Refocusing roads and reform', shows the folly of Labor's current tax and keep approach. The council claims that a more efficient management of expenditure on roads could produce a gain to GDP of $10 billion over the next 10 years. We are talking about an expenditure of $4 billion to fix the problem, yet if we spend that $4 billion we will gain $10 billion. Such is the short-sightedness of this government's policies that it is not even prepared to make a start on the expenditure.

The Business Council report went further and stated that Australia's primary road network is below world best practice, that less than 10 per cent of all Australian urban travel is on controlled access primary roads. In the US, the comparative figure is 40 per cent. This is a real problem as our stop and start major roads are inefficient compared to freeways. Freeways and proper divided roads, which is what we are advocating for the north coast, have 70 per cent fewer accidents, 30 per cent less fuel consumption, 50 to 100 per cent less fuel emissions and 50 per cent less cost in time for business.

In the light of all this, the ALP government's decision to renege on promises for black spot funding is appalling. The hypocrisy of this Keating government really knows no bounds on this issue. This government cancelled programs on the Pacific Highway after the tragic coach deaths. It is trying to force local government to pick up the tab for what is really national priority work. The Bureau of Transport, Communications and Economics has shown the benefit of black spot improvements. The reduction in accidents at these sites was more than 2 1/2 times greater than at untreated sites. The coalition government will reintroduce black spot funding as a priority.

Up on the north coast where this money has not been spent and these roads have not been improved, the ALP sitting members try to distance themselves from the Keating government but they cannot really hide their ALP affiliation. It is amazing that when the major improvement on this program which was to be done by the Liberal government—the Pacific tollway—was scrapped just after the Carr government was elected, there was not a peep out of Bob Horne in Paterson, out of Harry Woods in Page or out of Neville Newell in Richmond, and they are supposed to be representing their constituents.

In Bob Horne's seat of Paterson the F3 freeway finishes in a swamp. Senator Campbell actually drove past that, where the expressway goes from four lanes down to a two-lane country road carrying the main traffic out of Sydney. The state Liberal government actually started building the thing and Mr Brereton came up and re-announced its start, but it was well under way at that point. He came up and announced the Branxton to New England Highway link.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that what they mean by the `Laurie of lies'? Is that the Laurie they are talking about?
—That was their `Laurie of lies' when he was in Paterson.
—Order! Senator Tierney. In referring to a minister you are to refer to him by his full name. It is disorderly to refer to a minister lying. I ask you to withdraw that.

—I withdraw that. He was travelling around in his lorry of lies and at that time he made the promise of connecting the F3 up to Branxton. Not only had it been announced 18 months earlier but the timetable had been set out. Curiously, he did not have any timetable. He just said, `We're going to build it.' When, in 10, 20 or 30 years time? It was a meaningless gesture.

PARA.TAB: Up in Page, Harry Woods's main project is the Summerland Way on which he has done nothing. He has been the member for six years and they have not built any of the Summerland Way. It is a $33 million project which will take a huge amount of traffic and all the big heavy trucks off the Pacific Highway and up into the back of Brisbane over the McPherson Range. It is an urgent priority. On our black spots tour we went and had a look at that but, under this government, nothing.

We have the classic case up in Neville Newell's seat of Richmond where they have a bridge that has no approach roads. It is sitting up all finished, but with no approach roads. Meanwhile, traffic and buses pass each other in very dangerous situations. These are just some examples in these three seats of the neglect of this government of roads. It is scandalous. The Labour government should fund it properly. They have not done that for the last 13 years. The Liberal party has a priority for such roads and these will start when a Liberal government is returned.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this public interest debate I want to raise the issue of illegal entrants, the mandatory detention of asylum seekers and the current push by the government to deport them against their will. The matter was referred to in the adjournment debate last night. I feel it is important to bring to this chamber and to the general public the story of two Cambodian asylum seekers currently facing deportation at any moment.

PARA.TAB: The two young men, Sok Kheng Ngep and Sok Khom Ngep, arrived on the boat nicknamed `Collie' in 1990 aged 16 and 17 years. They were rescued by an Australian navy boat because the boat that they were travelling on was in such a difficult and dangerous situation that it was about to sink. Having been brought to Port Hedland they were kept in detention and have been there for the last five years. Because of legislation that was passed in this chamber in both May and December 1992, they were deprived of being able to appeal to the court on the grounds of illegal detention. Also, any chance of compensation was ruled out of order by legislation which has recently been reinstated, which was proposed in December 1992 and overruled by a court, to reduce any compensation for illegal detention to a dollar a day.

These young men not only have been imprisoned at a stage in their development which would be deleterious to anybody but also they have been in the category of those asylum seekers who have been most penalised by the interaction between this parliament and the courts of our land. If it is not bad enough that these two have been held in detention for almost five years, the government is now intending to deport them to Cambodia where they have no relatives and no prospect of a normal life. Since they left their country, their relatives have been able to gain asylum in America. While they have made inquiries about going there, they have been informed by the United States authorities that that process will take two or three years. If Australia deports them back to Cambodia, it certainly will not be deporting them to their home. It will be deporting them to a place from which they fled and to which they have no family connections or prospects of a normal life.

During the time that they have been in detention in Port Hedland, the department did offer them, through the minister, the prospect of returning to Cambodia for one year. They could then reapply to come back to Australia. This offer was taken up by many people who were in detention. It was a way of getting out of their invidious situation. I think 160 of the people who went back to Cambodia for one year they are now back in Australia having been legally accepted to stay.

Because these two young men were afraid of returning and because they had no place to return to and no connections which they could renew, they are now being penalised. They are going to be forcibly deported against their will. There are also some doubts about the way in which the department of immigration advised these brothers during various stages of their refugee claim process. The brothers were listed with others in their category who came in on the same boat to go before the court. In actual fact, they are two of the four Cambodians remaining in detention at Port Hedland. They are the only two who are under threat of deportation. The other two Cambodians remained on a court list and their case is still to be heard in the court.

However, these two brothers were advised that, if they withdrew their appeal to the court and resumed the usual process of going through the refugee review tribunal process and if they were then knocked back, they would have a better chance of gaining humanitarian visas or entries to Australia. On the basis of that advice, and I have good authority to support this, they withdrew their legal appeals and this has now left them vulnerable. We know that the humanitarian category to which they were extending their hopes has been removed. They rely only on the minister's discretion, and the compassion of the people who support them in this place, to allow them bridging visas so that a way can be found to allow them to stay in Australia at least until such time that they can make the appropriate approaches to rejoin their parents in the United States.

I acknowledge that it may well be that the minister for immigration feels no legal obligation to do this, but I certainly believe there is a moral one. The migration act has been amended time and again, as we know, to deny people such as the two brothers the most fundamental of human rights—for instance, freedom of movement and proper access to the legal system. There are Cambodian groups in Australia who are willing to support the two brothers if only they were given the chance.

I believe that the saga of boat people has been one of shame for Australia for the past six years. This incident provides an opportunity for the government to act with compassion. I only hope that the opportunity is not lost. It disturbs me enormously when the public debate on these matters fails to take into consideration the actual details of the lives of the people we are talking about.

It is quite true that the people of Australia are concerned about the increase in migration numbers. There are many people within the Green movement who are concerned that we are not giving sufficient attention to the appropriate level of population within our country so that we maintain the quality of life and the quality of the environment that we enjoy at the present.

It is also true that people are very concerned about the way in which multinational and overseas interests are gaining access to land and developments within our own country and the way in which capital and investment profits are disappearing overseas. This concern in the community is far more connected to the knowledge that the immigration numbers are increasing and that business migration is increasing than to asylum seekers. Comments are made in the press that seem to relate the problem to the absolutely unrelated matter of the relatively small numbers of illegal entrants to this country who have fled from their own countries, have nowhere to go and seek asylum on our shores.

The matter of illegal migrants is vastly different from the matter which has attracted the concern and antagonism of the people of Australia. People are concerned, but they are not well informed. They do not understand that the reality of the increase in migration is totally independent of boat people, asylum seekers and those who are being detained mandatorily at Port Hedland, sometimes at Darwin and at the Curtin base.

These illegal entrants are a very small proportion of those we could call illegal migrants: those who come into our country with authorisation and then overstay, disappear or otherwise flaunt the basis on which they entered the country. They are a far greater number. They are not detained in custody; they are allowed bridging visas on an almost automatic basis the minute they come here. In a way it is essential so, because if we detained them mandatorily in detention we would have a much larger detention system than any of our prison systems at the current moment.

It is very unfair that, when people who are in detention seek compassionate and humanitarian release into the community, the other argument about the extent of migration and business migration—which is being used in an opportunistic way by the government—is thrown up to attack them.

People in the Australian community are much more compassionate than the government gives them credit for. A very clear distinction should be made between the concerns about the population growth rate, immigration numbers and the people who seek asylum on our shores. We have to look at the reputation that Australia wants to have in the eyes of the world, and, at the moment, we are displaying a double standard. On the one hand, we are talking about human rights violations all around the world as though we are on the high moral ground. On the other hand, the way in which we have dealt with asylum seekers—particularly in the last four or five years—is a disgrace that will come back to haunt us when people see that we are being so punitive and so lacking in compassion.

I urge my colleagues to look at this matter to try to separate out the two different aspects of migration. There are many in the Greens who want us to have a look at the impact of migration overall, but there are also those who are well aware that the human rights needs of people who are fleeing their country and are afraid to return have to be respected. Because we have been detaining these people in custody we have incurred an enormous bill for which they are not to blame. If we choose as a government—which is what both major parties are responsible for doing—to detain and to virtually imprison these people, then we cannot complain that the cost of their detention lies at their feet; it lies at our feet.

Churches and community groups right around Australia have been adamant that they would be delighted to assist in the support of these people in the community, which would be far less costly. Those offers have been repeatedly refused by the government. Then we start hearing figures of how costly it is to keep them in detention and, also, that lawyers are being blamed for working on behalf of these people to give them the legitimate citizenship access to their legal rights that anyone in the world should have on a free basis. So we are now attacking the lawyers who provide what is, I believe, a very good and commendable service for also being part of the process by which they remain longer in the country and increase the bill that we have generated by our refusal to allow them entry on a bridging visa basis into our own community.

I urge my colleagues to look at the case of Sok Kheng Ngep and Sok Khom Ngep. They have been in detention for five years. They are still as afraid of returning to Cambodia as they were when they fled and I believe, by wanting to deport them, the government is wanting to remove from our shores the evidence of our own guilt and inhumanity towards them. I can only urge the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to rethink his stance on this issue and allow them bridging visas, allow them to avail themselves of the community support which they have been offered and make the arrangements that they are seeking to make a new life for themselves in freedom rather than in custody.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the great concerns that we in the National Party have is achieving a mechanism by which regional development can go ahead, especially in areas of North Queensland. I note and acknowledge the presence in the chamber of Senator Burns. I am sure he would agree with me that one of the grave problems we have is that there are areas of Queensland that have enormous resources but which do not get the development they deserve. One of the reasons for this is the simple fact that there is a tax regime in place at the moment which punishes companies for putting investment into regional Australia. The tax regime in question is the fringe benefits tax.

PARA.TAB: Let me explain to honourable senators why this is such a problem. Take, for example, north-west Queensland, an area which is an immensely rich mineral province. North-west Queensland is home to mines like Century, Mount Isa—it was home to Mary Kathleen—Ernest Henry, Duchess and so on. Yet if Mount Isa had been started in the 1990s instead of when it was started, there would be hardly anybody living in Mount Isa. Senator Campbell, who is in the chamber and comes from Western Australia, knows exactly what I mean. Companies are forced to pay fringe benefits tax on the deemed fringe benefit that they give in providing accommodation to workers and their families who move to work in those mines.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some fringe benefit!

—Some fringe benefit, indeed! Instead, what happens is, so as to not have to pay fringe benefits tax, the companies are forced to do what they would call fly-in fly-out operations. In some cases it is proposed that the workers for these mines in north-west Queensland will be based in Brisbane. Their families will live in Brisbane and it is cheaper for the company to fly those people on a chartered jet up to the mine and fly them back at the end of the week, than it is for the company to make an investment in providing accommodation for those people in the area. If this is the way the Labor Party believes that we are going to achieve development of regional Australia, I have one very simple message for them: I am sorry, you are wrong.

PARA.TAB: The simple fact is that this fringe benefits tax regime penalises regional Australia. It penalises communities that ought to be getting some sort of benefit from these mines. And, remember, the resources that are ripped up are ripped up from these areas. The people in the townships surrounding those resources get only one chance to get the maximum benefit from those resources. The only time that those resources are worth anything to those people is at the time that they are mined. So, what happens? The government puts in place a tax regime that means that those townships miss their once in a lifetime opportunity to get some benefit from the resources that lie underneath them. That is what this government is doing. It is wholly and utterly immoral.

This is a government that claims to represent the workers. Yet what sort of a lifestyle is it for the workers in these mines to be flown, sometimes over a thousand kilometres from their home, out to work in a mine for a week, not be able to see their family, and then flown back? It is not fair on the workers, it is not fair on their families and it is not fair on the community. A simple change to the fringe benefits tax regime in this country to exempt those remote areas would lead to an increase in investment and an increase in infrastructure spending by the private sector, not the government sector.

It might surprise people to know that many of the problems in rural and regional Australia could be ameliorated without a cent of taxpayers' dollars, if only the government was willing to see sense. The crazy thing is that, as the companies avoid the fringe benefits tax liability by flying the workers in and out, the cost of flying them in and flying them out is fully deductible as a tax expense by the company. So, instead of getting extra tax revenue for the government, we are adding to the costs of the mining industry in this country and we are reducing the tax that those companies will pay. They deduct the cost of flying the workers in and flying them out from the profits that they make. Here we have a ham-fisted, lamb-brained government that cannot understand the consequences of its own tax legislation, and people in regional Australia are paying the price.

I say here, and I have said it many times before, that the government has to recognise that it has a responsibility to more than just Sydney, Brisbane, Melbourne and Perth. The government has a responsibility to all of Australia and tax laws such as this should be scrapped to ensure some fairness and some equity for people who live in regional Australia. If the Labor government will not do it, I am sure that the people of regional Australia will get a much better go under the coalition government that will come in at the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most Australians know and are proud of the fact that Australia is one of the world's greatest sporting nations. We were reminded of that in the early hours of Monday morning, Australian time, by Mick Doohan who, for the second year in a row, won the 500cc motorcycle world championships. Indeed, he is the first Australian to do so back-to-back. We have had a proud record of achievement at every Olympic Games since the very first modern Olympic Games when a young Australian, who was a merchant banker in London at the time, went across to the Olympics and won a medal. At the Commonwealth Games, of course, we have an even better record in a whole range of sports. The most recent games in Victoria, Canada, were one of Australia's best Commonwealth Games ever.

PARA.TAB: I rise to speak in this matter of public interest debate because, for the second time in the last 30-odd years, the sport of shooting has, at this stage, been taken off the list of sports for the year 2002 games to be hosted by the City of Manchester. I wanted to raise this matter in the national parliament because it is something that I am appalled by, as are sporting shooters across Australia.

There is to be consideration given to this matter at a meeting of the Commonwealth Games Federation congress in Bermuda on 3 November 1995. I want to ensure that the Commonwealth Games Association of Australia delegates, and delegates from other Commonwealth nations around the world who attend that conference in Bermuda, are fully aware of the views on this matter which are strongly held by members and senators from all political sides in Australia.

The decision to exclude shooting is a bad one for all of the Commonwealth nations, and for the Commonwealth Games, but it is a particularly bad one for Australia. I have not gone back past 1966 to look at the history of our achievements in this sport, but our achievements since 1966 are impressive. Indeed, the only year since 1966 in which shooting was not included on the Commonwealth Games list of sports was 1970, in Edinburgh. It is good to see that the Scots made amends in 1986 and did include it on the list.

In l966, in Kingston, Jamaica, we won a silver medal and a bronze medal. In l974, in Christchurch, we won a gold, a silver and a bronze. In Edmonton, Canada, in 1978, we won two bronze medals. In Brisbane, in 1982, we won seven gold, three silver and four bronze. In Edinburgh we won four gold, seven silver and three bronze. In Auckland we won seven gold, five silver and three bronze. Last year was our most successful year: in Victoria, Canada we won 10 gold medals, five silver medals and four bronze medals.

I think it is very important that this be an issue that is brought to the public attention. It is a matter which will be of great interest amongst sporting shooters and competitive shooters across this nation. I know that all politicians would far prefer that shooting take place in a competitive, controlled environment, where the shooting is done at targets, rather than on the streets and at moving targets. The encouragement of sporting shooting is quite crucial, not only in terms of public safety but in its own right as an enormously important and successful sport.

I urge the organisers of the Manchester Games, who have excluded shooting from the list for those games in the year 2002, to think very seriously about the implications of this. Sporting shooting is a very important sport in many of the nations of the Commonwealth. It is not a sport that achieves an enormously high public profile, but the level of participation in sporting shooting and competitive shooting is very high across Australia and across a number of other Commonwealth countries.

It would be an absolute disaster—and, I would go so far as to say, a disgrace—if the organisers of the Commonwealth Games in Manchester were to leave it off the list. I urge them to reconsider. I urge the delegates at the meeting on 3 November at the CGF congress in Bermuda to put all force possible on the organisers to have them include shooting on the list for the games at Manchester. I wish Ray Godkin, the President of the Commonwealth Games Association, and our other delegates at the meeting in Bermuda the very best of success in having shooting put back on the list for Manchester.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few remaining minutes, there are a couple of matters that have been discussed during this lunch hour to which I do want to respond.

PARA.TAB: The first matter I want to respond to is Senator O'Chee's incredible claim that fringe benefits tax is responsible for the relatively new policy, of the last decade or so, of fly-in fly-out mining operations in Australia. Firstly, the fringe benefits tax introduced by this government was an essential part of any tax reform ensuring the equity of our tax system in this country. It ensures that all forms of income are taxed. That is as it should be, because fringe benefits generally apply to people with higher incomes. It is people on lower incomes who do not have access to fringe benefits. It is only right and proper that fringe benefits be included in the tax regime.

I have had the opportunity, as parliamentary secretary for primary industry and resource matters, to visit a number of these mining communities. About two months ago, I went to Roxby Downs in South Australia where I discussed this issue of fly-in and fly-out mining operations. Roxby Downs has been operating for about five or six years and it has a township built on site, like a lot of the other mining developments of the last 30 or 40 years. In discussing the issue of the fly-in and fly-out operations, there is a world wide trend to fly-in and fly-out. It has very little to do with a fringe benefits tax. Certainly, I will accept that it may be a consideration, but there are a number of other important issues that mining companies consider when determining how they operate the supply of labour to a mining operation.

The sorts of issues that are now considered right around the world are primarily social considerations. Mining companies are giving very serious consideration to the importance of not transplanting a group of people into an artificial environment in an isolated township. Certainly, the costs of such operations are a consideration, but a fringe benefits tax is a very minor part of the cost of operations for the mine. As I have said, the world wide tendency is towards abandoning fly-in and fly-out operations. I think, on balance, the reasons that mining companies give are that it is in the best interests of all concerned.

Senator Tierney gave us a contribution about road funding in the northern part of New South Wales. He alleges neglect by the member for Hume (Mr Sharp) and by members of other electorates on the north coast of New South Wales. In reference to what he says are billions of dollars worth of expenditure required on roads in northern New South Wales, Senator Tierney concluded his speech by saying that that will start when a Liberal government is elected. I am not sure what he was saying, but he certainly gave the impression that the day a Liberal government is elected, whenever that may be, there will be billions of dollars expended on roads in northern New South Wales and that that will virtually happen overnight.

If this is an early preview of what will be in the opposition's policies, I certainly welcome it. However, I question whether Senator Tierney has the imprimatur of the opposition to be announcing the expenditure of billions of dollars on highway funding as soon as a Liberal government is elected. I applaud him for his honesty but I doubt very much whether we are going to be seeing billions of dollars committed on highway funding in New South Wales as soon as a Liberal government is elected.

Many of the roads that he referred to are not the responsibility of the national government. As I understand it, we have a responsibility for the National Highway, but we do not have responsibility for the rural and regional roads throughout northern New South Wales. If Senator Tierney has managed to include that promise to spend billions of dollars on roads in northern New South Wales in the opposition's package, which we are yet to see—but he gave us a little looksee during the luncheon debate today—it will be very interesting to see whether that sort of expenditure is going to be committed to every other rural and regional area of Australia. The cost of that sort of a promise will add up to billions of dollars. Where is the money going to come from and when are we going to see the opposition's policies? Never. (Time expired)
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Order! The debate on matters of public interest is concluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask: isn't it a fact that between December 1983 and June 1995 average weekly earnings in this country fell in real terms? If that is the achievement of the Accord, the partnership between Labor and the trade union movement, why should workers vote for you again?

—The record of this government in terms of real wages and household disposable income—I apologise to the Senate that I am a bit short of breath from running to get to question time—is one that quite clearly flatters the government. What the Accord is about is dealing with living standards. Under the Fraser government, we knew all about wage rises that were eaten away by high levels of inflation, that ordinary Australians were worse off, because of a wage increase, than they were before.

—Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I do not think the minister listened to the question. The question was: isn't it a fact that seasonally adjusted average weekly earnings between December 1983 and June 1995 under this government have fallen?
—What about the second part of your question? What is the second part?
—That was the first part of the question I asked. The second part of the question, if you want me to say it again, was: doesn't that failure—
—Read the second part.

—I did not have anything to read. The question was: doesn't that failure of the partnership between the trade union movement and the Labor government demonstrate why workers have been let down and why they should not support you again?

—Madam Deputy President, on the point of order: the question has been reiterated and Senator Hill has got it into Hansard twice, which may have been his intention. But there were two parts to this question. The second part of the question was about the Accord. I was answering that part on my way to coming to the first part, and I am completely in order. This is just another stunt by the opposition to try to get a question up rather than actually be serious about asking a dinkum question.
—The question was reasonably precise but did have some open-ended aspects to it, and you have a limited time in which to get to the precise part, Senator Cook.

—In dealing with the Accord, the purpose of the Accord is about living standards. Living standards are not just wages eaten up by inflation so that people are worse off. Living standards are about good wage incomes, about low levels of taxation and about a high delivery of a social wage so that the total package in living standards rises. Under us, the total package in living standards has risen. A key part of that has been the Accord.
—Have real wages fallen or not?

—I will come to real wages. You are not going to win on that argument; you are not going to win on the real wage argument. I will come to that in a minute. Under us, living standards have risen. Compared with the opposition's record, there has been a stunning improvement for ordinary Australians.

PARA.TAB: The other part of it is that under the Accord the level of industrial disputation has dropped, industrial harmony is stronger in Australia, more investment comes to this country, more jobs get created as a consequence and the economy grows—and grows strongly. That is good news for all of those people looking for further work, and that is also one of the achievements of the Accord.

The first part of this question was about real wages. In terms of a comparison between wages under Labor and under the opposition, from June 1983 to June 1985—that is the period of comparison I have and can confirm—the percentage change in real wages, using the full-time adult weekly earnings survey basis, is an improvement of 7.2 per cent. I repeat that statistic: the percentage change upward of full-time adult average weekly earnings, based on the survey, is 7.2 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —What year?

—The years are June 1983—we came to office in March of that year—and June 1995. Over that period, full-time adult average weekly earnings rose by 7.2 per cent. That is one part of what constitutes living standards.

PARA.TAB: During that period, the burden of taxation on the average punter in Australia went down. The social wage—that is, the support of Medicare and the provision of other services delivered by this government—went up during that period. So living standards rose. Real household disposable overall incomes went up for that period by 41.8 per cent and by 20.9 per cent per capita. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I note that the minister is not prepared to challenge that, in fact, average weekly earnings in this country, seasonally adjusted, determined by the Bureau of Statistics, have actually fallen during this period of the Labor government. Is that therefore the reason your colleague Wayne Swan said:

QUESTION.PARA: It has been wage restraint on the union side during this period which has meant there have actually been declines in real wages, not ones that have actually been appreciated by the work force . . .
If that is what he meant, why do you not stand up and honestly acknowledge the failure of your government in that average weekly earnings have fallen?

TALK.START.PARA: —Because I am not going to propound a lie. I am actually going to tell the truth. I am going to actually insist that the record be right. The record is right in terms of full-time adult average weekly earnings on a survey basis, which have gone up in the period of our government by 7.2 per cent. That is the fact. I am not going to confirm figures that in fact do not tell the truth.

PARA.TAB: I am sick and tired of getting questions from the opposition asking me to confirm something which, upon closer inspection, one later on finds is erroneous. So I am going to stick with my figure. The truth is that the Accord has been fundamental to managing this economy in a sustainable way and has increased living standards of ordinary Australians without wage rises being eroded by high levels of inflation. It has been wage restraint that has enabled companies to grow and to employ more people, which is one of the other things the Accord has delivered.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I refer to the Leader of the Opposition's attempt to run air traffic control at Sydney airport from the chambers from this parliament. I ask the minister: will the government introduce simultaneous operation of the east-west runway and the parallel north-south runways at Sydney airport?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we won't. I must say—
—What did you say in 1991?

—I will tell you what I said 1991 and I will tell you what was said to you, Senator Parer, by the president of the Air Traffic Controllers Association. Just wait. If Mr Howard was some loopy local candidate in Sydney sitting on three per cent, which Mr Howard is—it is a marginal seat—and worried about shoring up a few votes under the flight path of the third runway, you could excuse it. But as an alternative Prime Minister—I have no difficulty in saying this—in all the time I have been a member of the Senate I have never seen anything so criminally irresponsible as what Mr Howard is proposing to do. I will make out my case. What Mr Howard is suggesting is criminally irresponsible, yet that is what Mr Howard is suggesting.

PARA.TAB: It is a brave person who suggests that he will use this parliament, and in particular the numbers in this Senate, to run air traffic control at Sydney airport over what the air traffic controllers say, over what the former Civil Aviation Authority says and over what the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation says. That is the expert body that actually goes and investigates the results of things like this after the event.

What Mr Howard is suggesting is criminally irresponsible. I think it demonstrates more effectively, more dramatically, than anything else how unfit he is for the high office of Prime Minister of this country. Leaders are supposed to lead. What I said in 1991—

TALK.START.PARA: —What did you say in 1991? Read it out.

—Read it out, Senator Parer! I said it in 1991, which was several years, of course, before we had the benefit of a second parallel runway at Sydney airport. And why in the hell did we spend the money to build it? So it would be safer, Senator Parer, and more efficient than intersecting runways; that is a fact. What the Prime Minister said in the House this morning is correct.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is too much talking on my left.
—What the Prime Minister said is this, Senator Parer:

ANSWER.PARA: Two parallel runways and with two parallel paths will always provide a higher level of safety and efficiency and for the city, the country a higher level of throughput.

That is correct. Yes, Senator Parer, you can operate simultaneous operations in a safe manner. But what do you have to do? Senator Parer, your ignorance on this subject is profound. But some of you people have actually used Sydney airport. What did you have to do, and what did I have to do as aviation minister, in order to make sure that it was safe? Let me tell you: we had to ban the use of simultaneous operations at Sydney airport for all international carriers, with the exception of Qantas—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not for Qantas or Ansett.

—With the exception of Qantas. But all international carriers, Senator Parer—and why? Because, as a result of the operations of simultaneous operations at Sydney airport, we came within three seconds of the worst on-ground aviation disaster in the world where three aircraft almost collided on the intersection of those two runways—and why? Senator MacGibbon should take you aside and talk to you about this, because yes, Senator Parer, you can operate simops safely if you do things like banning international aircraft from using it—
—Don't be so silly.
—Don't be so silly, Senator Macdonald? That is what happened at Sydney airport. I will read what the air traffic controller said to you, Senator Parer. Senator Parer, you asked:

ANSWER.PARA: Are you suggesting that the cross-runway operations are not safe or just less safe?
The president of the air traffic controllers association said this to you:

They are less safe. They rely more heavily upon the skill of the aerodrome controller in judging the point of conflict between two aircraft operating on the crossing runway set-up. At the moment with parallel runway operations any conflict is removed from the precinct of the airport itself.
Yes. What I have consistently said, Senator Parer, is yes, if you ban aircraft from using it you can operate it safely, but parallel runways are safer.

PARA.TAB: What the alternative Prime Minister of this country is saying is that he is going to use this parliament to impose a less safe air traffic control regime on Sydney airport than currently operates and which is supported by the airlines and the controllers. Nothing could be more criminally irresponsible. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy—and I hope he has calmed down a little. Is the minister aware that the President of the Cattle Council of Australia, John Wyld, told the National Rural and Resource Press Club this morning that Australian meat processing remains uncompetitive, and that the government has a vital role to play in creating a climate for change and reform? Is he aware also that Mr Wyld confirmed that a recent independent report into industrial relations in the processing industry found that reform had been ineffective and that the Bureau of Industry Economics says that we have slipped back in waterfront competitiveness, despite the government's reform process and the expenditure of hundreds of millions of dollars? Do you agree with that statement, Senator Collins?

—I do not know quite why Senator Boswell insists on asking the same question every day so that I can give him the same answer. This is, in fact, the third consecutive day on which that same question has been asked. In order to be consistent, apart from anything else, I will give him the same answer today as I gave yesterday and the day before: yes, there can be and should be an improvement in work practices in Australian abattoirs.
—That was said yesterday.
—Yes, in fact it was said, Senator Hill. Why don't you clean your ears out?

PARA.TAB: But it is ridiculous and silly to say that the workers and work practices in meatworks are to blame for the inefficiencies in Australian meatworks. I have pointed out the nonsense of quoting the Booz-Allen report in that regard, Senator Boswell, and that is what you are quoting from.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you got it wrong.
—You still have not read it, Senator Panizza.
—You did not say this at the start of the week. Have you read the report?
—If neanderthal man will be quiet for one minute, I will finish the answer.
—They have an identity crisis.

—Yes, they have an identity crisis. Sixty to 70 per cent of that gap of inefficiency identified by the Booz-Allen report was in fact identifying factors that are out of the control of cattle producers in Australia and processors. Of the 30 per cent gap that remains, Booz-Allen did identify work practices as being one important factor—and they are. That is why right now—and Senator Boswell simply refuses to acknowledge it—there are changes occurring in Australian abattoirs and new enterprise agreements being negotiated in cooperation between meatworkers and unions.
—Is that why they are all shutting down?

—Apart from the problem with the Australian currency; apart from the problem of the drought; apart from the problem of a higher cost of the input stock into abattoirs—apart from little factors like that, Senator Macdonald, which you simply refuse to acknowledge, even though the operators of the abattoirs have said publicly that those have been the major reasons for the closures.

PARA.TAB: The unions would have been screaming at management under other circumstances and saying, `It's all your fault.' In fact, have a look at the public statements they have made. The unions have said that, yes, they regret the closures; but the beef industry has always been a seasonal industry in Australia, closures have always been part of it—and regrettably they have—and hopefully the situation will be temporary and will improve. Have a look at what the unions have said also, Senator Boswell.

Yes, work practices in Australia can improve. But Booz-Allen, Senator Boswell—and I really do recommend that you get around to reading the report—have actually identified that as being one of the smaller factors in the inefficiencies that exist in Australian processing. One of the other big factors, Senator Boswell—and have a read of it—is in the hands of Australian cattle producers. A very significant proportion of the inefficiencies is because of the type of cattle going to the meatworks—smaller, grass-fed animals. Read the report. In respect of those work practices, there is in fact work under way and initiatives under way to improve the work practices in Australian abattoirs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Doesn't your blustering over this issue simply prove that, in the end, like the government of which you are a part, your first loyalties lie not with primary industry or even the meatworkers but with your trade union friends?
—No.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. It has been reported in this morning's media that the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, has vowed to block the sale of Sydney's airports until the east-west runway at Kingsford Smith is reopened. Senator Collins has just graphically outlined the potentially disastrous consequences of this for the safety of airline passengers. Would you explain to the Senate what the budget impacts of this approach would be?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian business community are worried by the opposition on several fronts. On one front they are worried by the opposition because of its hostility to foreign investment. They are shocked by the opposition on their industrial relations policy. But today they are shocked even further by the announcement by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, that he intends to punch a $2 billion hole in the 1996-97 budget by blocking the sale of the federal airports. They are shocked because this is an opposition intent on destroying a budget surplus.

PARA.TAB: While that is an extraordinarily bad signal to the business community about stability in government, the other thing that should be said is that the people who will bear the burden of that are ordinary Australians. This budget is in surplus. The next budget would be in surplus, if the sale were to go ahead. By virtue of those surpluses, there will be downward pressure asserted on interest rates in Australia because we have public savings because of the budget surpluses. Knock that out and, of course, there will be upward pressure on interest rates.

The people who will wear the responsibility for that will be Mr Howard and this opposition, if they proceed with their plans. Mr Howard is prepared to vandalise upwards to $2.5 billion for the sake of a handful of votes in his own electorate. He is jeopardising national economic strategy for what can be described only as local party-political interests.

He is attempting to run transport policy from his own electorate by threatening the privatisation program while, at the same time, he is saying that he supports the privatisation program. On the one hand, he is saying that he supports micro-economic reform and that it is not going far enough, and he has argued long and hard to open the third runway. But, on the other hand, he is proposing to stop the third runway and to end micro-economic reform in the transport sector with this important reform. If anyone thinks that that does not define what the meaning of the word `hypocrisy' is, then I would like to hear what they believe it does mean. This is a stunning display of hypocrisy by the opposition.

Mr Howard travels across the country lecturing the government about the size of Australia's current account deficit and warning people of its dire consequences, yet the government has put the budget into surplus to improve our national savings performance in order to address this very problem. Mr Howard's response is to wreck that strategy, to damage our savings performance and to worsen the current account situation just for gross and base political reasons. Not only is he stopping the $2.5 billion from the sale of the airports but his party in the Senate, which is supposed to be independent and cannot be directed of course, is knocking holes in both the spending and the revenue sides of the budget. He cannot run a truck uphill. The so-called `lorry of lies'—the national debt truck—broke down yesterday. Now he wants to break down the airline system.

On this important sale of the federal airports, Mr Howard should take note of what his former spokesperson on privatisation, John Moore, said. Mr Moore criticised the government last year for not proceeding fast enough with the airport sale. Mr Moore said:

ANSWER.PARA: This continuing uncertainty will do nothing to generate confidence from potential investors or purchasers in the future of these assets . . .
Further delays and doubts will make it increasingly difficult for the sale to realise $2 billion.
That is the warning from the opposition's own frontbench. What Mr Howard is doing is adding to and jeopardising—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Deputy President. Is it proper for the minister to refer to the Minister Brereton in the other place as `"Laurie" of lies'?

—On the point of order: the Acting Deputy President during the matters of public interest debate did rule that referring to `"Laurie" of lies', particularly as it relates to Laurie Brereton, was unparliamentary.

—On the point of order: we are trying to involve ourselves here in a question on some major national issues, and you get these facetious and stupid points of order. You should not only rule them out of order but also tell them to desist from it.
—I shall have a look at the Hansard later to see the context in which it was used.
—I thank the minister for his answer. But I would ask him: going on from the budgetary impact which he mentioned, what would the consequences be for the development of Badgerys Creek airport?

—The government is committed to the early development of the Badgerys Creek airport. In order to supplement the Sydney airport's traffic, we are committed to expending $1 billion on the infrastructure development of that airport. Importantly, we are committed to getting that airport as a curfew free destination in operation by 1999—in time for the huge tourist influx as a consequence of the Sydney 2000 Olympics. This will be a massive gain for Australia, and having the airport infrastructure freed up like this is vitally important.

PARA.TAB: However, the Badgerys Creek construction could not go ahead if the Kingsford Smith airport was not sold. It requires the Kingsford Smith airport to be sold to finance the development of Badgerys Creek. What Mr Howard is doing is trying to knock a hole not only in our budget but also in the Sydney Olympic Games. That is a despicable and disgusting act in its own right.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. Minister, it has been a demonstrated fact that there have been a number of breaches of compliance with licence conditions and forests being illegally logged and chipped in Tasmania, Victoria and Western Australia. The woodchip companies show no remorse for their illegal actions in destroying the magnificent and unique forest areas. In 1996 there is no guarantee that it will not continue to happen. I ask the minister: how do you propose to monitor compliance with the licence conditions and the licence issuing criteria? How will you monitor protective area boundaries and harvesting practices? Will you legislate to protect the areas named as deferred forest areas after the process is finalised this year to ensure that those areas which the government admits will be of high conservation value and wilderness will be forever safe from logging?

—Senator Bell has a close interest in the forestry issue. I am well aware that Senator Bell knows full well the answer to the question that he has asked, but I imagine he wants to have it on the public record, so I am happy to provide him with the answer. I know that Senator Bell is aware that arrangements have been altered by the Commonwealth positively to enhance the monitoring of the arrangements of licences that are issued for woodchipping. I cannot recall at the moment whether the legislation has actually been introduced yet—if it has not, it is about to be introduced—to change those arrangements so that the actual cost of that enhanced monitoring role by the Commonwealth will be paid for by the industry as part of its licence arrangements.

PARA.TAB: A dedicated and independent monitoring unit is being established within the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to implement these new arrangements. This unit will work in close cooperation with the states in the development and implementation of monitoring programs, as it must, because, as we keep on restating in here, forest management is a state government responsibility. The only role that the Commonwealth has in legislative terms is powers over the export of woodchips. The specific functions of this unit will include verification that exporters comply with hardwood chip export licence conditions, collation and analysis of exporters' annual reports on compliance with export licence conditions and the actual investigation of alleged breaches of licence conditions. I must say that those breaches are the exception, not the norm.

I emphasise that these arrangements will apply to all licences issued for export of hardwood chips from native forests. As I have already just said, the costs of this enhanced monitoring regime will be recovered from the exporters. It is proposed that fees be charged pursuant to regulations under the Export Control Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for the answer, as much as it was. He would have to recognise that there is little chance that Australian citizens will believe that the government is serious about monitoring these licence-setting criteria. With 70,000 people marching and begging the government to protect the areas, the government has not defined how it will protect them. I asked the minister whether the government would legislate; I did not get an answer to that. I am not convinced, minister. What can you say to convince those people who want you to protect the areas?

—What the government is doing—and I believe it will be successful in doing it—is establishing in Australia, quite simply, the world's best reserve system of forests. The 15 per cent criteria that has been determined has already been cited as the world's best by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature, which is the United Nations' watchdog on biodiversity. When the system is in place it will, quite simply, be the best system of forest reserves in the world. At the same time, we will provide the basis for the long-term expansion of a viable Australian timber industry.

PARA.TAB: I know that both sides of the argument have a definition of enough always being more than what you have. That cannot be satisfied, and Senator Bell knows that full well. But I have no question at all that the majority of Australians will endorse and support the government's position on this, which is to have the world's best protection for forests and one of the world's best timber industries, and both things can be done. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Regional Development. Has the minister seen today's press on the release of the final report of the Australian Urban and Regional Development Review on urban Australia called `Trends and Prospects'? Can the minister advise the Senate of the implications of this report for Australian cities, regions and urban environments?

—Yes, I have seen the report, and I have seen references to it in today's media. The report was in fact launched by Brian Howe today. The government welcomes the report. The federal Labor government is all about developing policies for all Australians so that they can have equitable access to the social and community amenities in the places in which they live and work. This latest report that Senator McKiernan referred to is exactly about developing these policies.The report comes at an important time because it will feed into important policy announcements which we can expect later this year.

PARA.TAB: Essentially, the report is a substantial research report about our cities and regions. It encompasses population trends, patterns of settlement, employment and investment, infrastructure investment, social structure, environmental impacts, and it concludes with a chapter on urban management. It recognises, as does the government, that Australia is a nation of regions. It is our urban and non-urban regions which are our competing areas. It is our city regions which provide our international trading gateways.

Underpinning the report and also underpinning the government's position in this area is an understanding that Australia must continue to develop its cities, regions and urban environment if we want to compete internationally and maintain our living standards. The government is developing policies and implementing them to make sure that the economic and social factors are there to make Australia competitive. In this report, however, there is reference to the fact that the government's programs in the area of urban infrastructure development and micro-economic reform are right on the mark. So it is encouraging to us in that respect.

Importantly also, the report acknowledges that the nation is endowed with environmental qualities which are of great economic importance and they can, together with our social justice and economic development agenda, give us integrated outcomes for the benefit of all. The latest report does provide a basis for policy development, and policy outcomes can be expected later this year.

The report is part of a broader agenda. The Australian Urban and Regional Development Review has now produced a number of significant reports which together provide a substantial body of work relating to both urban matters and regional matters. It is also part of the broader Labor government agenda, because through a number of initiatives we have directed attention to the major issues confronting both our urban and regional areas—initiatives such as the better cities program, the regional development program and a range of programs which have addressed local area planning, local government approvals and guidelines for housing development.

As the Senate is aware, and as, I am sure, Senator McKiernan is aware, it was only a few months ago, in the 1995-96 budget, that the better cities program was expanded to address three major areas—international gateways and economic corridors, areas of rapid growth and areas of urban renewal.

This report will provide the basis for policy outcomes and government decisions. I say in closing that we can compare this scientific approach based on a comprehensive overview of the needs and attributes of the Australian landscape to the ad hoc approach which has led to absolutely no policies in this area from the opposition.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the minister representing the Treasurer. The minister would be aware that the National Australia Bank is currently running a test case seeking to make customers liable for stolen and forged cheques drawn on their accounts. This is at odds with what has been the existing law in this country for nearly 200 years and was recently described to me by a senior banker in Hong Kong as outrageous. The editorial in the Australian Financial Review on Monday went further. It said:

QUESTION.PARA: If NAB wins, Australian law on cheques would be at odds with the law in most comparable countries. It is clearly desirable for Australian banking law to remain in harmony with international practice.

PARA.TAB: But perhaps the best argument against changing the law along the lines favoured by NAB is that it would not be fair.

QUESTION.PARA: I ask: given the clearly unfair result which could come out of this case, will the government intervene by urging the court to uphold the existing law and not allow it to be changed?

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator O'Chee for his question. I might say though that I do not make a subjective judgment that a court will come down with an unfair decision. I think your question referred to an unfair decision that could come out of this case. I do not make that judgment, and I want to make that definitional point clear.

PARA.TAB: The National Australia Bank is taking legal action in the New South Wales Court of Appeal. As the question intimated, it is legal action which challenges the existing common law that assumes banks rather than consumers carry the losses of forged cheques when these cheques are presented. The action being taken concerns a corporate client not an individual customer.

The matter is still before the court and, until a judgment has been handed down, I think it would be inappropriate for the government to comment on what the possible results of a court action would be. Once a judgment is handed down, we will examine that judgment. If there are, in our view, any unfair implications that may have damaging consequences for consumers, we will respond to that accordingly. I acknowledge the question but, given that there is legal action current, I do not think it is appropriate for me to speculate on what the outcome might be and what steps might flow from that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. Can I just say that there is the opportunity for the government to appear and argue on public interest grounds, and I believe that that would be appropriate. Can the government also give consideration to what impact there would be on the government's strategy to attract companies to put their regional headquarters in this country—as compared with, say, Hong Kong or Singapore—if the banking law would be more onerous on them here than it would be overseas? Would it not be inconsistent with that strategy to allow this result to make customers liable for forged cheques instead of banks?

—In respect of the remarks about our regional headquarters strategy, our strategy works very effectively. I note the observations Senator O'Chee made about what the likely impacts might be, but I have to say once again that that is speculating about what the outcome of the case might be, and I do not wish to engage in that. I would prefer to wait until the case is decided and then respond. As far as the first part of your question is concerned—about the right of the Commonwealth to appear—I will refer that to the Treasurer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. Minister, in your response to a question from Senator Chris Evans yesterday, you seemed to suggest that quarantine standards in other countries were being used as an unfair trade barrier against Australian agricultural products, such as apples, pears and citrus fruit. You also seemed to imply that quarantine standards needed to be lowered. Is it not true that Canadian salmon exporters are using the same argument to push for salmon imports into Australia? Is it not also true, as claimed on Monday's Four Corners program, that this is in fact a response to the Uruguay Round of GATT, whereby countries were pushed to lower quarantine standards and, as a result, so-called free trade under GATT will facilitate the sharing of animal and plant diseases and pests worldwide? Does the minister agree that, as a consequence of these changes in international trade regulations, Australia's ability to adopt the precautionary principle in setting quarantine standards will be adversely affected by the requirement that you alluded to yesterday that it be `justified on scientific grounds'?

—The answer to the last part of that question is no. The answer to the very first part of the question is yes. In relation to your comments in between, can I make it clear that we regard it as very important that it is recognised that the basic aim of the sanitary and phytosanitary agreement under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is to maintain and does maintain the sovereign right of any government, including the Australian government, to provide the level of health protection it deems appropriate.

PARA.TAB: We recognise the right of other countries to do that and have never challenged that. We challenge other countries which create artificial barriers. That is, they pretend that their measures are based on quarantine, when they are really just artificial measures to keep out of their market our high quality products—products which we sell in Australia to Australians on the basis of high quality health standards. We challenge that and challenge it on behalf of Australian growers—including many whom you represent, Senator Margetts, and many whom all of us in this place represent.

That is our obligation and our right, and we will continue to do it. We cooperate with the industry to do it, and we cooperate with the state governments of all political parties to do it. It is part of the appropriate action that any government—including our own—would take when it is seeking to maximise the reasonable economic welfare of its citizens without in any way undermining their legitimate health standards.

We reserve the right to establish high quarantine standards—Australia always has. There are unique characteristics about Australia that mean that sometimes the quarantine standards we set will be different from those which others set, and we retain the right to do that. But we cannot advocate one law for everybody else and a different law for us. That is, I think, a proposition that we must accept.

If we wish the international community to treat us fairly, we have to treat the rest of the world fairly. That does not mean we have to have the same standard as everyone else, because our circumstances are different. Australia has some unique characteristics—and they apply to some of the cases you referred to, Senator—that have to be taken into account and may in certain circumstances, perhaps including some of those to which you referred, justify us having higher standards than others, because we are in different circumstances. But it does not mean that we should sit idly by and allow others to create barriers so that Australian apple growers, other fruit growers, tomato growers and Australians involved in a whole range of horticultural activities are denied legitimate access to those markets and people in those markets are denied access to quality food at cheap prices.

I have never found it a progressive policy that parties of social reform and social justice would advocate that people in other countries should have to pay artificially high prices for basic food requirements. I have never understood why anybody thought that was a progressive policy, and I have never understood why you advocated it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reversal of the onus of proof surely means that the absolute proof is only created, in relation to fish, when fish start dying. In an aquatic environment, that is too late, as it would be if we imported newcastle disease. Is it not true, Minister, that, as a consequence of the Administrative Decisions (Effect of International Instruments) Bill that was tabled in the Senate today, a quarantine officer could give approval to allow the import of a fish product that was carrying a disease that may be harmful to human health and that this decision could be made without considering the requirements under article 20 of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade concerning the impact on human health? Is it not true that this quarantine officer would not be obliged to inform health authorities and fish farmers of this decision?

—The quarantine regulations are not part of my portfolio responsibility, but I can tell you that there is nothing in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade or in the rules of the World Trade Organisation that in the slightest way impairs Australia's right or capacity to protect the animal health or human health of Australians, and scare campaigns to try to build barriers will not work.

PARA.TAB: We will do that, and we will defend our right to do that, if necessary, in any challenge before the World Trade Organisation. If we are challenged, we will go there and defend our right to do that, as every other country will do. We will also defend the right of Australian growers and suppliers to supply those products and to create the jobs and the wealth in rural industry and defend the right of citizens in those countries to get the cheapest products at the best price. I have always thought cheap food was a good policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Bob Collins. I refer the minister to media statements by Senator Murphy in which he indicates that any government decision regarding the importation of foreign salmon has been delayed until after the federal election. Can the minister confirm Senator Murphy's statement or is he guilty of misleading the Tasmanian media? If the government is as prepared to support the Tasmanian salmon industry as Senator Murphy and others would have us believe, then why is the government attempting to quash any decision until after the election? What is the government's real priority—the Tasmanian salmon industry or the marginal seats in Tasmania?

—I do not think that anybody who has actually dealt with me on this issue in Tasmania—and Senator Calvert knows the personal attention that I have given this matter on several visits now to Tasmania, apart from meeting delegations here—would doubt or question for one minute that the concern of the government is in fact the quarantine issues that are associated with that vitally important industry. I have not seen what Senator Murphy said. Senator Murphy has the advantage of me in that sense. He clearly knows when the federal election date will be and I do not.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health. In recent weeks, there has been speculation regarding the possible listing of the drug pulmozyme—a treatment for cystic fibrosis patients. Sufferers and their families have been arguing for access to this treatment through the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Can the minister inform the Senate about recent developments with respect to having the drug listed and how it may assist persons suffering this most unfortunate disease—cystic fibrosis?
—And will you tell us why the minister changed her mind in two weeks.

—I am glad that a couple of senators opposite are very aware of this matter. What is important is to make sure that not only them but everybody knows what has been the recent announcement by the Minister for Human Services and Health, Dr Lawrence, about this very important matter—the listing of the drug pulmozyme on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.
