PARA.TAB: Some seem to know but I am very pleased to tell all senators that there are estimated to be something like 2,000 sufferers of cystic fibrosis and about 500 of those people will benefit from this decision. The patients, their families and treating doctors will certainly welcome this news. Indeed, that is also obviously the case with the public acknowledgment over the weekend.

Pulmozyme is a brand of the drug Dornase Alfa and it is inhaled and intended to reduce the viscosity of lung secretions—a very critical part of this disease. It is important to know that pulmozyme has already been approved for marketing in Australia for the treatment of cystic fibrosis in patients over five years of age with moderate lung disease, but it is very, very expensive. The decision is expected to cost $6 million.

It is also important to know that the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee is an independent body which recommends to the Minister for Human Services and Health which drugs should be listed. It is not something that the minister or anybody else just plucks out of the air. The decisions are based on strict criteria including cost-effectiveness and clinical effectiveness.

I would have to say the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee will discuss with the Cystic Fibrosis Association and treating doctors which patients should be able to benefit from this drug in the long term.

TALK.START.PARA: —We know who should be able to.

—Somebody over there knows the answer to everything. It is you, Dr Woods. Cystic fibrosis patients will need to demonstrate that they achieve significant improvement in lung infection after an initial trial in order to qualify for continued subsidy under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Indeed, as I think you were interjecting over there, Senator Woods, it is important that these very expensive medications be applied to people for whom they will be of benefit, not indiscriminately.

PARA.TAB: However, before the subsidising can commence, the pricing of the drug has to be considered by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Authority at its October meeting. Also, as the PBAC has recommended that pulmozyme be distributed from state public hospital outpatient departments, there will need to be discussions with the states. The announcement is very good news for cystic fibrosis sufferers and their families.

I would also like to acknowledge the contribution to this serious consideration of a number of people, including my colleague who asked this question, Senator Forshaw, and others from both sides of this chamber who have campaigned very much for the reconsideration of this. But it is important to remind senators that the decision has been changed by the PBAC, an independent authority advising the government, and on further advice about cost-effectiveness. It is important that further information be known to all senators and to people, particularly families of cystic fibrosis sufferers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question for the Minister representing the Treasurer, Senator Cook. What compensation is to be provided to superannuants and self-funded retirees to make up the second round of promised tax cuts which were set in l-a-w law before the last election?

—We announced in the budget what we will do about the second round of tax cuts and, as you would recall from the budget, where workers make their own contribution to superannuation, we will provide an additional contribution. I refer you to the budget papers on the detail of that.

—Senator Cook, that is absolutely appalling. I did not ask you about workers. I asked the question: what will happen to self-funded retirees and superannuants who will not get the tax benefits? What is happening to them? They have been cheated, they have been let down, by this government. What are you doing to compensate them for the l-a-w law tax cuts?
—I have answered the question.

—My question is to Senator Cook, the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and also the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the 18 months of exhaustive inquiry by the Industry Commission into the wine and wine grape industry and to the final report from this inquiry that the government has now had for some three months, and I ask: why has the government not released this report already? Are you aware, Minister, of the reluctance by many to invest in this industry because of the uncertainty surrounding both the final recommendations in the report and your government's response to them, in particular to those relating to taxation? When will the government release this report?

—The government will respond to the report, I am advised, in late October-early November. This report was a review of the wine industry conducted by the Chairman of the Industry Commission, Bill Scales, by Professor John Freebairn and by Brian Croser. Since receiving the report, the government has broadly followed the processes for responding to IC reports in general, and that is: not to formally respond to the report as such; to have the draft report open for a period of public comment; to receive the final report and release the final report; with a response.

PARA.TAB: I understand that departments are currently formulating advice to the government on what ought to be the grounds of the government's response to this report. But I repeat what I said at the beginning of this answer: I am advised that the government will respond in late October-early November to this report.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Ray, the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. When was the government first made aware by shipping companies of apparent irregularities in the payment of the stevedoring industry levy? Why were these apparent errors not detected by the Collector of Public Monies and the Secretary to the Department of Industrial Relations? Is the government investigating the possibility that any improper or illegal activity has occurred in the collection of the levy? Is it true that the minister's appointee to the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee has been removed from his position? Will the government guarantee: (a) to repay to any shipping company that is found to have made overpayments the full value of those overpayments with interest; (b) to pursue any shipping company that has failed to make correct payments, including, apparently, the government's own ANL; and (c) to impose the statutory penalty of 20 per cent on any unpaid amounts?

—That is an extremely detailed question. As to whether someone has been removed, I do not think even you would expect me to be able to answer that directly. The information I have on this is that stevedores, not shipping interests, were responsible under the legislation for paying the levy. They have been closely consulted on the basis for winding up the levy collection arrangements and have agreed that the remaining funds be held pending final analysis of levy payments.

PARA.TAB: Shipping interests have also been informed of this intended approach. If certain shipping lines have not met the terms of their commercial arrangements with stevedores, that is a matter for those parties to resolve. Stevedores have been asked to advise the Department of Industrial Relations of any transactions for which they have not paid a levy.

The process for winding up the arrangements will involve assessment of those obligations which have not yet been met. Claims of overpayment of levy will be considered as part of this process, which will ensure that the interests of all parties are taken into account in an equitable way. You go on to ask whether, in fact, refunds are necessary and under what conditions. Again, I will have to seek some information on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology.
—Is it really without notice?

—You ought to wait to hear it. I refer the minister to this week's annual conference of the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science. I ask the minister to comment on proposals by the government for Australia to become a centre for the development of scientific innovation in the Asia-Pacific region. What role does the minister see Australia playing in the development of science in this region, and how does he foresee the government's objectives being achieved?
—Madam Deputy President—
—You've got a brief on this, haven't you, Cookie?

—I happen to actually have made an original contribution on this subject, Senator Patterson. I am quite happy to explain it to the Senate because it is the answer to the question that has been asked of me as well.

PARA.TAB: Next week, under the auspices of APEC, there is an APEC regional science ministers meeting in Beijing. This is the first science ministers meeting ever held for APEC. It will be an important opportunity for Australia, which has pushed for this development, to post on the regional science calendar a number of significant initiatives.

The government has already done much to establish its strong science links and technology links in Asia. We have science and technology agreements with Japan, China and Indonesia. We have less formal government to government arrangements with many other countries in the region. Those arrangements facilitate science and technology collaboration. Countries in this category are Malaysia, Thailand and the Philippines.

Our major public sector science agencies are as well developing strong collaborative programs in the region. For example, 32 of the 34 CSIRO divisions are involved in a total of 380 projects in the Asia-Pacific region. Australia was strongly represented at the recent ASEAN science and technology week in Bangkok. We attended the ASEAN science and technology ministers meeting as a dialogue partner. Australia had the largest pavilion at the exhibition with over 40 exhibitors, including cooperative research centres, education institutions, the CSIRO, and the Australian Institute of Marine Science; and the Australian high technology companies were also there.

Australia is also actively promoting itself in the region as a highly competitive location for research and development. In this regard, I reported to the Senate earlier this month the release of my department's publication entitled Australia: your research and development location in Asia.

As I said, the APEC science and technology ministers meeting will be held next week in Beijing. This will be a key opportunity for Australia to take further the issue of regional collaboration. The establishment of this meeting was an Australian initiative, and we have played a leading role in shaping the agenda for the conference and in developing the proposed action plan for APEC's science and technology collaboration. The key themes for this conference include the development of a policy framework for APEC collaboration, based on shared goals and principles; improving the flow of information and technology; human resource development in these important disciplines; improved regulatory frameworks; and areas of joint research.

Last Friday, in a national video conference hook-up with 60 of Australia's leading scientists from all over Australia, I discussed the proposals for this conference with them, and they put forward some items for the Beijing meeting. There was much interest in the opportunities for Australia provided by APEC linkages in science and technology through demonstrating our capabilities in science and technology, especially given the quality of our scientists and science education; more efficient use of high cost research facilities on a regional basis; and providing new opportunities for our high technology companies.

One specific proposal I will be taking to Beijing is an Asia-Pacific project on sustainable development. This will be to stimulate combined efforts by government, private industry and scientists to make better use of science to address the region's problems of land degradation, deforestation, air pollution, cluttered cities, burgeoning population, new health crises, and improving the supply and quality of water resources. I believe that a project such as this will inspire a whole generation of the region's best and brightest scientists to choose science as a continuing vocation and will certainly attract new students into these fields. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Under the 30-day rule, I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan), why I have not received an answer to a question put on notice on 23 March this year relating to the Prime Minister's travel allowance.

—I thank Senator Michael Baume for giving me some indication that he was going to raise this matter with me today. I have inquired. The matter has been processed by the department. It is in the Prime Minister's office for checking. I expect it to be with you very soon, Senator Baume.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Trade Senator McMullan), to a question on notice asked by Senator Michael Baume this day, relating to the Prime Minister's travel allowance.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, I am surprised that it has taken since March to come out with any information, which we still have not got, about the travel allowance of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I find it even more curious that the facts which have been established by the department apparently have had to go to the Prime Minister before they are allowed to be revealed. This is a ministerial matter. This is a matter for the minister. It is not a matter of whether or not the Prime Minister agrees with the figures. It is a question of what the figures actually are for his travel allowance. As I understand it, the Department of Administrative Services is the department that handles this matter. That tends to be confirmed by what the minister just said, but the answer has gone to the Prime Minister's office for checking, as I understood the Minister representing the Prime Minister, the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan), to say.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, I find that extraordinary. The most extraordinary thing is that this question, which has taken so long to answer—well, it has not been answered yet—relates to amounts in respect of the years 1985-86, 1988-89 and 1991. It emerges from an inadequate response to a question I asked back in February of this year, when I asked what the travel allowances were.

The response excluded several months—several months in each case. The answer said, for example, that no figures were available for the period March to June 1985. Why on earth not? What is going on? When asking a simple question about what the Prime Minister's travel allowance is, you get mucked around by getting an answer that specifically excludes several months. Then, when you ask someone to correct the answer and give the facts, you have to wait another six months with still no answer.

What has the Prime Minister got to hide about his travel allowance? We all know about how he managed to live in Canberra and get a travel allowance because he put down his address as being Sydney. We know that, and we know how retrospectively that fiddle was fixed under the previous government when the Prime Minister was Treasurer.

It is particularly poor when this Senate is effectively denied for so long—and I presume I am getting an answer now only because I am nagging—a proper answer to a proper question. I regard as unfortunate that, in the first place, the original answer to my question in February was not complete and, secondly, trying to get a complete answer has taken so long. What has the Prime Minister got to hide?

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not really want to involve myself in this debate, but I think Senator McMullan must have missed the call, so I will just speak for a couple of minutes so that Senator McMullan will be aware so that he can answer Senator Baume's question. It really does seem quite incredible to me—
—I did answer the question. He has now moved a motion to take note of my excellent answer.

—The point Senator Baume was very clearly making was one that Senator Collins had a lot to say about. He said, `Why would it go to the Prime Minister? It always does,' or something like that. He had an answer and he is sitting right next to you, Senator McMullan, so I thought you might like to say whether Senator Collins was right this time or whether, as usual—100 per cent of the time—he is wrong yet again.

PARA.TAB: I am only speaking, Senator McMullan, to give you the opportunity to answer the question Senator Baume has asked. He asked the question of the Minister for Administrative Services. He expected the answer back from the Minister for Administrative Services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Uncensored by the Prime Minister.

—Uncensored by the Prime Minister. You, I understand, Senator McMullan, represent the Minister for Administrative Services. Why, then, did you say that it had to go to the Prime Minister's department or the Prime Minister's office for checking? You are shaking your head. You did not say that, is that right?
—You got the first part wrong.

—Oh, the Prime Minister's office. So are you shaking your head or are you nodding your head? I do not know much about this particular incident. I just wanted to alert you to the fact that the motion had been moved. Senator Baume is very interested in the response and, I might say, so are other senators. I would think that those who do listen to this particular broadcast would be also. Many people do. I know there are many because on Monday, when I asked a question of Senator Collins about the cattle industry, my phone ran hot with people who said, `What a disgusting reply.' People said, `I used to have some regard for that minister as the minister for primary industries.'

PARA.TAB: Senator Knowles interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —For those sorts of people it didn't. They still thought he was not a bad primary industries minister and they said, `We have now seen for ourselves what this person is like.' I said to them, `Bob Collins is not a bad fellow; a nice man.'

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—I think you had better get back to the substance of the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said, `But he does in primary industries what he did when he was in charge of the transport and the waterfront—makes the statement, sounds tremendous but never delivers the goods.' That is just as an aside. That is how I know that people do listen to this, Senator Collins, because my phone rang hot in condemning the approach you took to that very serious matter.

PARA.TAB: So Senator McMullan—I am about to sit down—you would be alerted that people listening would very much like to hear you explain why the Prime Minister's travel arrangements, that come from the Minister for Administrative Services, have to go to the Prime Minister's office for double-checking and censoring. I know those listeners are interested. I am interested and Senator Baume is interested—

TALK.START.PARA: —And how long has it been there?
—That is good. Perhaps when you do get up to respond, Senator McMullan, you could also tell us how long it has been in the Prime Minister's office because they are the sorts of things—

PARA.TAB: Senator Murphy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying something, Senator Murphy? You should give Senator Collins a copy of your speeches in Tasmania if you want to say something, something about those Tasmanian salmon things that Senator Collins has not heard from you. You should get involved in that. Just don't worry about me.

PARA.TAB: There we are, Senator McMullan. It is over to you. It is your turn to tell us why that material had to go to the Prime Minister's office and why it just didn't come straight from the Minister for Administrative Services. We eagerly await your contribution.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Wheelwright this day, relating to the proposed privatisation of Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister in his answer claimed that the coalition's decision to seek deferral of the privatisation of Kingsford Smith Airport until a fair deal has been worked out for a fair sharing of the noise problem—including the reuse of the east-west runway—would cost the 1996-97 budget between $2 million and $2.5 million. That statement by Senator Cook is typical of his and his government's statements in that it was misleading, it was deceitful and it was simply untrue.

PARA.TAB: At least the minister said that the problem would arise, as he saw it, in 1996-97. In an interview this morning the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) did not know that that was the case. The Prime Minister this morning did not even know which budget might be involved; he just said `the budget'. The clear implication to be drawn from what Mr Keating said this morning, or what he meant to give the impression of, was that the decision would impact on this year's budget—the 1995-96 budget. That is not true. There are no proceeds included by the government in the budget papers or the budget figures for this year's budget. So the impression that the Prime Minister gave this morning was deceitful, dishonest and untrue.
The situation is as John Howard, the Leader of the Opposition, said this morning in a doorstop interview. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The government needn't have a hole in its budget. In fact, there is no money for Sydney airport, as I understand it, in this year's budget anyway—so that's another piece of exaggeration.

In other words, he picked up that very obvious point by the government. The other important point is that there need not and will not be a budget hole at all, including in the 1996-97 budget, if the government takes the simple measures that are necessary to reopen for reuse the east-west airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —East-west runway.

—Indeed, it was only a week ago, on the 22nd, that the government placed an advertisement in the Australian Financial Review in connection with the sale of the FAC with the objective of seeking expressions of interest to be made in early to mid-1996, followed by a formal leasing process and culminating in the completion of the leasing process—that is, stage 1—at the end of 1996. There is no intention at all, and there never was any intention, to include even one cent in the 1995-96 budget.

PARA.TAB: The simple fact is that the hole that will occur in the budget of 1995-96 will occur not because of any actions by the coalition but because the government does not have a hope in Hades—and never did have a hope in Hades—of realising the asset sales figure of $5.3 billion that it included in the 1995-96 budget. There is no way in the world that that figure can be reached. Indeed, it even looks as though the sale of the Commonwealth Bank shares—for which a huge amount must be raised if the government is even to get within a bull's roar of its estimated figure for this year—will be deferred, as the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Beazley) said two days ago, until after the election. So, unless the election is held before Christmas of this year, there is no way that the government will get those sale proceeds in either.

Therefore, on that basis the government will be $2 billion to $3 1/2 billion short of the proceeds from asset sales this year—and that is where the real lie has come. It is in the government's own budget figures for this year, which it knew from the very outset were deceitful in the extreme and could never be achieved.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—I did not interrupt the previous speaker, but I invite him to check the Hansard tomorrow and make sure that he did not breach standing order 193(3).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short just said that the answer to this problem is in our hands, in the sense of—
—Are you taking note?
—Yes, I am taking note, Senator Patterson; like every other senator has the right to do.
—We will remember this. It's pretty unfair.

—Stop gibbering on; senators do have rights in here. Senator Short just said that we have to do the simple thing—the simple thing—of opening up the east-west runway at Sydney airport. The only thing the opposition has relied upon in terms of, as I said, this criminally irresponsible proposition is that in 1991 I made a statement about the simultaneous operations at Sydney airport. That is the only thing they have advanced as justification for doing this. I remind the Senate that it was in 1991—that is, before the second parallel runway was opened. I have to say that I greeted the opening of it with a great deal of relief.

PARA.TAB: The entire purpose of building the second parallel runway at Sydney airport at a cost of hundreds of millions of dollars was to make the operation of Sydney airport more efficient and safer. There is no such thing, as Senator Parer knows, as absolute safety in transport. When you step outside your house, you run a risk. In fact, you run a risk even living in your house, statistically.

What is beyond doubt is that, yes, it is possible to operate a safe system of simultaneous operations at airports where that is, in fact, the only option available to you, which is what the situation was in 1991. But it is irresponsible to seriously suggest that you will operate a system of simultaneous operations on intersecting airports when you have constructed a second parallel runway that gives you the option of not doing that.

I am appalled that someone who holds himself out as being a future Prime Minister of this country is seriously proposing—because he is sitting on a three per cent margin in the seat of Bennelong and he thinks it is worth a few cheap votes in his own seat—that he will use this parliament to second-guess the air traffic controllers at Sydney airport. I could not think of anything more irresponsible. It is an absolute fact, and I challenge Senator Parer or anyone else on the opposition's frontbench to deny it, that operating parallel runway operations is safer than operating simultaneous operations on intersecting runways. That is a fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —What evidence do you have?
—Thank you, Senator Herron. A press statement issued by the airlines—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like the laughter to be in the Hansard because the response to that by the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) was to say, `The airlines don't know what they're talking about.' On 18 September Qantas Managing Director and Chief Executive, James Strong, and Ansett Managing Director and Chief Executive, Graham McMahon, said—and these are the key words—that their operations experts regarded the parallel runways as inherently more safe and efficient than intersecting runways. That is a fact. I know that the operational people within those airlines know that operating two parallel runways is safer than operating aircraft arriving at the same time on intersecting runways. Even my six-year-old kid knows that. Let me quote the evidence by the president of the air traffic controllers association to Senator Parer in a Senate committee. Senator Parer asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Are you suggesting that cross-runway operations are not safe or just less safe?
Mr Lorschy, who is the president of the air traffic controllers association, said:

They are less safe. They rely more heavily upon the skill of the aerodrome controller in judging the point of conflict between two aircraft operating on the crossing runway set up. At the moment, with parallel runway operations, any conflict is removed from the precinct of the airport itself.

That statement was made by the president of the air traffic controllers association, and you do not need an expert to tell you that. As a result of a very serious incident at Sydney we had to ban international aircraft other than Qantas from using the airport when Simops was in operation, and it was less safe than the existing arrangements. It is criminally irresponsible for you to propose that we make the arrangements less safe than they are. (Time expired).

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say briefly that I do not intend to respond in any detail to Senator Collins.
—I'll bet you don't.

—It's all right for you, Senator Collins, to say, `I'll bet you don't.' You have been eating lemons all day—you have sounded like it—and you have been equally irresponsible. Let me say that it would be improper of me to respond in any detail. It is all right for Senator Collins to come in here and do so. But we have a committee operating at this stage which I chair. The Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise in Sydney has been run very well. I see Senator Forshaw, who is also a member of the committee, over there. We have certainly had a different emphasis on the committee, but it has been done in a civil way. I thank Senator Forshaw and the other people on the committee for that.

PARA.TAB: For me to respond in any way prior to the findings of that committee would be totally improper. For that reason, even though I have to bite my tongue, I thought I would make those remarks just in case some villainous individual, such as Senator Collins, says, `I gave Senator Parer the chance to respond and he didn't do so.'

TALK.START.PARA: —All I want to say is that, as I am also a member of the Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise in Sydney, I cannot participate in any substance of this matter. It would be improper to do so, just as I believe it is totally improper for Senator Collins to have imputed motives to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). I draw your attention to the motives that were imputed to Mr Howard in Senator Collins's remarks. He indicated that Mr Howard had an improper motive in doing what is totally proper, and that is to require this noise problem, which affects a very large proportion of the population of Sydney, to be resolved one way or another before the airport is sold.

PARA.TAB: The imputation by Senator Collins is typical of his personal attacks. It is typical of the sorts of personal attacks we get by the Labor government from the top down. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is the expert. He is at the top of the anthill in these matters. He prides himself on being some kind of bull ant with an effective bite. All I can say is that there is an inverse relationship between the strength of the government's argument, the strength of their case, when they are attacking us personally and the level of personal abuse.

Once again, the only thing Senator Collins could do was to make personal imputations on the integrity of a man who is recognised in this nation as an honest politician. It is no wonder that, when doing a spellcheck on your computer, it stops at the word `Keating' and says to try `cheating'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked Senator Collins what evidence he had to support the statements that he made in relation to parallel runways. All he did was give me opinions of people. Australia will be amongst the world's first users. So we have no evidence, Senator Collins. The two largest independent regional airlines operating in New South Wales—Hazelton and Tamair—have called on the federal government to reopen the east-west runway and implement long overdue changes to air traffic management procedures. We have cross-runways in Melbourne, Adelaide, Brisbane and Perth. So I think there are three points that need to be made in this debate.
—Simops at Melbourne? We're talking about two different things, you fool.
—I would ask Senator Collins to withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—I am sorry, I did not hear the remark. But it has been withdrawn.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan), to a question without notice asked by Senator Margetts this day, relating to quarantine restrictions on imports.

SPEECH.PARA: My question related to Australia's importation of possibly damaging items in relation to our primary industries. I notice that in the last year there have been many questions, motions and concerns raised during speeches in the Senate in relation to the importation of food products, animals and plants as trade goods. The base of these concerns has been the introduction of diseases or parasites which may infect our animals and plants, both cultivated and wild. Senators from Tasmania have brought up the impact on fisheries many times. The Greens and others have brought up these and other issues, such as the potential impact of Newcastle disease on both the domestic poultry industry and our native birds.

PARA.TAB: There seem to be more and more issues related to allowing products through quarantine now. Often products have not been allowed before. The major reason for this seems to be negotiations to drop so-called trade barriers. Under the Uruguay Round of GATT and the World Trade Organisation we are allowed to set up quarantine. However, this must be based on what Senator McMullan has called `valid scientific grounds'. Once it is determined that there is a real cause, it must be shown that quarantine is the least restrictive option for dealing with the problem. Only then will it be acknowledged that quarantine is not a protectionist trade barrier.

Suddenly we have the people who are concerned about farmers and the fishing industry put in the same position that those who are environmentally concerned have been in for generations. We now have a situation where farmers have to prove why they should be allowed to protect their industry from disease with the assumption that their concerns are really motivated by a simple attempt to reduce competition.

We only need to look at how difficult it has been for people to prove that a chemical that causes cancer should not be used in shampoo or that dieldrin or heptachlor should be banned and not required to be used by all householders on an annual basis to see how difficult that might be. In the shampoo case, toxicologists were tied up for 10 years fighting corporate chemists, trying to prove that a type of cancer that only occurs in relation to a specific chemical was actually caused by that chemical. After it was finally accepted, the company replaced it with a virtually identical chemical. The toxicologists were back in court for another several years.

We are being asked to prove positively that a diseased organism has the potential to infect our animals or plants. We are being asked to prove that this is the case where the organism may have been processed or treated in some way. We are being asked to prove that, in principle, processing or treatment does not render the organism safe. We are asked to ignore the evidence that there are sometimes problems of compliance. The poisoning of several people recently through eating smallgoods is such evidence. These products are usually safe when prepared or treated properly. That did not stop the poisoning.

The principle that a thing is safe until proven unsafe has never really worked to ensure safety. That is why public health, safety and quarantine regulatory agencies around the world have moved to what is called the precautionary principle. This principle states that where there is doubt, the emphasis should be on protection and the burden of proof should be on those who claim there is no problem. Under the World Trade Organisation, this principle has been reversed and we have all agreed to it in this chamber, except for us and the Democrats. The farmers and fishermen and aquaculturists will now have to prove that there is a real problem. It does not matter that the consequence of any mistakes will be devastating, and they will be devastating. Marine disease could wipe out millions of dollars of investment overnight and further threaten other aquatic and dependent bird species. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Bell this day, relating to forest management.

SPEECH.PARA: I asked Senator Collins about the monitoring of the licence criteria, the area boundaries and the harvesting practices that apparently this government would be bringing to the areas that are to be determined as deferred forest areas by the end of this week.

PARA.TAB: I asked that because, although we have been told by this government that we are to have a transparent system and that we are to see what is going on, I think the community is quite cynical about whether this will actually occur. We need to know what it is that the government is putting an enhanced monitoring system in to observe. The government has told us that enhanced monitoring will be established and there will be people in the forests checking and monitoring. We need to know: monitoring what? We need to know what the licence criteria are, exactly what the boundaries are, what the harvesting conditions are and what state information has been provided to the government to enable it to make these decisions. Unless we have this information, unless this information is public, I think the public will be unable to determine whether that monitoring has been effective. That is the nub of the matter.

In the minister's answer, all that we got was an assurance that the monitoring would be enhanced. He missed the point that this information is crucial to the capacity of the public to judge whether the government is doing its job properly. The capacity of the public to measure the government's performance here is reliant upon that information that I have listed. The public need to know what the export of woodchip licence granting criteria are, what the harvesting conditions are and the criteria used to judge those—how the harvesters are to be measured, their concern for complying with the failed national forest policy, exactly where the boundaries are and also the information that has been provided to the federal government by the state governments.

I am not convinced that that is forthcoming. The minister did not tell us how that information will be provided or who has it, nor did he indicate that it would be shared with the public, and that is the crucial point. It is the public's capacity to measure this, to be aware of this—an informed democracy is the only real democracy—and in this instance the minister did not give us any indication that that information would be made available to the public.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins), to a question asked by Senator Calvert this day, relating to the importation of salmon and the Tasmanian salmanoid industry.

SPEECH.PARA: An issue was raised relating to a comment attributed to me in the Examiner newspaper, in an article written by Claire Braund. The article states that I said the decision on whether to adopt the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service recommendation to allow the salmon imports would not be made before the next federal election.

PARA.TAB: If Claire Braund had been at the brief for the media that was held on that day, she would probably have written it differently. But even when I spoke to her on the phone, if she had put it in the context in which it was conveyed to her, it would have been on the basis that AQIS had prepared a draft risk analysis with regard to the importation of Canadian and American Pacific salmon into this country. The responses and submissions it has had following the period of time for public input are to be assessed and, if there were a requirement to conduct further scientific work as it related to Australian waters, you would not expect to get a decision before the next federal election. That is the context in which it was put and I stand by that comment because I think it is totally accurate and I think it will be the case.

I find it rather amusing and sad that Senator Calvert would come in here and ask that question. What led to that statement was that a representative of the employee's group, Salmonid Aquaculture and Fisheries Employees—SAFE—a group set up in the course of this debate about the importation of Canadian and American salmon, asked me to present to the chamber on their behalf a petition which contained some 10,000 signatures. Would they do that if they thought that I was not pursuing their interests? No, they would not.
I will seek leave to table that press statement put out by SAFE. I quote from part of it. Referring to Mr Fountain, it states:
Today he handed over the 10,000 signatures to ALP Senator Shayne Murphy, who will present the petition in the Australian Senate next week.
Mr Fountain said Senator Murphy had been one of the industry's strongest supporters.

"Senator Murphy has lobbied hard on our behalf and has demonstrated a real understanding of the threat posed to the thousands of Tasmanians employed in the Salmonid and associated fisheries industries."

SPEECH.PARA: I have read it two or three times, but I could not see where the Liberal Party, Senator Calvert or any of his colleagues got a mention.

PARA.TAB: In the discussion that occurred between state government and Commonwealth government and between industry and Commonwealth government, where did all those people, including the former Premier and now state Liberal minister, go when they came to this parliament to actually get assistance to pursue the issue in the interests of the Tasmanian salmon industry? They came to my office; not to Senator Calvert's office and not to the office of any other member opposite. They did not go there in pursuit of this issue.

I have pursued this issue strongly, and I will continue to do so because I think it is a very important issue. I will not be reflected upon incorrectly by Senator Calvert in this place. I have a very strong view about this issue, and I have put to our caucus committee a proposal with regard to further investigation. I stand by that. I will continue to pursue that issue.

Senator Calvert, you made a big mistake today. You sought to gain some trivial political advantage by using something that was not properly reported. You did not chose to quote from the article in the Mercury, and you did not chose to quote from the reports on television. I find it very unfortunate that you would choose to come in here and misrepresent me.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murphy has sought to spend the last five minutes attacking me on a lack of action. May I remind him that the first day this matter was raised I went along, at the request of the salmon industry, to Senator Sherry's first press conference on the importation of Canadian salmon. I have followed it very closely since.
—It wasn't the first.

—It might not have been the first, but it was almost the first. I remember very well the day that Senator Sherry made the very strong point that any decision on this matter would be based on scientific fact and not on politics. Senator Murphy came in here and tried to tell us that he is one of the strongest supporters and tried to tell us of his great efforts. When are you going to table this petition? You have had it for four days and you still have not tabled the petition, with 10,000 signatures. That is how serious you are about it. Where is the petition that they gave you last week? You have not bothered to table it yet. You have had it for four days and you have not even bothered to table it. That is how strong you are on the matter. Do not come in here attacking me on the matter. You have done nothing.

PARA.TAB: Where were you the day the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Committee went to Tasmania and took evidence from AQIS? We received information from the growers. We met Tim Fountain. We visited the place. We talked to them first-hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can speak for myself, without your help. When we went down and spoke to them, where were you, Senator Murphy? You are a member of that committee, but you were not there. Not one Labor senator put their head in the place; not one Labor senator turned up at the public hearing. The only senators there were Tasmanian Liberal senators and Senator Harradine. You come in here and attack me about how much interest I have. I have followed it very strongly all the way through. Don't come that one, old son.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order—
—I hope Senator Abetz will finish off what I have to say.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Order! The time for the taking note of answers has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a point of order.
—I will put the question first.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order: in relation to the taking note of answers, I understand that usually a system is applied in giving senators the call. I happen to have noted that today Senator Short got the first call and we then went to Senator Bob Collins, Senator Margetts, Senator Bell and then Senator Murphy, which meant that two Labor people got up, one Democrat, one Green and only one coalition senator.
—Senator Parer got up.
—No, Senator Parer responded to Senator Bob Collins, who took note of his own answer.
—No, Senator Bob Collins did not take note of his own answer. He was following Senator Short, I think, from memory.

—But either way, the point of order I make is: could you consider the way that this is done in the future, to ensure some degree of equity? I am not saying that the way you called people today was designed to disadvantage the opposition. I just think that, with the way people were called today, the opposition was not given the degree of time and latitude that is usually afforded to the opposition, and I would ask you to look at that.

—On the point of order: there was no quote of the number of the standing order that was not being complied with, nor any indication as to whether it was a standing order. The evidence Senator Abetz gave was faulty in that he omitted the contributions made by Senator Baume and Senator Parer and as such it gives a misleading impression as to the amount of relative time that was given to those who spoke in the taking note process.

—On the point of order: I would like to make a suggestion. I am sure the parliamentary secretary at the table, Senator Sherry, would allow Senator Abetz to have three minutes so that everyone within the chamber would be happy about what has happened. It has happened on other days that, if someone particularly wanted to speak, they were allowed to speak.

—On the point of order: I think it should be recalled that Senator Short stood up and raised the first matter to take note of an answer and then there were speakers on that, including Senator Bob Collins, Senator Parer and Senator Baume. My recollection is that then Senator Bell got the call, which raised—
—Not the speakers; the actual matters.
—Yes, I am dealing with the matters. That was the first matter raised by the opposition, and then there was a matter raised by Senator Bell, which dealt with a different answer to a question.
—Senator Margetts was the first.

—Senator Margetts raised one and then the government raised one. Mr Acting Deputy President, if you go through and look at the number of matters that were raised, you will find that it was equal right across the chamber; that is, that Senator Short raised one for the opposition, Senator Margetts, Senator Bell for the Democrats, and the first time any matter was raised by the government was when Senator Murphy got to his feet.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Thank you very much for your help. As the half hour progressed, I was aware of the fact that the opposition was not getting as many calls as it normally gets. But I did have a difficulty in giving the call to those various parts of the chamber that were seeking the call. I can recall on the first day that we were here this week the Democrats were seeking the call but did not get the call, and I have to take into consideration what might have happened the previous day as well. I just ask you to realise it is a very difficult situation to be able to ration the call when you only have half an hour.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I accept your explanation.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Calvert) agreed to:
That leave of absence be granted to Senator Chapman for the period 25 September to 28 September 1995, on account of illness.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROHIBITION OF EXPORTATION OF URANIUM TO FRANCE (CUSTOMS ACT AMENDMENT) BILL 1995

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Kernot moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to General Business order of the day no. 134, relating to the Prohibition of Exportation of Uranium to France (Customs Act Amendment) Bill 1995.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue of whether the Democrats have a mandate for many of the things which we raise in this chamber, either by way of private member's bills or by way of amendment to other matters before this chamber, has often been raised and particularly rather vehemently by newspaper editorials. Let me point out that on this particular occasion if anybody has a mandate for what we are proposing this afternoon it is the Australian Democrats.

PARA.TAB: Repeatedly in recent times we have seen surveys of Australian public opinion and over a considerable period of time, ever since the French first let off their first weapon, we have seen that the vast majority of Australians, well over 85 per cent of Australians, are opposed to the French tests. These surveys also show that not only do Australians oppose the French tests but also they oppose the export of uranium from Australia. They also have very strong views in relation to the very weak response by both the government and the opposition with respect to these tests.

We do have a mandate. We have a very strong mandate from the people. We ask: where is the mandate which the government has claimed for its very weak response? I have here the most recent poll conducted by Research International Australia which shows that 96 per cent of Australians are opposed to the French tests. Indeed, that is reflected across the world. It shows that some 61 per cent even in France are opposed to the tests. Some 95 per cent in New Zealand are quite strongly opposed to these tests. Indeed, not only do we have a mandate from the Australian people but we have a strong request from all the people in the world that we use every means at our disposal to prevent these tests. That is why this matter is urgent and that is why we have sought the suspension of standing orders.

President Chirac has said that our uranium finds its way into French bombs. `Why', he asks, `do we continue to supply uranium for this purpose if we are so opposed to the making and testing of nuclear weapons?' Senator Gareth Evans has called President Chirac a liar. Why then should Senator Evans believe President Chirac when he says that France will permanently and completely stop nuclear testing and enter into a comprehensive test ban treaty once this series of tests is over? If you do not believe the man with respect to one aspect of his claim in relation to nuclear bomb making and testing, why should we accept his view with respect to another aspect?

This is a move which the majority of Australians want. They do not want to see Australian uranium going to France while France is testing nuclear weapons either in the South Pacific or on its home territory, as was shown in the survey to which I referred.

Senator Evans has said on many occasions that if we were to ban uranium exports to France, France could get uranium more cheaply from Kazakhstan than under these long-term contracts with ERA. Therefore, France is not even in a position to make a claim against Australia to the effect that it has been in anyway disadvantaged if we go down that road and ban our uranium exports.

Senator Evans also said that there may be no shipment of Australian uranium to France before the current tests are over and France has joined the comprehensive test ban. If that is so, and France does the things it promises, there is no harm done. If it does not, the sword of Damocles is hanging over the head of the French in a—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order: I do not want to hold up Senator Coulter but he has not told us one iota of why this matter is so urgent that we should suspend standing orders to debate it. Perhaps he should address that point.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Order! There is a certain amount of latitude in this area. Continue, Senator Coulter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am explaining precisely why this matter is urgent. It is urgent because the majority of Australians want it. (Time expired)
—This is an odd place in which to be raising this particular matter.
—What's so odd about it?

—As I understand it, Senator Coulter gave notice that he would be seeking to bring forward a certain bill. The correct time for such bills to be brought forward under our arrangements—arrangements which, in some instances, the Australian Democrats have forced upon us—is on a Thursday. That is when those of us who are not in the government get an opportunity to introduce and have debate on private member's bills.

PARA.TAB: We have an arrangement with the Australian Democrats to ensure that they get a fair share of those Thursday debates. That is the arrangement for bringing on a matter of this nature. It is a pity that the Australian Democrats do not comply with the structures that they have voted to apply to all other senators. I agree that, in exceptional circumstances, the program can be rearranged, which leads to the issue of the merits of this proposal.

I have some worries with Senator Coulter's proposal because it seems to me that it would do no damage to the French at all but would benefit them. At the moment, the price of uranium on the spot market is considerably less than under existing Australian contracts. If the Australian government forced the Australian supplier to break the contract, the French would respond gleefully. If we are seeking in some way to punish the French, why would we act to reward them? There must be some logic somewhere but it is not immediately apparent. Perhaps one of Senator Coulter's colleagues will explain it.

On the other side of the ledger, of course, is that the Australian company, if we forced it to break its contracts, would no doubt have an action in damages, and the damages would have to be paid by the Australian taxpayer. What we have here is Senator Coulter looking for the Australian taxpayer to pay damages to an Australian company for breach of contract, while the French respond gleefully and welcome this action which will enable them to get their uranium from elsewhere at a cheaper price. So if Senator Coulter's motivation is in some way to apply greater pressure to the French—which is what we would be seeking: pressure to desist from their nuclear test program—then the proposal that he has, on the face of it, certainly will not achieve that and, in fact, will be counterproductive.

If the urgency that Senator Coulter is arguing is that in some way by acting upon his private member's bill we would be applying greater pressure upon France, then that case is simply not being made out. If it were the case that these sales that are taking place at the moment could have been used in the weapons that are being tested at the moment, then you might be able to at least develop an argument. But we have assurances—and I accept those assurances—from the Australian government that that is not occurring. So the fuel that we are talking about now, the sales that you are seeking to stop, is going into the power generation industry—

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you prove that?
—No, I said I am relying on the assurances of the Australian—
—They haven't made that assurance.

—They have made that assurance. I am relying on the assurances the Australian government has given us and, I presume, therefore, given you. If you do not accept their assurances, then that is a debate that should be had, but that is not the debate you are seeking to bring to the attention of the Senate today.
—Since when did you believe Senator Evans?

—That is unfair, Senator. That is below the belt. On the basis of the assurances we have had from the government that this fuel is being solely used within the nuclear power industry and because the motion will be counterproductive to the objective that we are all seeking, we therefore do not see that the urgency has been made out to suspend standing orders.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not be supporting the suspension of standing orders motion that has been moved by Senator Coulter to bring on this particular bill for debate at this time. When Senator Hill commenced his remarks, he made a point that for once I can actually agree with, which related to—
—That's a worry!

—What I say is, `He's got to be right every now and again.' You cannot be a loser all your life, and every now and again Senator Hill has to get something right. He did make a valid point when he said that this seemed like quite an unusual time to bring such a matter on through the vehicle of a suspension of standing orders.

PARA.TAB: The point I would like to make to Senator Coulter and the Australian Democrats through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, is this: ordinarily, the opposition and minor parties have used the time available for general business on a Thursday to deal with these sorts of matters and, to be fair to the Australian Democrats, that is part of our routine of business that they have not used in the sittings during 1995.

I did have a close look just a moment ago at the matters that have been raised during general business time this year, and I noticed that on no occasion, in fact, did the Australian Democrats propose a matter to come forward for debate. There have been three clear occasions in the 14 sitting weeks we have had where that general business time has been utilised by the government. There was one other period of general business, on 9 February, when both government business and opposition business were discussed, but on no occasion has a matter been identified for discussion by the Australian Democrats.

I say to the Democrats that it is more appropriate, obviously, for such a private members bill to be dealt with during general business on a Thursday afternoon. It is not uncommon, and I think all senators would have to accept this, for a debate of that nature to come forward during general business time. There are plenty of opportunities for these sorts of matters to be raised.

I think it is very unfortunate that this proposal has come forward at a time when there is such a significant backlog of government legislation for us to deal with. We started these sittings with a legislation program of some 60 packages of bills. Four weeks into these sittings, there are still some 50 packages to debate. If time is to be taken of the Senate to debate a private members bill, it would be a great deal more sensible to utilise the time that is made available on our sitting program to deal with such propositions, and that is during general business on a Thursday afternoon.

Most senators in the chamber would agree that, in the last couple of sittings, we have had a woefully inadequate amount of time to deal with government business. A tremendous number of stunts have been pulled in the Senate chamber over the past few months, and there has been a hell of a lot of politicking in this place. The sort of concentration that one would expect on the government's legislation program has not been given by this chamber. At the rate we are going, judging by our performance to date during this last session, we will be lucky to deal with half of the legislation that is before us.

Proposing a suspension of standing orders at this time ought to be identified as a stunt. I appeal to senators—the Democrats have a good record in understanding the need for orderly conduct of business in this place—on this occasion to oppose this motion, because it certainly does not provide that. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will of course be supporting the motion to suspend standing orders to urgently debate the Prohibition of Exportation of Uranium to France (Customs Act Amendment) Bill. Although the urgency currently centres on the French, China has been testing this year and the US, Russia and the UK all would not mind having a go at the kind of thing the French have announced and in fact carried through. It would be open slather for the nuclear arms race, and current disarmament rhetoric would stay just that—rhetoric.

PARA.TAB: The Greens (WA) believe Australia should not be exporting uranium at all. Australia currently sells uranium to Japan, South Korea, Sweden, France, Spain, the UK, Belgium and Finland. We would like to see the mining contracts of ERA and Western Mining with companies such as Cogema cancelled and legislation to stop the government giving away uranium stockpiles.

I understand why the Australian Democrats have written this bill in the way they have. It closely mirrors existing ALP policy to expose the hypocrisy of a government that will not even support its own party policy. I urge all Labor Party senators to take note of this paradox and vote according to conscience, not party line, else they will be guilty of betraying their own party yet again.

The Australian government response to the French nuclear tests has been completely inadequate. Ordinary Australians feel the same way. It is something that nobody has stopped talking about. The main thing the government has to do if it is serious about not being part of these tests and the aspirations of France to remain a strong nuclear power is, instead of tinkering around the issue, ban all sales of uranium to France and other countries.

Has the government got the means of doing this? This is a fine legal point. With GATT, the national interest clause and the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, there may have been a trade-off, a sell off, of our national interests. Has the government got the political will to ban uranium sales? It is not just a matter of the government doing intergovernmental deals to sell the uranium stockpile. It would also be an important matter to stop our two uranium producers, ERA and Western Mining, from selling uranium direct to nuclear nations.

It is interesting to see that an issue like this exposes the stakes that other countries have in the sale of our uranium. Australia sells France 280 tonnes of uranium per year through ERA. France owns 8.3 per cent of Energy Resources Australia directly via nuclear fuel cycle firm Cogema, which is owned by the French government. Cogema also owns most of the two other firms, Saarberg Interuran and Urangesselschaft, which also have large shares in ERA.

In 1990, ERA had a direct contract with Cogema for 125 tonnes per year as well as contracts with Saarberg Interuran, 75 per cent owned by Cogema, for 250 tonnes per year and for 100 tonnes per year with Urangesselschaft. These contracts with Cogema were negotiated after the institution of a testing moratorium and should have been cancelled with the announcement and the resumption of the testing.

The damage done to our economy by banning uranium sales would be minimal. ERA has for a number years been selling uranium for less than it costs to produce. The French decision to resume testing is just one more reason for Australia to cease uranium mining altogether and withdraw completely from the nuclear fuel cycle. Australia is a major contributor to the spread of nuclear weapons in France, the nuclear weapons states and nuclear powered countries with nuclear weapons aspirations. Giving countries nuclear technology is akin to giving them nuclear weapons potentials.

Over the last eight years, the federal government has given permission for enough plutonium of Australian origin to be separated for the construction of 250 nuclear weapons. Since 1986, the Australian government has given permission for spent nuclear fuel containing 327 tonnes of Australian origin uranium to be reprocessed.

Safeguards do not work. One of the major problems with safeguards is that accounting methods used in large-scale reprocessing plants are able to account for only about 97 per cent to 99 per cent of the plutonium separated from nuclear fuel. The small amounts that are not accounted for are significant because only small amounts of plutonium are needed to construct a nuclear device.

On a large scale, the figures are alarming. A large-scale commercial reprocessing plant such as La Hague in France handles approximately 800 tonnes of spent fuel a year. After a year of operation, the loss is enough for 24 kilograms of weapons usable plutonium. Eleven kilograms of weapons usable plutonium is enough for a bomb.

These kinds of problems have led to major problems in black marketeering of uranium, of which Australian origin uranium would be a source. It is very clear that the only thing Australia can do to keep itself free of blame for nuclear testing in this region, for providing the material to test weapons and for adding to the international nuclear arms race and nuclear fuel cycle, is ban uranium sales. This is urgent. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter is urgent. It must be discussed today. It need not be delayed any further. Those who are committed to questioning what the French are doing in the South Pacific should look beyond the niceties of the argument that was presented by Senator Hill and Senator Faulkner and look towards where their conscience leads them—whether they truly do oppose what the French are doing or whether they just want to keep the daily program neat and tidy.

PARA.TAB: The action that Senator Coulter is undertaking follows a series of questions, petitions, notices of motion and the mounting pressure that the government assured us it was adopting in its stance regarding what the French are doing. The government assured us that it would conduct an escalating program of opposition. This is another stage in that. We are using whatever parliamentary devices are available to us to support the petitions, the postcards, the letters, the personal messages, the boycotts and the visits. Mr Acting Deputy President, you would know of the international travel that has been undertaken by MPs.

This action is in support of and part of—it is not the best or only action by any means—the continuing strategy. For anybody in this place to deny its urgency is to be hypocritical about any of the other tactics and moves that have been undertaken. By not discussing this at the moment, we are thumbing our noses at international politicians and at the unanimous opinions that have been expressed through Australia.

Senator Coulter mentioned the most recent poll of 27 September. That provides us with the knowledge that 83 per cent of New Zealanders opposed the tests, as did 79 per cent of Australians and 71 per cent of French. Yet here we are, thumbing our noses at that and denying the opportunity for those sorts of people to be represented in a continuing action in this place.

It has been suggested that we should wait until Thursday so that everything can be nice and neat. If we, as the Democrats, wish to raise something in general business on Thursdays, it is with the permission and cooperation of the coalition and we are not able to be assured that that will happen.

Talking about assurances, we heard Senator Hill very meekly agreeing with the assurances of Senator Gareth Evans that Australian uranium was not used in French weapons. There are no such guarantees. No guarantees have been given to this parliament. Despite persistent questioning from Senator Bourne, the foreign minister has not been able to guarantee that. He has not given us any guarantees because such guarantees are impossible. The Democrats first revealed that in this chamber in 1989 in relation to the flag swapping deals that had been done to move uranium around, to make the uranium that is used in both weapons and fuel for power generation a generic substance. It is not possible to keep it separate and it is not possible to determine whether there is any Australian uranium in French weapons. Yet we had Senator Hill blandly standing there agreeing that whatever Senator Evans said had to be right and that therefore there was no point in opposing it.

We also had Senator Evans responding to my recent questions as to what he had done to determine the true story of whether French military flights took place over US airspace. I asked what he had done to determine whether what was published in the New Scientist on that matter was true. He had done nothing. He had not approached the United States Department of State to determine whether such flights took place. He said that the French could travel through Guadeloupe, or somewhere or other. He had not made any effort to determine that or not.
We have to debate this matter today. We have to take whatever steps we can. We should not be shillyshallying about with the niceties of Senate procedure. Let us get on and do something.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no urgency in relation to this matter. Whilst Senator Bell seeks to belittle my leader in this place, saying that Senator Hill meekly accepts what Senator Gareth Evans said, I simply remind Senator Bell that his leader kissed Senator Evans. Our leader has never gone that far. If you want to talk about embracing the Labor Party, your statistics are a lot worse than ours.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the question of urgency, clearly it is a matter of very real concern to the Australian people that there are nuclear tests taking place at the behest of the French. In relation to the public debate in this matter, my leader in the other place, John Howard, was the one who raised this issue and really made Senator Evans get into a position where he represented the views of the Australian people. I think the Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, is to be congratulated for the stance he took.

The results are now clear that on the issue of French nuclear testing there is a bipartisan approach in this country. Ninety-six per cent of people oppose it. The next matter then is how we deal with that issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are running away from it.

—No, we are not running away from it. There is a recognition within the Australian community, as shown by an opinion poll in the Australian in recent times, that the opposition is clearly out in front in relation to environmental policy. Thirty-one per cent of people believe that the Liberal and National parties have the right policies in relation to the environment compared with the Australian Democrats, who enjoy 13 per cent support, which is less than the `unknown' category of 17 per cent. Their relevance in the environmental debate, with respect to them, is very minimal.

PARA.TAB: Of course, what they are trying to do is look at the polls, which show that support for the Democrats is always on the decline. There is no support for them in the community, so they have looked for an issue they think they can piggyback on—the 96 per cent support against the nuclear testing—to try to get some support for themselves in the forthcoming election. That is their motivation. That is their stunt. It is quite appropriate and quite proper that we in the opposition are so very strongly opposed to nuclear testing by the French—and, might I also add, by the Chinese. We oppose that. We see that simply as a stunt. There is no urgency that is made out—

TALK.START.PARA: —When did you make your first speech on nuclear disarmament?
—Isn't that very interesting? I welcome the opportunity because in taking note of answers—

PARA.TAB: Senator Spindler interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, no. When this issue first came out, I raised that matter and the Hansard record will disclose it. Unlike those in the Democrats—
—Since 1977. How outrageous!

—The chances are that the Australian Democrats were still in swaddling clothes in 1977. In 1977, about 20 years ago, I was still at matric. All you Democrats are showing your age. Twenty years ago you might have represented the youth of this country, but you people need some generational change in your ranks. We on this side have some younger members in our ranks—like Senator Bill O'Chee, Senator Ian Campbell and me—who are able to reflect—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: has the last two minutes been in any way relevant to this motion to suspend standing orders on the nuclear debate? I would submit that he should be brought back to the matter before the chair.

—You do not need to rule on that, Mr Acting Deputy President. I fully accept the point of order and I confess that I rose to the bait thrown out by the Democrats. I think I have sufficiently demolished them not to continue in that vein. The simple—
—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: in fact, what Senator Abetz has done is just demonstrate how little he knows about the nuclear issue and that is why he has got off the point.
—There is no point of order, but Senator Abetz has run out of time.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Patterson proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The continued failure of the federal Labor government to address the problem of unemployment, in particular the unacceptably high levels of hidden unemployment, underemployment, youth, rural and regional unemployment.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling Senator Patterson, I would ask that the clerks set the clock for speaking times in accordance with the agreement that has been reached.

—The issue that we are discussing today is unemployment, and we will have all sorts of furphies and excuses from government senators on the other side. But unemployment, the shortage of paid work, in Australia today continues to be one of the major problems this country is facing, just as it continues to be one of Labor's greatest failures.

PARA.TAB: Unemployment is running at 8.2 per cent, seasonally adjusted, for August. This means that officially there are about 755,000 people who are unemployed—three-quarters of a million Australians devastated, disillusioned and debilitated by the soul-destroying situation of failing to find meaningful full-time employment. Each one of those is an individual—not a statistic, not a number, but an individual: a young person looking for a job, a woman looking for a job, an older man who has been thrown onto the scrap heap. I repeat: there are about 755,000 individual Australians who are unemployed.
The official figure of three-quarters of a million unemployed is alarming in itself, but more alarming is the answer to the question I am about to ask: what is the real level of unemployment?

TALK.START.PARA: —They won't tell us.
—The real level of unemployment—
—Hidden.

—is hidden. The official figure is just the tip of an iceberg—an iceberg created by Labor's failed policies, an iceberg made up of Labor's deceit, an iceberg made up of hidden unemployment and hidden underemployment. Labor needs to get real.

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating said to small business, `This is as good as it gets.' By saying that to small business, he is saying to the Australian people also that this is as good as it gets for them because small business employs the majority of people in this country. So if this is as good as it gets for small business, then this is as good as it gets for people looking for work. So this is as good as it gets. Labor needs to get real—to stop hiding behind the contrived and totally false figures, because this alarming iceberg will sink Australia and take an army of unemployed with it.

What is the size of the iceberg? What is the size of that hidden group of people underneath the tip of the official figures? There are over two million Australians who want more work than there is available—over 2 million people who say, `We are willing to work for more hours than we are able to get.' That is the size of the problem, and the size of the problem highlights the amount of hidden unemployment and the amount of underemployment which exist.

This is the Labor government with its various accords and its relationship with the ACTU, the praises of which Mr Keating will be singing today—and I think Jennie George has forgotten that she is no longer No. 3 on the Senate ticket in Victoria; she now is to be president of the ACTU. Not every member of the ACTU is a staunch Labor voter. If Jennie George is to represent the workers of Australia through the ACTU, she ought to remember that. She ought to put aside her party politics and represent those workers.

We have always agreed that there is a place for unions in this country, if what they do is represent the real interests of workers—not those who are attempting to get false benefits for themselves—in achieving real and proper working conditions. Jennie George ought to have gone into the ACTU and demonstrated that she could do that in an unbiased way. But she has not done that. In her first appearance on a television program she indicated that she was there as a member of the Labor Party. I hope that today, as she takes on that new role, she thinks very carefully about that.

The ACTU, in concert with the government, has given Australia the highest level of unemployment since the Great Depression. That is what we reached; that is what we achieved. What we are seeing now is the backwash of that highest level of unemployment since the Great Depression.

The rigidity of Labor's industrial relations system discourages employment and in many cases, like unfair dismissal, actively discourages businesses from employing people on a full-time basis. My young brother, who is 24 and now managing part of my father's family business, rang me the other day and said, `You can't put people on because you can't sack them if they steal something.' That is a 24-year-old who wants to employ someone. You cannot put people on because you cannot dismiss them.
