Small businesses are not willing to employ people on a full-time basis. They will take on casual labour; but they will not employ people because the unions and the government's legislation have made it so difficult for them to actually take people on in good faith. The government and the unions are denying employment for hundreds and hundreds of workers in this country who are prepared to work, and work cooperatively with employers. That is what they have done. They have destroyed the opportunity, because employers are not willing to employ people.

The government will no doubt get up and crow about jobs growth; but this will not deceive the Australian public. The number of people in full-time work is still less than it was five years ago. What is more, statistics on long-term unemployment released on 15 August this year showed that there has been no decline in long-term unemployment over the previous seven months. These long-term unemployed people have been dumped like flotsam in the wake of the recession that we had to have. They are the victims of the recession that we had to have—Mr Keating's recession. They are the people who have been left in the wash of that recession like flotsam, with no job and no hope.

The failure of Labor to address the totally unacceptable level of real unemployment and long-term unemployment is not only creating a trail of human tragedy but also producing an enormous bill costing billions of dollars to Australia in benefits, allowances and subsidies. We also know that the unemployed are more likely to seek help from doctors and are more likely to be ill. Not only is it a cost; it is also a tragedy for them. These are the people who cannot get work and want to work.

Not only is there an army of long-term unemployed; as I have said, there is also an army of people who want more work and an army of people who are the hidden unemployed. How is Labor hiding the unemployed? When you look at those official figures do not forget that in 1994-95 over 98,000 unemployed people were placed on benefits, which removed them from the standard JSA and NSA statistics.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many?

—Ninety-eight thousand. Two hundred and fifty thousand people were placed in short-term training programs or subsidised employment, which removed them from the JSA and NSA statistics. These programs can be effective only when there are real jobs created. Because of the industrial relations policies of this government—there are lots of other reasons: tax on business, et cetera—employers are not willing and prepared in good faith to take on new employees.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at where people have been shifted to in 1994-95: mature age allowance, 32,000 people; mature age partner allowance, 12,000; widow allowance, 10,000; youth training allowance, 20,000; community development employment program, 24,000; jobstart, 189,000-odd; training wage, 5,000-odd; new work opportunities, 11,000-odd; contracted placement, 4,600; post placement support, 100; disability reform package post placement support, 150; landcare and environment action program, 12,700; jobskills, 12,600; new enterprise incentive scheme, 6,000; and Office of Labour Market Adjustment, 13,000. That is where they have all gone.

How well do they do? That is interesting. Dr Kemp asked a question on notice in the other house about labour market program outcomes. What happens to these people? How successful are these programs? Let us have a look at them. After three months, what percentage of people do not have a job? Sixty-three per cent of people do not have a job three months after they have been on jobtrain; jobstart—it is a bit better—37 per cent are unemployed; job clubs, 60 per cent do not have a job three months later; job skills, 60 per cent do not have a job three months later; special intervention, 70 per cent do not have a job; accredited training, 65.5 per cent do not have a job; LEAP, 60 per cent do not have a job; skillshare, 60 per cent do not have a job; and OLMA, 51 per cent do not have a job. I could go on.

These people are taken off unemployment benefits, put onto a training program and most of them—over 50 per cent of them—do not get a job. The same thing happens with the other labour program, the new work opportunities program. Seven in 10 new work opportunity participants could be unemployed at the end of the program. Seventy per cent of the people whom Labor took off the unemployment queues to make the figures look good go back onto the statistics. That is what this government is doing: putting people onto programs. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is discussing Senator Kay Patterson's matter of public importance. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The continued failure of the federal Labor government to address the problem of unemployment, in particular the unacceptably high levels of hidden unemployment, under employment, youth, rural and regional unemployment.

Of course, Senator Patterson has conveniently ignored that we have come out of a recession with a worldwide problem of unemployment, and Australia is better prepared than most other countries as a result of the policies that this government has put in place. That is in sharp contrast with what happened when the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, was Treasurer. Unemployment was over 10 per cent in this country. When he left office there were 158,000 15- to 19-year-olds looking for full-time work. Today there are 91,000. That is a stark fact. I was here in 1983 and before. I remember very well the situation that existed. People were not being helped to get back into employment; they were not being trained.

PARA.TAB: Of course, Senator Patterson mentions hidden unemployment. It is particularly ironic that the coalition mentions hidden unemployment. If participation rates were the same today as they were when Mr John Howard, the Leader of the Opposition, was Treasurer, then our current unemployment rate would be five per cent—five per cent, if we use the figures, the statistics and the standards of John Howard when he had the opportunity of running this country. You cannot make any comparison at all, because under John Howard people just gave up.

There was a hopelessness that was reflected in the debates we had in this chamber. People did not even bother entering the system because despair was the order of the day when John Howard was the person who was controlling the purse strings and the policies in this country. Countless thousands of women have benefited from Labor's initiatives in the period that we have been in government. I take up Senator Patterson's suggestion that you do have to look at the total picture. I certainly will look at the employment policies of our government as part of the overall economic and industrial relations atmosphere that exists in the country.

We must ask the question: what would the opposition under John Howard do about employment? They will not really tell us. He is asking the Australian people to vote for him, but he does not have the decency or the courage of his convictions to tell them exactly what they will be voting for. What we do have is the nitpicking that has been characterised by Senator Patterson's contribution of trying to undermine the picture we are painting here—for people to be able to take their place in employment and come back into the work force in a properly codified way where there is industry training and career paths.

In contrast, the opposition at this very moment is following a policy which is the old election policy revisited. Already we have the chaos in economic terms that this will give us. We have the question of overtime rates, penalty rates, penalties for weekend or night work and holiday leave loadings, which will all be under challenge. If wage and salary earners exercise their democratic rights in relation to those industrial relations issues to which Senator Patterson referred, they will be punished and have those rights taken away from them.

We thought that Jeff Kennett's impulsive, destructive industrial relations policies were disastrous, but we now have Premier Court's Western Australian model to show us just what would happen under a coalition government: it would be survival of the fittest. The opposition's offer of Jobsback is largely intact, with only a shift in the opting out provisions and the jettisoning of the electorally disastrous and completely discredited youth training wage.

It is significant that in July this year Peter Reith, the shadow minister, said that the real barrier to work reform `is the intervention of the commission or the right of intervention by trade unionists who do not have a member on a particular site'. Senator Patterson has alluded to that again today. It is the nub of the industrial relations policy of the coalition. They would remove the rights of unions to intervene before the commission. This not only has the effect of hurting unemployed people who are aspiring to work at a proper rate but also undermines the rate of work for employed people going from job to job and employed people generally. All the resources of the employer are with the employer. He or she has those resources but, unfortunately, the person applying for work or the person in work will be undermined by those policies that a coalition government would follow. In other words, it is a law of the jungle situation where the employer has all the advantages and the person in the workplace has all the disadvantages.

Any level of unemployment is too high, and I agree with Senator Patterson that that is a serious thing. This government has an aim to get unemployment down to five per cent by the year 2000, and I hope we will never accept five per cent. The reality is that we have achieved the targets that we have set in bringing down the unemployment figures. Every time that the opposition has said that we would not achieve the figures, we have in fact achieved them. For example, total unemployment fell by 140,000 in the 12 months to June 1995. That is almost a 16 per cent drop in unemployment. Total long-term unemployment fell by 74,000 people—almost a quarter—in the same period. The OECD forecasts that unemployment will be at eight per cent in 1996 in line with budget forecasts. Our approach is not piecemeal. We have a progression there based on a whole range of policies which we have put in place that are working consistently to reduce unemployment levels.

We address every area of the problem. We do not use unemployment, as the coalition would have if it had won office at the last election, by shoving people into $3-an-hour slave labour. Whatever variant the coalition finally comes up with, we will be developing our policies based on a fundamental integrated approach. We want to develop the human capital of this country. We are making sure that there is an integration between the education and the training of people to be able to deal with the changing workplace that they will be going into. That is what we are doing.

We are not going to go back to the Howard years of a low skill base and a policy that does not deal with issues in an integrated way. We want the total picture. We start off with our basic building block of secondary schools. More young people are staying at school longer. When we came to government, three in 10 people stayed at school until year 12. Now the figure is eight in 10. That is the difference between us and the opposition. That is one of the key building blocks which will ensure that young people will have a future.

In addition, there is post-secondary education, apprenticeships and training. Significant TAFE increases have occurred. The government will spend $1.55 billion on vocational education and training between 1994 and 1997. Next year the Commonwealth funding of TAFE will provide an extra 300,000 places over and above what the states and territories provide. We have a similar picture with universities. As I pointed out before, John Howard said that we could not create half a million jobs in three years; he said that it could not be done. The target was reached a year early, and this government has created 630,000 jobs since the last election. John Howard says that we will not get the unemployment figure down to five per cent by the year 2000, but clearly we can and we will.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance submitted by Senator Patterson relates to `the continued failure of the federal Labor government to address the problem of unemployment'. I cannot agree that the government has continually failed to address that problem. There have been a number of situations in which the government has attempted to address this problem. Whether they have successfully resolved the problem and whether their addressing of this problem has been useful is a different question.

PARA.TAB: Recently, Senator Troeth and I took part in an SBS program called Insight, which considered the question of whether Australia could achieve an unemployment rate of less than five per cent by the year 2000. The government was represented to some extent by Mr Langmore, a member of the House of Representatives. He was not keen to be described as the government representative, but he was there. There were 50 others there. They expressed concern that the government could not achieve that aim unless changes were made to several things—not the least of which was the way in which labour market programs are heading.

One participant, who was a representative of the armed forces, spoke of the difficulty of recruiting young people to our armed forces. The dozen or so young people who were there unanimously rejected the idea of working for the armed forces, even though the government is spending a huge amount of money on recruitment advertisements for that same employment prospect. That illustrates the difficulty that the government has. In many instances, the areas of traditional employment or the areas which might seem to be areas in which young people could be enticed to develop a career are not those areas that attract interest. The government is also spending a large amount of money on the labour market programs, and some of these are not the most appropriate offerings. Senator Patterson is right to draw the Senate's attention to the fact that an average of 60 per cent of the participants remain unemployed after taking part in jobtrain, jobskills, jobclub, LEAP and skillshare types of programs.

The Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee, of which I am a member and which is inquiring into long-term unemployment, has considered the question of removing people from unemployment benefits, or whatever the payments are, and putting them into these sorts of schemes. It is particularly looking at the long-term unemployed people who are no longer part of the unemployment statistics but who, subsequent to the completion of such programs, do not join the ranks of employment. That changes the statistics with regard to long-term unemployment. It confuses the analysts. It is not providing an accurate picture of the profile. However, that is not to say that they are all wrong. During that SBS program, I complained that many of the labour market programs, as I have just said, did not necessarily recognise the areas of interest and the areas of growth in our employment opportunities in Australia.

Minister Crean has shown that he recognises these areas of growth and interest with his recent initiatives with regard to youth employment strategies. He was telling youth that they have the power and an opportunity by giving them multi-media access to more information. I think that must be acknowledged as a step in a direction which I think is important—that is, to recognise the huge growth in employment opportunities in the areas of arts, recreation and entertainment. After all, we only need to refer ourselves to those who are often described as the richest Australians, whether it be Mr Packer, Mr Murdoch or others involved in those industries, and ask ourselves: are they industrialists or are they people who have invested and reaped the benefits of their investment in entertainment and the arts? That should indicate the direction in which we should invest further facilities.

The investment in those areas is something which has taken a long time to reach, but now we see some tentative steps. I have to acknowledge that some tentative steps have been taken in that area by Minister Crean. I have faith that this is an area which will reap great rewards for Australia because if there is anything that we have an actual advantage in it is in those areas, particularly in recreation and entertainment.

Not so long ago California was described to me as having the world's fifth largest economy, based mainly on sunshine. The sunshine had facilitated the development of the entertainment industries in Hollywood. That is a significant component and a major reason why a great number of large international entertainment industries are located there. We have similar comparative advantages and it is about time we recognised them.

I will mention one particular group in this context. Last year I sponsored a visit to this place of the Rip'n Tear Theatre Company. I know that Senator Harradine knows something of that group and supports it in its endeavours. This theatrical group was established in Burnie in Tasmania and works essentially with young offenders and helps to increase their self-esteem. I acknowledge Senator Denman in the chamber, who has also supported this group in the past. These people are given the opportunity to develop their talents, skills and self-esteem in learning the craft of theatre and learning what opportunities they have to express themselves and also to develop their capacities in this area of increasing employment opportunities in Australia.

Support of such groups throughout regional Australia could provide great benefits to this government. We do not have enough investment in such strategies. Another group called Big Hart, Big Art is a proposal to establish in regional Australia the infrastructure to enable the development of our young people's talents in the arts. If Mr Murdoch is investing several hundred million dollars in film studios in Sydney, I can anticipate a great growth in this employment opportunity area. That is one thing that the government should address and develop. I will not condemn the government outright for not having done that. It should recognise that this is the area of growth and continue investment in it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating a matter of public importance which says:

PARA.TAB: The continued failure of the federal Labor government to address the problem of unemployment, in particular the unacceptably high levels of hidden unemployment, under employment, youth, rural and regional unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: This afternoon I would like to focus on the question of youth unemployment. It is a very serious problem. Currently, youth unemployment stands at about 26.3 per cent, although young people have constituted as much as 40 per cent of the unemployed Australians in the earlier part of this Labor reign. By way of comparison, the general level of unemployment supposedly now stands at about 8 1/2 per cent. I say `supposedly' because I take up the issues that my colleague Senator Patterson mentioned earlier about the iceberg. The level of 8.5 per cent constitutes that iceberg that is above the water. The rest of those people who are unemployed are hidden in other areas under the water. That is the problem and that is where we are at today.

PARA.TAB: All this Labor Party can do is take out full page advertisements, on the one hand accusing us of not having an industrial relations policy and then, on the other hand advertising the pitfalls in that policy. How can you possibly have it both ways? The contribution, albeit from you, Mr Acting Deputy President, when you were not in the chair, was quite remarkable. You focused not one skerrick of your attention on the real problems associated with unemployment, the real problems associated with young people and the ramifications of those high levels of unemployment. The reason for those high levels of unemployment generally and, in particular, youth unemployment, is that the government has allowed small business to be ground into the ground.

The government has sent so many primary employers in this country to the wall. It has taxed the rest to death and continues to tax them. They simply cannot afford to employ people. Once again, as Senator Patterson said, they cannot afford to employ them and they cannot afford to sack them. The fact that youth unemployment has remained more or less three to four times the national average of unemployment is an absolute scandal and should be something about which the government is deeply ashamed and doing something to rectify. Is that happening? No, it is not. The fact is that the lack of those policies to help young people has increased the issues of homelessness, poor health, suicide, illicit drug use and crime, just to name a few. Once again, there is no demonstration of concern amongst the members of this government and there is certainly no will, wish or desire to correct the policy mistakes that have led to these dreadful statistics that we now see.

In August this year—one year after Working Nation was brought down—youth unemployment stood at 26.5 per cent, just 0.1 per cent lower than in August 1994. In fact, the number of young teenage males out of work had actually increased since Working Nation. So what is the government doing about it? Working Nation has not worked. Is there something that it has in the pipeline to rectify it? The answer is clearly no. I will be interested to know whether or not the following speakers from the Labor Party have any contribution to make in the way in which it is going to solve this. I hesitate to say that there will be no such contribution because surely if there was to be some clear sign that it was going to resolve these problems, it would have happened already.

I refer to the social ramifications, for example, of interest rates and housing. The issue of housing is so critical. Young people today cannot find housing that they can afford. The accessibility of public housing is simply not there. In many cases, understandably, public housing is allocated to families before young people. The other issue of housing affordability is to buy, which is something that is just getting way out of the reach of young people. They have not been able to secure full-time employment, they do not have any security in the employment that they have and, therefore, they simply cannot budget and look at the purchasing of a house. Housing prices and interest rates have just gone up and up and further and further out of their reach, while they simply cannot get work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—If Senator Neal wants to flap her gums over there and say that that is wrong, I challenge her to go and talk to young people out there in the street and actually find out how many young people can afford to buy a house in the suburbs of, say, Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide, Perth or Brisbane. They cannot afford to do it because they do not have a job to enable them to make the repayments. How can they pay a mortgage? How can they get a mortgage if they do not have a job? Your government has ensured that they do not have jobs. That is an absolute national disgrace.

PARA.TAB: We should look at the question of underemployment because there are highly qualified graduates fresh out of university who do not show up on the unemployment statistics because they are working in McDonald's to pay their way in life. For someone who has qualified as an engineer, a doctor or whatever, working in McDonald's is not necessarily what they have studied for. Yet what you have done as a government is to simply let these people rot on the heap, with utter disregard for their future and the way in which they are going to tackle it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about your policies.

—We will tell you at a time of our choosing. As I said to one of your equally silly colleagues the other day, we are not going to tell you what our policies are going to be. We will tell the people of Australia at a time of our choosing. We know what our policies are going to be. The fact is that you are the government. The mere fact that you are seeking to know about our policies is a clear reflection that the Labor Party is an absolute vacuum. You cannot rely on your own policies to get young people out of this mess that you have put them in, so you are begging to know the way in which we would solve the problem.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that this government has failed young people. It has failed them miserably. From the day that it took over, it has ensured there are 30,000 young homeless people who simply cannot get homes, who cannot get jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Cut that out. Be factual, Senator.

—Cut it out? Okay, I will give you a bit of a quote. The National Youth Housing Strategy executive summary, prepared by AGB McNair in March this year, found there were about 30,000 young homeless people and a further—if you did not like the 30,000 figure, you might like the next one—`230,000 independent young people on low incomes who have problems finding affordable housing'. Are you happier with the 230,000 figure? The fact is that this government has failed young people. It has a responsibility to get them jobs. It has a responsibility to provide an environment for a secure future, and it has failed on all counts.
—Mr Acting Deputy President—
—Can we interject as much as they interjected on us?

—Certainly. As much as I would like to continue on from Senator Childs and highlight the opposition's hypothetical alternative to Australia's employment arrangements, on the last occasion I addressed the Senate—as it happens, on industrial relations issues—I was accused by Senator Chapman of playing fast and loose with the facts. It was an interesting phrase, given my condition at the time. So it will relieve Senator Knowles that on this occasion I will focus on the details of the government's approach to the problem of unemployment.

PARA.TAB: Under Working Nation, the government is implementing a package of integrated policies which address all aspects of the economy; that is, the government focus is on ongoing, sound macro-economic management and micro-economic reform to achieve its twin objectives of economic and employment growth. This, in the context of low inflation, social cohesion and stable industrial relations, is providing benefits for all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did you get this rubbish from? Who fed you this rubbish?

—I prepare my own speeches, Senator Patterson, as I did the last one, despite what the opposition interjected. The government is addressing the issue of fear, not just fearmongering, as the opposition would accuse us. We are taking real measures, addressing genuine fears of a jobless and skewed recovery. But we still ask: what would the opposition do? And we still hear nothing.

PARA.TAB: The government is quite serious in its obligations to report on how its initiatives and its programs are being developed and also on the effect of their implementation. That is why last month Minister Crean released the report on the first year of the four-year program of Working Nation. Working Nation is a comprehensive set of initiatives, including enhanced skills development and training assistance for both the unemployed and people in the work force. It includes greater labour market program opportunities and intensive personalised case management, especially for jobs compact job seekers and those at risk of becoming long-term unemployed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been a disaster.

—I thought this was what the opposition was asking for. You wanted the details of the programs. Working Nation includes early intervention assistance for at-risk, short-term unemployed. It includes a youth training initiative to ensure that unemployed youth under 18 years of age do not become long-term unemployed, including eligibility for case management at 13 weeks and a labour market program place at 26 weeks of unemployment.

PARA.TAB: Working Nation includes a guaranteed job or other suitable offer for those in the jobs compact and commitments by unemployed people themselves to accept a reasonable offer of employment and training—those people who often the opposition say do not want work, will not work or who are on social security because they can get a free ride on the government. We need to remember that—these Aussie battlers, these people who are getting a free ride on the government, according to the opposition. Working Nation also involves a sharper regional and community focus through area consultative committees and better linking to regional economic development.

Let us look at some of the areas highlighted by Senator Patterson. Let us look at hidden unemployment and underemployment. Senator Childs has already indicated that the government has achieved improvements in the participation rate—that is, more jobs for people. Although there has been some longer term shift to part-time jobs, full-time job growth has been very strong, despite opposition claims, with 223,800 new full-time jobs in the year to June 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will show you something on case management. It came out yesterday. I will let you have a look at it.

—I am waiting, Senator Patterson, for the figures which you say indicate that Working Nation does not work. Let us look at the effect of Working Nation on women—that key group of people who are usually referred to when we are talking about hidden unemployment or underemployment. Working Nation introduced policy measures which have greatly improved women's access to labour market assistance and is reducing the barriers which many women face when seeking work. The most important of these changes are those to the social security system, which embody the principle of the independent entitlement of spouses to income support.Also, there is a recognition of their caring responsibilities. Those spouses, mostly women, who have dependent children are eligible to apply for the new parenting allowance. If these people choose to look for work, they can still register with the CES and, if assessed as being at risk of becoming long-term unemployed, they will receive immediate access to case management and most labour market programs. What programs would the opposition keep in place? They will reduce funding to programs under Working Nation.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the issue of youth unemployment. Working Nation provides better access to entry level training opportunities and early intervention assistance through the youth training initiative. Structured entry level training is essential to assist the transition from school to work for young people. Traineeships, for example, have extremely high success rates in placing young people in worthwhile and sustainable jobs. This will interest Senator Patterson: currently, 88 per cent of all trainees who complete their training are in employment or further education and 85 per cent are in unsubsidised employment three months after completing their traineeships. So they are working.

As a result of the government's commitment to training, there are more young people participating in entry level training than in any of the previous three decades. Working Nation also focuses—and this will interest Senator Knowles—on young people who are homeless or at risk. We are not just talking about young people who want to buy homes but young people who cannot get into homes. The case management arrangements introduced under Working Nation have brought a new deal for unemployed young people.

The integration of the case management arrangements developed under the job placement, education and training pilot program into the youth training initiative and jobs compact provides direct access to expanded resources for assisting unemployed homeless youth into education, training and employment and linking into the mainstream programs, providing options not previously available to young people. Another area highlighted by Senator Patterson was regional unemployment. As I mentioned earlier, one of the key focuses of Working Nation was regional development. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: Today we are discussing yet another one of Labor's failed policies for Australia. We are discussing the matter of public importance raised by Senator Patterson, which is the continued failure of the federal Labor government to address the problems of unemployment, particularly in certain areas.

PARA.TAB: It is often hard to decide just which area of the economy Labor has failed most. Record levels of foreign debt, record interest rates, record current account deficits, record high inflation and record bankruptcies are all hallmarks of the Hawke and Keating Labor administrations. Earlier in the debate today Senator Childs blamed things that happened 13 years ago. For God's sake, when is this Labor government going to look at some of the things that they have done to cripple Australia in the last 13 years?

Senator Jacinta Collins just talked about Working Nation and how it is working. That is the problem. We have about two million people who are not working to their full capacity, who are unemployed or who are underemployed. Senator Childs and Senator Jacinta Collins talked about the Accord, but there have been no sustainable long-term jobs created by this Labor government in the last 13 years.

Perhaps the cruelest failure is the total failure to come to terms with unemployment and to give young rural people an opportunity in life. It is cruel because, with each new budget or policy statement—and we have had 20 or so of those in the last 13 years, and Senator Childs should realise that—there have been promises of another new job scheme and another plan to reduce unemployment. As we all know, despite the rhetoric and the multitude of white papers, green papers and Working Nation statements, is that unemployment is still unacceptably high, as is underemployment.

It is also cruel because more than 50 per cent of those who participate in jobstart training programs remain underemployed or unemployed three months after completing the scheme; some going through the program repeatedly without success. It is cruel also because one in 10 of Australia's children and dependent students are growing up in families directly scarred by unemployment.

We know the rate of unemployment is not the official 8.2 per cent because, in the collection of official statistics, even people who have worked for only one hour a week are counted as employed, for statistical purposes. The real number of Australians seeking work is about two million, including nearly a quarter of a million discouraged job seekers who have given up bothering to register for work; those working a few hours a week but wanting full-time work; and young people who stay at school because of the lack of job opportunities.

For those living in the metropolitan areas, the underemployment and unemployment crisis in rural Australia is perhaps not as well known, but within country towns and on farming properties it is a major crisis and one of bitter frustration for parents and young job seekers alike. It would be a lucky country town that has unemployment of eight per cent, because the average is somewhere close to double that percentage.

The failure of Labor Party policies has impacted heavily on rural Australia because whole towns have closed and services have been removed. Banks, service stations, shops, real estate businesses and chemists—some towns have lost all those services. In some cases that means there is no chance for apprenticeships for young people. The young people have gone to the cities. That is the real indictment on this government—the drain of good young people to the cities.

When we look at the trend of employment in the rural sector, it has fallen from 6.9 per cent of the work force in 1982-83 to below 4.9 per cent today. It has declined every year the Labor government has been in power. Yet this sector is still expected to produce some 33 per cent of our export income, with only about 4.9 per cent of the work force to produce it.

In New South Wales in recent months we have suffered the double Labor whammy, with the Carr government outstripping their federal mates in decimating industry and killing off job prospects. This has happened in the forestry industry, where Mr Carr has admitted that about 50 per cent of direct jobs in the forestry industry in New South Wales will be lost as a result of his government's forest policies. In the Coolah Tops area, near where I live, there will be 26 people lost out of the timber industry, which was the main manufacturing industry in the area. If things go ahead in the Walcha area there will be 229 people who will lose jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —That cuts the heart out of those towns.
—That is right. There will be a thousand jobs lost in the Dungog-Gloucester area, and 300 in the Grafton area.

PARA.TAB: In New South Wales the position with respect to job opportunities for young people in rural areas is desperate. In the Richmond electorate on the north coast of New South Wales—an electorate which has been held by the Labor Party for the last five years but which, I suggest, is not going to be held for much longer by the Labor Party—there is a youth unemployment rate of nearly 29 per cent; 29 per cent of the young people in that area have not got a job. In the central west of New South Wales and across the north and north-west of New South Wales the figure is nearly 33 per cent. How in the heck members of the Keating Labor government can accept that as fair and as giving an opportunity for young people, but still blame somebody for something that might have happened 13 years ago, I do not know.

In a small town like Lithgow, in the central west, there are presently over 1,000 young people on JSA, NSA or training allowances. In Lismore the figure is nearly 4,000. In Murwillumbah there are another 1,500. In Tweed Heads it is nearly 3,000. So the list goes on. Chances are that the great percentage of those people—many of them young people with no work experience—will stay on benefits. Under the current policies of the Keating Labor government they most probably will never get a job.

This government, as with all Labor governments, fails to recognise that to get unemployment down you need to foster the necessary conditions for growth and investment. We need genuine industrial relations and workplace reform. We need to encourage business investment and provide a positive and confident environment in which business can operate. We need to take the monkey off the back of business, with reduced taxation and the removal of other unfair and unnecessary imposts that have been put on the Australian people, put on the Australian work force and put on the unemployed people by the Keating Labor government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: Later I will be seeking leave to have a graph on structural unemployment incorporated in Hansard to help illustrate what I am saying today. This graph shows unemployment has been rising steadily over the last 25 years. There are fluctuations. As the line on the graph shows, we are currently seeing unemployment decline. In spite of this, we see clearly the trend over the last quarter of a century has been that each cycle sees unemployment reach a higher level during recessions and during the maximum employment period. Unemployment is higher than the last such period. The result is a steady increase in unemployment generally from about 1.5 per cent in 1970 to about eight per cent today.

PARA.TAB: The term for this type of rise in base level unemployment is structural unemployment. Structural unemployment is caused by the way industry employs people and by the globalisation of trade which sees more labour intensive industries go to countries where they can get an advantage by exploiting people who cannot get a decent return for their work.

The second area mentioned in this matter of public importance is that of underemployment and hidden unemployment. ABS state that in September 1994 there were 500,000 people officially underemployed, as well as 830,000 officially unemployed. Roughly 60 per cent of the underemployed were women. In other words, we need to add another 60 per cent to the unemployed figure to get the number who are officially looking for work or for more work.

Given that I only have four minutes, I will change direction. Both major parties have been pushing strongly for structural reform in industry and for the so-called efficiency and productivity measures that basically mean job shedding and work intensification. Labor has consistently delivered wage restraint, which means the real value of wages has gone down. The coalition push for what they euphemistically call deregulation of the labour market and competition within the labour market. This generally translates as union busting and slashing of wages and conditions.

Structural unemployment is caused by a failure to distribute the benefits of productivity increases. The benefits of real productivity gains, if distributed, would mean people working fewer hours for the same wage, with products becoming cheaper. Instead, it means companies employ fewer people and increase profits. The higher level of unemployment is then used to bring pressure against workers. False productivity has also been pursued. An example is the use of recorded waiting lines for Telstra. Keeping customers on hold for up to 10 minutes may allow fewer staff to be employed and assure that those staff are constantly responding to calls for their whole shift—it therefore increases profit—but it is not productive or efficient to keep large numbers of customers tied up on hold waiting for a response.Most of those customers could be more constructively engaged if they were not waiting on phones. What is happening here is that time, often paid time, is transferred from the customer's business to Optus or Telstra or an increasing list of businesses that are able to get away with contempt for ordinary people.

Competitive pressure does not seem to address these issues. It makes them worse as companies try to cut costs by shifting them from labour. The presence of Optus has meant that Telstra and Optus compete in staff minimisation. The high unemployment rate is due to the failure of both major parties to deal with basic issues of distribution of benefits of social and technological change. It is a consequence of changing social relations under the development of global capitalism.

In the end, we have to start looking for regional solutions. Whilst this will not immediately create the employment required, we have to start looking at moving away from the direction we are going, which is making us more dependent on the internationalisation and less able to meet our own needs, including the needs of people for a decent wage and conditions. I seek leave to incorporate the graph in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The graph read as follows—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal Sen B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tackling the problem of unemployment has always been a major priority for this government. To say that there has been a failure to address this problem is just not correct. The most effective step that has been taken in creating real jobs is to set economic policies in place that create real and sustainable economic growth.

PARA.TAB: At the end of June this year, Australia increased its quarterly growth rate a further 0.1 per cent. This is an annual economic growth of 3.7 per cent. More importantly, it is the 16th consecutive quarter of economic growth—a record that has not been achieved since 1971.

Economic growth is the cornerstone of creating jobs. Putting it simply: we have been increasing the share of the cake so there is more to go around. Meanwhile, the government has been restricting its own spending in order to keep interest rates down. Total outlays fell 2.5 per cent from last year to 25.1 per cent of GDP. We have achieved a surplus this year, and this surplus is projected to increase over the following years.

This economic environment brought about by our policies and coupled with Working Nation programs, which have been outlined by Senator Collins, has brought about real results. In the 2 1/2 years since the election, this government has created 675,000 new jobs—385,000 of those since Working Nation was put into place. In 1994, the unemployment rate and the number of unemployed fell more than in any other year. Even more importantly, long-term unemployment dropped 23.4 per cent in one year. This is particularly heartening in relation to young people. In the age group 15 to 19 years, long-term unemployment dropped 22.1 per cent, and in the age group 20 to 24 years, long-term unemployment dropped 38.4 per cent.

What this means is that the government is taking this approach: firstly, it is making the total cake bigger, it is growing the economy; secondly, it is taking less of the cake itself, it is showing fiscal responsibility; and, thirdly, it is giving a bigger share of the cake to those in the community who need it most—the unemployed, particularly the long-term unemployed—by providing employment programs through DEET to assist these people in getting back to work.

What is the opposition's position? What is John Howard's position? What is the proposition that is being put by this so-called alternative government? It is this: `We take the cake and give a bigger share to big business and we divide up the balance into smaller shares between the working people of Australia.' What I mean is that the opposition's answer to unemployment is to cut the wages of average Australians. Mr Howard is lying low at the moment, but he has already given a clear indication of his intentions. I refer to a discussion John Howard had with John Laws on 20 October 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nineteen-ninety what?
—Two. John Laws said:

SPEECH.PARA: It gets back to something I have been saying for 15 years and I have always used it as a benchmark in my own negotiations: 80 per cent of something is a whole lot better than 100 per cent of nothing.
HOWARD: Absolutely.
Later, on the same day, on the 7.30 Report, the compere said:
And what if the boss says to me "I'd like you to work 50 hours a week now, at the minimum award hourly rate and if you don't like it there's lots who'll do it. See you later."?
Howard responded:
That becomes a matter of negotiation and you have to make up your mind whether in those circumstances you can get a better deal elsewhere. If you're a good worker you can get a better deal elsewhere.
In other words, you can lose your job if you will not take a wage cut.

PARA.TAB: The wage earners of Australia will have to have their wages carved up. This is how the coalition will create jobs. The opposition will not be able to maintain the fiscal restraint targets that the present government is targeting. Today the opposition announced that they would not sell the federal airports, thereby creating a $2.5 billion hole in the budget. How do they intend to fill that? John Howard said very clearly in his second headland speech that these gaps would be filled. (Time expired)
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—That completes the matter of public importance discussion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the first report of the Select Committee on Certain Aspects of Foreign Ownership Decisions in Relation to the Print Media. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's Response to the Findings and Recommendations of the Reports of the Senate Select Committee on Certain Aspects of Foreign Ownership Decisions in Relation to the Print Media
September 1995
RESPONSES TO MAJORITY FINDINGS AND RECOMMENDATIONS

PARA.EMPHASIS: Finding 3.1: In relation to FIRB contacting Barings after the recommendation of 5 December 1991 had been forwarded to the Treasurer, a number of questions remain:

SPEECH.PARA: Why was such basic information sought after the recommendation had been made to the Treasurer?
Why was such information sought from Barings and not from AIN?
How was FIRB able to compile the Minute of 5 December 1991 if it was not already in possession of such basic information?
Was the information sought to cover up a lack of substantive information on FIRB files?
Did FIRB correct its flawed analysis of AIN's bid and bring that matter to the attention of Treasurer Willis?
These questions remain open and the committee finds this situation adversely reflects on the impartiality of FIRB advice in this case.

Controversy regarding commentary about the newspaper expertise of AIN, which was contained in the December 5 minute, has been canvassed at length by the Committee. However, the Committee has failed to recognise that as an Australian entity AIN was not an applicant for foreign investment approval. Accordingly, that information was not of any consequence in determining the "contrary to national interest" test in respect of the two foreign investment proposals covered by the minute. Those foreign investment proposals, from Tourang and the O'Reilly Group, were dealt with on their individual merits.

It is not Government policy to deal with foreign investment proposals with a view to eliminating competition for Australian bidders. To have done so in the Fairfax case could well have resulted in the Australian sellers receiving less than a fair value for the asset. That would have amounted to favouring one group of Australians, the buyers, over another group of Australians, the sellers, in a commercial transaction.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The treatment of the AIN offer in the FIRB Minute of 5 December 1991 and the recommendation made by FIRB were fundamentally flawed and resulted in the advice put before the Treasurer being incomplete and misleading. Further, a reading of the FIRB minute suggests that there was no practical alternative to foreign control of Fairfax.

SPEECH.PARA: Response

The Committee has failed to recognise that the Government decision not to raise objections to a specific proposal as "contrary to the national interest" does not amount to a decision on the ultimate disposal of the asset. The question of who would be the new owner of Fairfax was a matter to be determined by the Fairfax receiver, not the Government.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee finds that the FIRB processes in the 1991 Fairfax decisions were defective and that the processes by which FIRB conducts its investigations and enforces its conditions must be rectified to achieve greater transparency and fairness to interested parties. This is a matter which is taken up again at chapters 7-10. The Committee believes that there needs, at least, to be some `signposts' to which FIRB, or some similar body, can refer in making indicative decisions and recommendations on the national interest.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a pre-existing body of precedents which is published from time to time in "Australia's Foreign Investment Policy: A Guide for Investors". In addition the Government issues press releases on specific decisions and the Foreign Investment Review Board publishes an annual report which sets out significant decisions taken during the year.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee has considered the conflict of evidence between the aforementioned players (Messrs Hawke, Black, Kerin and Kennedy) regarding government commitments on foreign ownership levels. The Committee has noted the following points:

SPEECH.PARA: The reports of the Caucus debate and decision on foreign ownership and media concentration that took place between the meeting in July 1991 and the Treasurer's decision on 5 December 1991;
The independent recollection of Mr Kennedy; and
The date and the contents of the press quotation above.

In view of the fact that Tourang structured its initial bid to accord with a 35 per cent limit, and the independent evidence of Mr Kennedy, the Committee accepts that Mr Black was given a positive indication that up to 35 per cent foreign ownership could be countenanced.

The Caucus decision provided no indication that 35 per cent foreign ownership of the Fairfax group would be "countenanced". The first Tourang proposal included an aggregate level of foreign economic interest of 40 per cent, some 15 per cent higher than the approved O'Reilly proposal. When the second Tourang proposal reduced the aggregate level of foreign economic interest to 25 per cent it was approved.

PARA.TAB: i)the criteria Mr Kerin advised that he would use in considering foreign investment applications for Fairfax;

SPEECH.PARA: ii)his evidence of what he actually did take into account;
iii)the arguments and recommendations put before him by FIRB (particularly the comments adverse to AIN);
iv)the decision that he took, particularly its timing, to approve O'Reilly and reject Tourang (purportedly so as not to disadvantage Tourang by delay); and
v)that in doing so he acted contrary to the Caucus decision in regard to both the treatment of foreign non-voting equity and the extension of foreign control of the Fairfax company;

The Committee rejects Mr Kerin's assertion that in approving O'Reilly and rejecting Tourang he was not effectively bequeathing Fairfax to the O'Reilly group. The Committee finds that the decision was discriminatory, based on incorrect and misleading advice and was deliberately intended to obtain an outcome in the interests of the government and not the national interest as required by the FATA.

Mr Kerin's rejection of the original Tourang bid has not had the effect of "bequeathing Fairfax to the O'Reilly group". No objection was raised to the second Tourang proposal which had a similar aggregate level of foreign economic interest. The Committee is therefore in error in finding that the Government discriminated against the Tourang proposal.

PARA.EMPHASIS: From the foregoing, the Committee concludes that the current procedures for consideration of foreign investment applications are defective and may be, in fact, a deterrent to investment.

SPEECH.PARA: The current procedures are not defective, nor on any objective criteria could they have been shown to have been a deterrent to investment which is in the national interest.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Despite numerous invitations to do so, Mr Willis chose not to attempt to justify his actions or to advance any legal advice to support his repeated non-cooperation with the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee condemns the action of Mr Willis in directing his officials not to cooperate with the inquiry in providing certain critical evidence. The committee finds that Mr Willis has acted contrary to the public interest in not assisting this parliamentary inquiry.

The directions given to officials in regard to their dealings with the Committee were consistent with established principles relating to the provision of confidential advice to government and the protection of confidential commercial information by applicants or other parties who make submissions or are consulted in the course of deliberations.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Given the totality of Mr Black's and Mr Keating's explanations, the Committee finds that Mr Keating did complain to Mr Black of unfavourable and, as he regarded them, gratuitous, comments by Fairfax reporters and that Mr Black's public response was to characterise these complaints as concerns about the separation of reporting from editorial comment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee does not accept Mr Keating's explanation to the media that he was trying to protect the rights of Fairfax employees `to write and have printed that which they believe and not have proprietorial intervention'. On the contrary, all his actions suggest he was more interested in using the unique leverage of his position to influence the political coverage of the Fairfax press in his favour in the lead-up to the 1993 election.

There is no basis for the finding that the Prime Minister was using his position to influence political coverage by the Fairfax press in the lead-up to the 1993 election. The Prime Minister's and Mr Black's remarks indicate that he was supporting among other things the rights of the Fairfax employees "to write and have printed that which they believe and not have proprietorial intervention".

PARA.EMPHASIS: Despite ample opportunities in the Parliament and elsewhere to do so, Mr Keating has never resiled from his remarks made in Seattle, where he said he had told Mr Black:

SPEECH.PARA: '. . . we want a commitment from you that the paper will be balanced. And if there is any notion that, you know, of bias, that is that you barrack for the coalition, on the basis of your conservative proclivities in other places, then there's no way you would qualify as the kind of owner we would like.'

In the light of those remarks and the other evidence mentioned here, the Committee finds that Mr Keating attempted to influence Mr Black regarding the political coverage of the Fairfax newspapers for the 1993 general election.

There is no basis for the Committee's findings that the Prime Minister had attempted to influence Mr Black regarding the political coverage of the Fairfax newspapers for the 1993 general election. The Prime Minister's remarks in Seattle indicate a desire for balanced coverage and for an absence of bias. That statement is entirely consistent with the Prime Minister's support for editorial independence and opposition to proprietorial intervention.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Since his acquisition of the Fairfax group, Mr Black has made executive appointments of persons who were sympathetic to his political and commercial concerns. By warning Fairfax senior management that the proprietor was on probation Mr Keating did his best to ensure that he would receive a more sympathetic hearing at Fairfax than had previously been the case.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee finds that Mr Keating attempted to exert pressure at Fairfax for favourable election coverage by making a linkage between `balance' in election coverage and an increased ownership limit for Mr Black.

There is no basis for the Committee's finding that the Prime Minister had attempted to exert pressure at Fairfax for favourable election coverage by a linkage between "balance" in election coverage and an increased ownership limit for Mr Black. If there were any validity in the Committee's findings that Mr Black has made executive appointments of persons sympathetic to his political concerns it would confirm the appropriateness of the Prime Minister's comments to Mr Black supporting editorial independence and opposing proprietorial intervention.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee rejects Mr Keating's claim to the Parliament that he took into account national interest considerations when deciding on the ownership of Fairfax.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has no evidence to suggest that changes in the ownership limits of Fairfax were contrary to the national interest.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee finds that Mr Keating's request of a

newspaper proprietor to provide `balanced coverage' is at odds with the whole history of media regulation and the overwhelming trend of democratic governments throughout the years, which has been to protect the diversity and plurality of the print media as a whole.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister's views about the importance of balanced coverage, his support for editorial independence and his opposition to proprietorial intervention apply to all newspaper groups.

PARA.EMPHASIS: For Mr Keating to have set himself up personally as the judge of bias and the arbiter of the kind and extent of freedom which Mr Black should give to his employees is plainly not at all the same as a government enforcing an open and well understood charter of independence. The Committee finds that it was improper for Mr Keating to set himself up in this role, holding power as he did over Mr Black's increased ownership.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister has never "set himself up personally as the judge of bias and the arbiter of the kind and extent of freedom which Mr Black should give his employees". Nor does the Government enforce "an open and well understood charter of independence". The Prime Minister has the same democratic right as any other Australian to express views on the performance of the media, as the media has a democratic right to express views on the performance of persons in public life. The Committee's findings that there is any impropriety in the Prime Minister exercising that right is rejected.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that, in the context of the APN submission to the Senate Print Media Committee, the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure inquire into and report on the merits of distinguishing between provincial newspapers and major capital city daily newspapers in deciding levels of foreign ownership.

SPEECH.PARA: Submissions on this subject have been made to the Committee by private interests and the Dissenting Report has made a finding upon it.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, as part of its reference on telecommunications developments (24 March 1994) should consider the regulatory issues of convergence of media technologies, especially as they relate to the preservation of diversity.

SPEECH.PARA: Through the work of the Broadband Services Expert Group and the 1997 Telecommunications Review the Government has considered the regulatory issues of convergence, including how they relate to the preservation of diversity. This work is continuing through the Government's national strategy for the adoption of new information and communication technologies, including the Prime Minister's high level expert group, the National Information Services Council, and regulatory action as appropriate will be taken. In light of this ongoing activity the Government does not consider that a reference to a Senate Committee is a priority.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which is examining codes of conduct for journalists, examine the issue of the enforceability of guarantees of independence as part of government regulation of the media.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has no intention of regulating for editorial independence in the Australian media and will not refer the matter of government regulation of the media to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Government prepare amendments to the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act and the Broadcasting Services Act which will ensure that limits on foreign ownership cover both economic (non-voting) and voting interests.

SPEECH.PARA: On 3 May 1995 the Government announced an Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) inquiry to focus on, inter alia, the current foreign ownership limits in the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 (BSA) and whether consideration should be given to imposing an upper limit on so-called "economic interests" for investments through the use of "quasi-equity" financing arrangements in the television sector.
The Government announced on 27 June 1995:
(a)a 15 per cent ownership limit on all the control provisions in the BSA, including limits on cross media interests, the 75 per cent population reach rule, and the one licence to a market rule;

(b)the definition of "company interests" in the BSA be amended to include performance-linked and voting-related instruments. This will also apply to future foreign interests in free to air broadcasters. The ABA is to be given power to determine which kinds of interests are performance-linked and voting-related instruments, and that such determinations be made disallowable instruments;

(c)the BSA be amended to provide scope for existing interests to be grandfathered in the event that the ABA's determination of the kinds of interests falling under the definition of company interests has the effect of placing such existing interests in breach of the BSA;

(d)the higher foreign ownership limits for subscription television broadcasting licences in s.109 of the BSA be retained and that this section (and, if necessary, other provisions in Division 3 of Part 7 of the BSA) be quarantined from any expanded definition of company interests for the reasons outlined in the ABA Report (page 25);
(e)Certain consequential amendments be made to the BSA in relation to the aggregation of the interests of a person and associates when calculating upper limits:-
(i)to match more closely a person's power to appoint directors to the new ownership limits;
(ii)to allow licensees A and B to co-operate without breaching the control provisions of the BSA;
(iii)to amend the tracing provisions and relevant definitions to simplify the process of determining who is a "foreign person" and the tracing of foreign interests;
(f)The amendments commence from 27 June 1995. The proposed amendments are expected to be introduced for parliamentary consideration during the next parliamentary session.

Action is available to the Treasurer under the FATA to prohibit certain acquisitions of Australian businesses where the Treasurer is satisfied that control would change, either becoming foreign or becoming controlled by a new foreign interest, and that this would be contrary to the national interest. In determining whether a person has a controlling interest in a corporation both voting and non-voting interests may be taken into consideration.

Non-voting equity in the media sector was used primarily to avoid the provisions of the BSA not the FATA. The subsequent proposed changes to the BSA will be given effect to as appropriate in the application of the FATA and foreign investment policy generally.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the government introduce legislation in the Parliament to amend Australia's foreign investment laws in accordance with the recommendations of this report.

SPEECH.PARA: No legislation is required to implement the Government's response to the report.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the government incorporate all components of its foreign investment policy into a single statute.

SPEECH.PARA: Response
It would be cumbersome to incorporate elements of Acts which are administered by other portfolio Ministers under the FATA.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the legislation include a comprehensive statement of the goals of foreign investment policy and identify those sectors of the economy which should be subject to foreign investment regulations.

SPEECH.PARA: Response

The Government's booklet `Australia's Foreign Investment Policy—a Guide for Investors' provides a clear statement of goals and objectives and identifies broad policy criteria for all industry sectors. These are used in the application of "not contrary to the national interest test"

It would be unduly restrictive to attempt to incorporate these `Guidelines' into legislation. It is impossible to have a sensibly based set of prescriptions defining the national interest that could have universal application.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the legislation contain the criteria which should be used to determine applications by foreign investors and that it should also provide, where appropriate, that the interests of domestic bidders be taken into account.

SPEECH.PARA: Response

Policy is currently set down in guidelines which are published from time to time in `Australia's Foreign Investment Policy—a Guide for Investors'. The Treasurer also issues press releases on some approvals and rejections and the Foreign Investment Review Board publishes an annual report which sets out details of significant cases during the year.

The implementation of legislative criteria would unnecessarily limit the range of issues which could be considered under the national interest criteria. Over a long period of time there are changes in the treatment of issues under the contrary to the national interest test and legislated criteria would inhibit new issues being taken into account as they arise.
Domestic interests are not restricted from bidding for Australian assets. Foreign investment policy processes determine which foreign interests may also bid.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the legislation to reform foreign investment rules reflect a realistic and appropriate range of sanctions to remedy possible breaches, and that there be a duty on the part of the administering body to monitor and enforce compliance.

SPEECH.PARA: Response

The Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975 already incorporates a range of sanctions for non compliance (eg, fines, prison sentences and divestiture powers). Section 25 provides the Government with powers to enforce conditions and for penalties for failing to comply with those conditions. Sections 26 and 26a provide for compulsory notification of proposals and penalties for failure to notify.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the legislation include procedures that the regulatory body should adopt to consult with applicants and other interested parties preparatory to it exercising any administrative discretions conferred by the statute.

SPEECH.PARA: There is already considerable dialogue between foreign investors and the Foreign Investment Review Board secretariat, both prior to making a foreign investment application and after one has been lodged. Other interested parties may also make submissions to the Government on the national interest issues arising out of a foreign investment proposal and they are fully taken into account in the examination process.

Foreign investment cases, by their very nature, vary considerably in the degree of complexity and the issues they raise. The examination process, including the nature and scope of consultations, needs to be on a case by case basis to cope with the variety of issues raised. It is important that the consultative process continue to protect commercial-in-confidence information and that it does not add unnecessarily to the time required to process applications.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the legislation provide that all applications and accompanying documentation would be accessible to the public after 12 months unless the affected party was able to demonstrate that the public interest required that such material to be kept confidential.

SPEECH.PARA: Response

Information on some proposals is already publicly available—for example, public offers on the stock market. Information can also be obtained through FOI requests where the parties have agreed to the release of the requested information that they had provided.

There are substantial concerns with releasing information beyond this. There is the established principle of "confidential advice to government". Much information is provided and received in confidence. Domestic companies do not have to disclose information beyond what is required by the corporations law. There are also privacy concerns, particularly in relation to the business dealings of temporary residents in Australia (some of whom will eventually become permanent residents) and the spouses of Australian citizens.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the new statute contain provisions establishing an independent statutory authority to be known as the Foreign Investment Commission (FIC) which will replace the non-statutory FIRB.

SPEECH.PARA: Response

The Foreign Investment Review Board provides an additional source of advice to Government and makes recommendations, it is not a regulatory body and nothing positive would be achieved by making it a statutory body.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the legislation establish the FIC as a regulator, as opposed to an `application processor'.

SPEECH.PARA: Response
A statutory authority as regulator is likely to create adverse perceptions about the environment for international investment in Australia.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That FIC be empowered to make binding decisions in respect of certain categories of applications, applying the tests established under the Act and that the Treasurer, on FIC's recommendations, make decisions in respect of more significant applications, for example, those in key sectors. These decisions would be made according to the national interest and would be accompanied by a statement of reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: Routine decisions which do not raise issues that could unsettle established policy are already delegated to officials in line with normal efficient administrative practice. There would be considerable difficulty in attempting to legislate to define significant applications requiring ministerial discretion. In any event, defining those issues in legislation would do nothing to diminish the controversy which may be associated with them.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That for those categories of decisions to be made by the Treasurer, FIC prepare briefing material and recommendations and that this material be published prior to its dispatch to the Treasurer.

SPEECH.PARA: Response

Currently, FIRB minutes are confidential to the Government. If details of proposals and FIRB recommendations were published it would certainly breach commercial confidentiality, whether the publication was prior to or after any decision by the Treasurer.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That FIC maintain a public register of all foreign investment proposals and decisions and that the register of proposals and decisions for each financial year be included in the FIC report which would be tabled annually in Parliament. The register would be limited to providing details of the receipt and status of applications.

SPEECH.PARA: The Foreign Investment Review Board publishes detailed statistics, with general discussion of the major cases in each industry sector, in its annual report. The Government's decision to introduce FIRB Quarterly Monitors will extend the information available.

PARA.EMPHASIS: It is essential that in protecting the interests of all parties, any review process be both speedy and effective. It is therefore recommended that the legislation provide that decisions of FIC be subject to the processes of administrative law review.

SPEECH.PARA: Response

Expeditious and effective decision making is fundamental to the operation of the Government's foreign investment regime. Applicants are usually involved in commercial transactions in which decisions are acted upon without delay.

Decisions taken under the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975 are not judicially reviewable under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, nor can foreign investment decisions be appealed to the AAT.
To subject foreign investment decisions to such processes could undermine the commercial responsiveness of the policy with adverse implication for the investment environment.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the legislation require FIC to prepare an ongoing communications strategy. This would be included in its annual report to Parliament and comprehensively address the information needs of both potential and foreign investors and the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: The Foreign Investment Review Board secretariat already devotes considerable resources to disseminating information to both potential foreign investors and the Australian community.
RESPONSES TO DISSENTING REPORT'S RECOMMENDATIONS AND FINDING

PARA.EMPHASIS: : That FIRB processes be restructured to permit a more open and consultative process which will ensure that FIRB has access to a range of expertise and community input on the merits of projects relative to the national interest.

SPEECH.PARA: Response
A wider consultative process that continues to protect commercial in confidence information and that does not add inappropriately to the processing time of applications will be implemented.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That FIRB develop a comprehensive system of notification which involves the publication of significant decisions, the publication of reasons for these decisions and the publication of conditions applicable to approved proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: Response
An expanded reporting system will be implemented.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That FIRB develop a comprehensive community and investment client reporting strategy designed to engender certainty and confidence in Australia's foreign investment policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Response
See comment on recommendation No 2.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That FIRB develop a plan of action to ensure that it monitors progress on those projects for which have been given approval subject to special conditions. Breaches of FIRB decisions should be the subject of appropriate FIRB action as provided for in FATA.

SPEECH.PARA: Response
An expanded monitoring system will be implemented with the objective of ensuring wider compliance.

PARA.EMPHASIS: There is a need to re-examine foreign ownership limits and cross-media regulations for the print media as they relate to impact on regional newspapers, where it may be desirable to allow some liberalisation

SPEECH.PARA: Response
The Government has decided to increase the foreign ownership limit for provincial or suburban newspapers from 30 per cent to less than 50 per cent for non-portfolio shareholdings.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to say a few words about the government's response to the report of the Senate Select Committee on Certain Aspects of Foreign Ownership Decisions in Relation to the Print Media. When I read the government's response this morning, it brought back some memories about just how politically charged and contentious this print media inquiry was.

PARA.TAB: I remind the Senate that this was an inquiry that cost some $150,000 of taxpayers' money. It lasted for six months and the sole purpose of that inquiry was to attack the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), to draw inferences about alleged impropriety—but, of course, no evidence existed of such—and to provide a platform for certain senators to gain media exposure which they otherwise would not get. Of course, today we have the same sorts of strategies revisited in terms of the foreign debt and we see the same sorts of populist sentiments attempted to be whipped up.

At the time, Labor senators took the view that the appropriate committee to evaluate the operations of the Foreign Investment Review Board was the Senate Finance and Public Administration Committee. I maintain that that was the correct view at the time, and that is the case today.

Instead, we saw a committee which operated in a highly political manner. It was very biased and, in fact, its proceedings were, I think, fairly described as outrageous. We saw a chair who sought to prejudice the inquiry from the very start. We saw a chair who sought to influence the editor of the Age to give balanced coverage to John Hewson. We saw Liberal senators leak reports and recommendations to the media before they were addressed by the committee and we saw totally biased views expressed in terms of unauthorised press releases.
