Perhaps more disturbingly, we saw a process which enabled the opposition to harness the powers of the Senate to run a vindictive, amoral and malicious campaign to undermine the integrity of many people within this country. We saw a long list of people, including public servants, government ministers, and ordinary Australians, who were abused, assaulted and threatened through this committee, people such as the Prime Minister, Willis, Dawkins, Hawke, Kerin, Pooley, Hinton and Roberts to name just a few. We saw the outrageous attacks upon the civil liberties of those citizens. In my view, this demonstrated the grave dangers posed by the Senate committee itself when it was used in this way. This went to the very heart of fundamental democratic principles which I think we ought to be upholding in the Senate, which we did not do through this committee.

We saw further interference in civil legal proceedings through various lines of questioning, germane to the litigation which was under way throughout the proceedings of this committee. We saw the threats of punitive action being taken against witnesses who would not give the answers that some senators on this committee thought they ought to. We saw the threats of gaol to public servants. We saw the suppression of legal advice obtained by the committee. We saw the denigration of citizens' reputations through the work of this committee.

It strikes me that, in terms of the majority report which the government has responded to, there was complete disregard for the evidence and it predictably came out with views which were prejudged from the beginning and which were critical of the government. There was no evidence of any deal between the Prime Minister and Conrad Black. There was no evidence to support the alleged impropriety of officers of the Foreign Investment Review Board. It was very interesting to note the way in which the opposition sought to use this inquiry to maintain a position on foreign investment which is completely contrary to its own position up until that time. We saw gross political opportunism.
I remind the Senate that the present Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, said in 1986:

SPEECH.PARA: The time has come for Australians to abandon totally all foreign investment restrictions and to abolish the Foreign Investment Review Board.

We saw at the time of the Fairfax sale the present spokesman for the opposition on media matters support Conrad Black's takeover and do so publicly. We saw the present Liberal policy summed up by John Howard when he said in the House of Representatives in 1989:
We will live to regret the day we were equivocal about foreign investment, because those investors will go to other parts of the world and increasingly they're starting to do that.
He said:

I hope that members of this place will in future go out into the community and argue the case for foreign investment, even though it is not popular in some sections of the community, and show a bit of courage, a bit of leadership, and persuade those people in the community that their sentiments on whatever those sentiments are based, are sentiments that if implemented in terms of policy, would do this country very real and very lasting damage.
Finally, in summarising his position, in his view, he was an `unrepentant internationalist'.

PARA.TAB: I think that is essentially what the Liberal Party policy is today, but we would not know that formally from any stated position other than that which is dripped out of various letters and the like. I recall back in April 1994 Mr Downer said he would be announcing the coalition's policy soon after the Senate inquiry released its final report on the takeover of the Fairfax newspaper group. We are still waiting.

That was a view echoed by the Liberal leader at that time. We saw in the majority report a whole series of recommendations which were designed to ensure that the Democrats came together with the opposition to bolster its position on that committee. No sooner had that report been handed down in the Senate than Senator Richard Alston made it very clear at a press conference that as far as he was concerned the print media report did not bind Liberal Party policy. He said that this report's recommendations did not bind the coalition party room—a similar position, I might say, to the one that was taken in regard to the ABC committee.

In terms of the government's response, it is very good to see that the government has responded to the minority report in the manner that it has. It is pleasing to note that there have been significant changes in terms of the operations of the Foreign Investment Review Board. I think we will see a much clearer view expressed in terms of its operation which will, in my judgment, lead to a very big improvement.

The government has moved to introduce a more proactive consultation process in the examination of foreign investment proposals in regard to advertisements to be placed in major newspapers and invitations for public comment. The public comment will be taken into account in assessing applications. The government has also moved to implement a more forthcoming announcement system in regard to press releases on all major approvals and rejections and orders under the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act.

There will be more frequent reporting on the issuing of FIRB quarterly monitors, which will highlight emerging trends and provide valuable statistical information. Perhaps equally importantly the government will expand a monitoring system to ensure wider compliance of FIRB actions and decisions. These reforms are welcome.

The government will also address issues of greater flexibility for regional newspapers as recommended in the minority report. In my judgment, these will improve the level of media diversity in provincial Australia. It is a very simple proposition that where there is only one newspaper there is only one view. I take the view that there ought to be much higher levels of diversity and media ownership in this country.

These measures come on top of a whole raft of proposals that the government has introduced to basically improve the level of diversity and to promote, at the same time, a viable media industry within this country. On 27 June a range of measures were announced to tighten the cross-media ownership regime in this country. I could go through the detail but time is against me.

In essence, what I think needs to be analysed in this discussion is exactly what is the coalition's policy. We do not have any clear statement other than its view that there should be open slather for foreign investment, other than that there should be effectively a regime which would allow the resources of this country to be carted off by the truck load, other than an opportunity for its friends to essentially take control of the media in the country in a way which would prevent diversity and which would lead to an undermining of our national culture and our national interest.

I ask again: what is the coalition policy? When will we see it? We have been promised it again and again. What are they frightened of? Why don't they come forward? One can only presume that they have something to hide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following that farrago of nonsense, I would like to come back to the facts in relation to this government response. The response is to a Senate inquiry that was established in December 1993 in response to considerable community concern about Mr Conrad Black's description in his autobiography of a deal with Mr Keating to allow Mr Black to increase his investment in Fairfax if his political coverage of the 1993 election was `balanced'.

PARA.TAB: It was also in response to Mr Keating's public comments on the record which supported the notion of a deal with Mr Black. It was also in response to considerable concern about the Foreign Investment Review Board processes leading up to the Fairfax decisions made in 1991 and 1993. So there was very considerable basis for having the print media inquiry which this Senate conducted.

What the government did was exercise its utmost energy in disrupting the inquiry, frustrating the inquiry and intimidating senators on the committee. Despite all that, the Senate committee was able to present its report in June 1994. What that report did was expose Mr Keating's attempt to blackmail Mr Black over his ownership of the Fairfax newspapers. Of course that stood up to all attempts by the Labor Party to deny that. It rang true with everything we know about Mr Keating and his hatred of the Fairfax newspapers—a hatred which continues today and which was so gross that it brought him into the chamber the other day to complain about the Sydney Morning Herald's article in relation to his sensitivity about his bald spot.

The report also found that Mr Keating did attempt to influence Mr Black regarding the political coverage of the Fairfax newspapers for the 1993 election. Now, 15 months later, 12 months after the due date for responses to Senate reports, we receive this government response. I have to say it can only be described as a pathetic response. It is grossly inadequate. Frankly, it ignores all the major issues raised by the Senate report. My colleagues Senator Alston and Senator Ellison, who were with me on this inquiry, will be responding in some detail to this government's response when they have an opportunity to speak tomorrow.

I want to remind the Senate that the print media inquiry committee's report exposed the unacceptable way in which our very loose foreign investment guidelines can be manipulated for partisan political ends. Those partisan political ends, in this case, clearly had nothing to do with the national interest, which is what should drive foreign investment decisions of this kind. I want to refer to independent evidence of that.

Mr David Bowman, a writer for the Adelaide Review newspaper, who concentrates on media issues, wrote some very interesting articles about this whole matter. At the time of our report he said the following about our committee:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the committee had enough witnesses and enough evidence available from the public record to be able to produce a valuable report, lucid, closely reasoned, damning of some individuals and their actions, and proposing reforms in the foreign investment procedures to make it more difficult for governments to misuse the processes for their own political advantage when the national interest was supposed to be their overriding consideration. The evidence against the Prime Minister was more than enough to justify the conclusion that he tried improperly to influence Fairfax newspapers by holding out to Conrad Black the prospect of increased investment.
That is an independent commentator in an independent newspaper in Adelaide saying those things—not me, not anyone else.

PARA.TAB: Without labouring that point, I note that the report made recommendations—sensible recommendations—to clean up foreign investment policy in this country to ensure that no Prime Minister of whatever colour or of whatever party could in future be in a position to seek to influence a media proprietor in the manner in which Mr Keating sought to influence Mr Black in relation to the ownership of Fairfax. It must be said that even the Labor members of the committee, including Senator Carr, acknowledged the need for a much more open, independent, transparent and accountable approach to the regulation of foreign investment.

I would have thought that Senator Carr would admit that the government's response to the Labor members' recommendations is mealy-mouthed, vague, very qualified and very begrudging. I would have thought that Senator Carr could admit that they are unhappy with the government's very inadequate response to their recommendations.

One of the significant recommendations in this report was to establish an independent statutory authority—a foreign investment commission—to replace the non-statutory Foreign Investment Review Board. The coalition members on that committee unanimously supported that proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that Liberal policy?

—We are not authorised to make coalition policy. As in your party the caucus makes the policy, our policy is made in the party room. But coalition members, a number of them senior, strongly supported the recommendation for the establishment of a foreign investment commission to replace the non-statutory FIRB. I place on record my hope that that will be coalition policy when we go to the next election. When you call the election, Senator Carr, we will announce our policy.

PARA.TAB: It was originally envisaged that the FIRB would be a statutory authority. I took the trouble to pull out the statement made by the then Treasurer, Phillip Lynch, in establishing the FIRB. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Initially we will establish the board by administrative action. It is proposed that it be given a statutory basis as soon as possible.

I must express my disappointment that the former Fraser government was a little lax in not setting it up as a statutory authority. That statement was made in 1976. Unfortunately, the government was defeated in 1983, just before it was about to make it a statutory authority. I am sure it would have been their first action following the 1983 election had they had the opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your nose is growing, Nick!

—It has not happened in the 12 years that Labor has been in office and I would be interested to know if it was the policy of the then Labor opposition. It probably was but now it is much more convenient to leave things as they are.

PARA.TAB: As our report says, it is time that the original intention for the board was put in place—that it be made a statutory body. It was very clear to us—the Australian Democrats, the coalition and, I think, the Labor members—that the current FIRB status and practice is quite inadequate for the management of foreign investment in this country. There is a clear need for an independent foreign investment commission to act as a regulator not merely a processor of applications. The government's response to this particular recommendation is really quite contemptuous. All they have to say is this:

SPEECH.PARA: The Foreign Investment Review Board provides an additional source of advice to Government and makes recommendations. It is not a regulatory body and nothing positive would be achieved by making it a statutory body.
All that does is state the current position without arguing the case whatsoever. They then say:
A statutory authority as regulator is likely to create adverse perceptions about the environment for international investment in Australia.
That really is bureaucratese. I cannot believe that anyone in the Labor Party really believes it.

PARA.TAB: I think the government is dead wrong. I think an independent statutory foreign investment commission would actually improve perceptions about the environment for international investment in Australia. It would mean that there would be greater certainty about the foreign investment rules and guidelines. There would be much less likelihood of partisan manipulation by one side of politics or the other. There would be much greater openness about the foreign investment process. There would be more effective regulation once conditions were laid down for foreign investment—because, as Senator Carr would have to admit, at the moment there is absolutely no regulation of the commitments that foreign investors make as part of their approvals. Obviously, there also would be greater independence of the process.

From our point of view, the government's rejection of the report's recommendations on cleaning up foreign investment policy confirms Labor's determination to maintain what is a very secretive process and, therefore, one which is able to be manipulated for partisan purposes.

The government's response will do nothing to enhance community confidence in the foreign investment processes. Unfortunately, from our point of view, it is typical of a government which has politicised so many aspects of our society to suit Labor's partisan interest, foreign investment is one of the areas that is increasingly politicised, and it is further evidence that the government has been in office much too long—it is well past its use-by date—and we express our gross disappointment with its inadequate response to this important report.
Debate (on motion by Senator Panizza) adjourned.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—On behalf of the Deputy President, I present the 23rd report of the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing, together with a document titled `Senate Committee Office: Review of Resources'.
Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 15th report of 1995 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I also lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 14 of 1995 dated 27 September 1995.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.
Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the amendment moved by Senator Vanstone. The question is that the amendment be agreed to. (Quorum formed)

—There will be a number of people speaking on this issue tomorrow, and I really feel there are a number of points that need to be clarified. If I could mention some of our concerns and then ask some specific questions, that would be helpful.

PARA.TAB: It seems that the requirement that a proprietary business must have a throughput of $10 million per annum, or 50 employees or assets in excess of $5 million, would ensure that small businesses and most medium businesses are excluded. I note that even a relatively large variety grocery store such as the Foodland or the Four Square type stores would not have volumes of this level—a group of those stores might, however—nor would they have that many staff in one place.

The industries that might be most affected are low volume, high value businesses. They also include high value technical industries. They are likely to have few staff and relatively few creditors. They would possibly be eligible for a discretionary exemption. I guess part of the question is: what kind of guidance will there be for the discretionary exemption? That seems to be a great deal of the concern that was mentioned to me, perhaps for an hour, over the phone last night from one of the callers who spoke to me about how a discretionary exemption might be administered. How would one company know that the kind of exemption that was available to a similar company would also be available to them? Do they have to fight their case all over again, and so on?

In the case of a large volume, low profit margin company, this seems to be a very major point of concern. Whilst I can understand that there is more likelihood of an exemption being available to low volume, high value businesses—such as machinery companies or companies selling trucks or tractors and so on—they also, ironically, would probably have the lower end of the auditing cost because the sheer volume, or lack of volume, of sales would make it easier to check the books, whereas it is the large volume, low profit margin companies which would probably suffer most from such an audit in terms of the actual cost to their business. If they were on, say, a two per cent margin and if the type of business were, like in Canberra, a chain of three hardware stores or so on, then the actual impost on them to check back on all of the items they sell would be huge.

Would they be likely to qualify for an exemption because of the cost? What are the likely benefits that would be expected from that kind of check? Could the minister provide some examples of private companies suffering financial difficulties which have affected either creditors or employees where the minister feels that the changes under this bill would have improved this position? We need to find out whether there are any instances where having the audit done may, in fact, be of benefit to the company. How do you work out this cost and benefit balance?

We can understand that exemptions may well be available to those people whose audit costs might be lowest. Exemptions might be a lot more difficult for those companies with a high volume and low profit whose costs would be highest. The problem with the costs is that we are given to understand that, because of changes to federal law, the audit costs are higher because it is extremely difficult for auditors to get liability insurance. Therefore, sometimes costs have gone up threefold to provide an audit.

What is the government going to put on the record here as to what it might do to mitigate the increased cost of an audit which has actually resulted—I am not saying it is a bad thing that auditors should be responsible for the outcome of their audits—from the government's change of legislation, which makes it extremely difficult for auditors to gain liability insurance? We have been told that sometimes three times the cost or more on audits have been hiked up because of these changes. I will throw out those questions now and, if there are other questions that need clarifying later, I will ask them following the minister's response.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Margetts for raising these issues. I appreciate that they are issues that might cause concern to some, and it is useful to get the opportunity to put them on the record.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the criteria the Australian Securities Commission would have in determining whether the audit requirements would impose an unreasonable burden, they are specified in our third amendment, which will be scheduled. I will not read them because it will unduly take the time of the chamber. That is the first point. I realise it does not cover all of the points, but that is the first point.

The second point is that I am advised with regard to these matters that it is the intention of the Securities Commission to put out class orders for public discussion so that people can assess the manner in which this matter is going to be handled. Of course, with regard to each individual company, the ASC's discretion is subject to AAT review, so there is some process of ensuring that it is not unfairly applied in a particular circumstance.

With regard to your audit costs question, there are really two points I want to make. The first is that it is true that there are some questions of audit indemnity that have been made more stringent, and some of that dates back to an earlier review of the Corporations Law with which I was involved. I got the impression that you perhaps shared that view that they are changes that were worth while. They do have some cost, but I think that is a cost that has a sufficient community benefit to warrant it.

I now turn to Senator Margetts's question about the high volume and low profit margin hardware store retailer. I am advised that it tends to be the case that, in relation to the audit procedures—and this is consistent with the general audit principles that were applied to various companies that I was involved with in a previous life—involving large volume and low profit processes, provided the processes and procedures of the company concerned are adequate, auditors would always take a sample of transactions to assess. Normally it would be a very small sample, say one per cent, because they would have confidence that taking that sample with a company with good procedures would give them a sufficient level of confidence to conduct their audit.

That is the procedure that has been operated. It is not specially to do with this legislation; there is nothing particular about it. That is the way in which we would expect that to take place. I cannot say that it will always be one per cent, of course. That would be at the discretion of the auditor in each case, depending on their judgment about their client. They may feel they need a higher sample because they have less confidence in the quality of the processes and procedures. Of course, that is not something that this legislation can have any bearing on. Senator Margetts, that goes to most of your questions. If I have not covered all of them, please come back and I will try to give you some more information.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the minister to clarify that the audit costs are, similar to the cost of tax assessment, fully tax deductible and clarify the procedures under which companies can seek exemptions from the Australian Securities Commission. Minister, you have mentioned the sorts of criteria that will be under the third amendment, but would they also cover the procedures by which they might seek exemptions?

—With regard to the first point, there is no doubt in my mind that such expenses will be tax deductible. Firstly, in the normal course we would expect those expenses to be tax deductible because they are incurred in the normal course of earning income. But I understand that there is a tax ruling, although I have not seen it, which makes that quite specific. That they would be tax deductible just seems to me to be straightforward, Senator. I can give you that confident assurance.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the process, the main process for application would be covered by the class audits where the ASC would say that certain types of companies are covered, and then they would not need to apply. But, if they were not in one of those categories, they could still apply to the ASC with regard to their particular case. Each company could make an application, though those covered by the class audit would not need to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —With Senator Margetts's concurrence, I would like to continue what I was saying when we were interrupted at lunchtime. At that time I was telling senators that the small businesses which will be redefined as large businesses are those that have 50 employees, $5 million of assets or $10 million worth of turnover.

PARA.TAB: These businesses already go to their chartered accountants to obtain a balance sheet so that their income tax can be assessed. That gives them a very good understanding of where their business is at, whether they are profitable and what tax they have to pay. So they are being looked after now.

I have the permission of a certain Mr Bolger to table a letter from his chartered accountants. Mr Bolger has given me permission to use his name in this chamber. He runs a business in North Queensland. He has a spare parts business.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a member of the National Party.

—He is a member of the National Party, but that does not make it a crime. Nor would it be a crime if he was a member of the Labor Party or the Greens (WA). He is a member of the National Party, but that does not necessarily make him some sort of fiend. He is a decent business person. The National Party has 100,000 members, but let us just—
—He could be a Democrat, Senator.

—He could be a Democrat. I am sure that, if he were a Democrat, he would be equally as worried. Mr Bolger has allowed me to table this submission from his accountant, Tognola Cabassi McCallum and Co. Mr Tognola says to Mr Bolger, in a letter dated 13 September:

SPEECH.PARA: We refer to our recent discussion regarding the Corporations Law Simplification Bill. Under the proposed legislation, we consider that your Group would be classified as "large" because it satisfies two of the three criteria set out in the proposed Bill.

Accordingly the accounts of the Group would need to be audited with the first audit probably occurring in respect of the year ended 30 June 1996. We estimate the fee for performing the audit for your group of companies, given the diversity of locations etc would range between $20,000—$30,000. This cost is considerably greater than what you are currently paying our firm for attending to the traditional accounting work that we perform which goes hand in hand with the compilation of the Group's income tax returns.

I believe Mr Bolger is already paying these people $9,000, and he will have to pay an additional, say, $25,000. This is a business which employs about 60 people. Mr Bolger is already paying a firm of accountants to do his income tax.

PARA.TAB: What will happen if this legislation goes through is that Mr Bolger's company will be assessed as being big and he will have to provide to the Australian Securities Commission his annual accounts, which are the profit and loss account, his balance sheet, directors report and the auditors report. Not only will it cost him an additional $25,000—I take the mean between $20,000 and $30,000—but details about his business will be made available to any of his competitors.

One of Mr Bolger's businesses involves the industrial removal of garbage. He is an industrial cleaner. There is fierce competition in that sort of business, such as from Cleanaway, Hunter Bros and a number of other people. When he lodges all those documents—his balance sheet, the directors report and the profit and loss account—with the Australian Securities Commission, this will leave him wide open to anyone to come in, get an understanding of his business and offer him a takeover fee or establish a business. All his books will be laid open for anyone to come in and examine. He will have lost any commercial-in-confidence papers that he previously had.
We must take that into consideration. I know the Greens and the Australian Democrats have a commitment to privacy. That right will go right out the window. I seek leave to table the letter.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Spindler said today that this kind of auditing will be of some assistance to business. If auditing was of assistance to business, what happened to Skase, what happened to Bond and what happened to all those big companies that crashed in the 1980s? They all would have been audited. It does not do one iota of good. Accountants for businesses of any size must do a profit and loss account, a balance sheet and then a tax form and send that to the taxation department, so already small businesses are getting enough information for their taxation to run their business properly.

PARA.TAB: I reiterate that—we can go around in circles about this—for some small businesses, $30,000 will be the straw that breaks their backs. This will certainly hurt many companies that are now exempt, particularly the smaller big businesses. A lot of times when they are getting up to the 49 mark and they want to put on a couple of people, they will not do so. I know that a lot of people do a similar thing in relation to payroll tax. They know that if they have only eight or nine people working they fall beneath the bar of the payroll tax, so they do not put another person on. They just make do with the people they have.

You raised some questions about getting exemptions from the Australian Securities Commission. Those exemptions will be arbitrary and at the discretion of the Australian Securities Commission. I do not believe it is in the best interests of Australia that we in this Senate make laws that allow government departments or semi-government departments—it is government departments in this case—to take the power out of parliament and make discretionary or arbitrary decisions. People then have to go and prove their case and spend huge amounts of money to do so, and they have to get accountants.

Senator McGauran, who was on the committee and did put down a minority report, will probably explain this more fully, but it is arbitrary. That does not mean the Australian Securities Commission is going to allow it to happen. It means that they have power under the act to do so if they want. No-one knows what the barriers will be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, they do.

—I do not think they do, Senator. You may be able to tell me, but I cannot see any reason for this Senate to impose an additional cost of between $25,000 and $30,000 on businesses in Australia. We go out there and we all—every person in the Senate does this, from the National Party to the Greens to the Democrats—pay lip service to small business. It is a huge voting block and we all say that we are for small business. It is like motherhood. We are all for motherhood and we are all for small business.

PARA.TAB: Here is one bill through which we can say to small business: `We know you are doing it tough, we know you have had a rough time paying 18 per cent to 24 per cent interest rates, we know you have survived and we admire you for employing people and for your spirit in staying in there when 40,000 small businesses have gone broke over the last four or five years.' But surely we, as a Senate, do not want to go in with a bill called the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill and use that bill, which is supposed to assist small business, to put another 13 pounds in the saddle and draw them out on a wet track. That is what we are doing. We are placing them right out on a wet track, putting weight in their saddle bags and telling them to survive.

Small businesses have had so much trouble surviving in the last five years with high interest rates and every other imposition placed on them. And here we are today operating under the guise of a bill that will help small business. If we are going to help small business in that way and we are supposed to be their friends, then they do not need a lot of enemies. I would be interested in having Senator McMullan explain to me how this arbitrary decision works and how the Australian Securities Commission is going to allow people to opt in or out of this auditing procedure.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to reply after each speaker because it will wind up extending the debate, but I want to respond to some of the points Senator Boswell made. I will be brief because other senators will want to speak and we want to try to get this through as quickly as we can.

PARA.TAB: I think it is clear that the accounts that will be required to be lodged simply will not go into sufficient detail to allow the sort of competitive information that Senator Boswell raised that opens people up to takeovers, et cetera. No-one is going to make a takeover bid on the basis of the sort of generalised information that is required under these provisions.

The second point was in regard to small business. It is not that people introduced this measure ignorant of the concerns of small business. We know that the people who suffer when these companies fall over, or when their suppliers and subcontractors and others fall over, and therefore get the knock-on effect, are small businesses. The people who predominantly lose—sometimes it is employees, of course—who will be benefited by this are in fact small businesses, the people who contract to, supply and become the creditors of these people who fall over without warning or without effective capacity for people to judge that this might be imminent.

With regard to the question of cost, I have before me an Institute of Chartered Accountants' survey of their members, which assessed that the estimated additional cost would be in the order of $12,000. That is, of course, a deductible $12,000. I do not want to say that that is irrelevant, but it is certainly much less than the figure Senator Boswell was quoting. I am not saying that the quotes are not accurate, because it may be the case for one company and I cannot, of course, comment on that. We are talking about an average over all the clients of about, in this instance, some 700 chartered accountants who responded. So we are talking about a smaller burden, a tax deductible one—but not nothing. I do not say that it is irrelevant to individual companies, but it is less than Senator Boswell was discussing.

In relation to the question of the manner in which this discretion is going to be exercised, it is in the same way that all decisions that are properly passed by this Senate are constrained. They are constrained by legislative criteria and administrative law requirements. That is, we will be legislating in amendments to set down the criteria that will apply in the amendment that the minister circulated and people will be accountable against those under the normal administrative law requirements of the Commonwealth. So it is not just an arbitrary discretion. It is one with legislated criteria and reviewable discretions exercised and accountable against those criteria.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I want to say first of all how much I welcomed your declaration of an interest in this matter yesterday, when this debate started. I think it is a very proper way to conduct ourselves. I do not think we should rely simply on the statements that are filed, in our case with the Senate, where we as senators are obliged to declare our interests. I think there is an obligation on all of us whenever we debate a matter in which we have or may have an interest and where there is potential for conflict. I think it is proper that we should declare such an interest.

PARA.TAB: I regret to say that I have no conflict of interest in this matter. I am not a director of any proprietary companies and stand to gain no benefit whatsoever from any change in this matter. This situation may not have obtained some years ago, but on coming into parliament I think I joined the great bulk of my colleagues in having a much lower level of income than I had outside.

I make another couple of points. I will endeavour to be brief on this matter. Firstly, I take note of what the minister said. I agree with him about the question of the benefits that are given to people who set up companies, the benefit of limited liability and I agree with him on, as a consequence of that, what one does to try to ensure that as few people as possible who deal with such companies are damaged by inadequate laws in this area—in other words the subcontractors, who may be caught when a company goes broke. That they should be protected I think is a sound point that should be noted.

Many small companies benefit from the rules applied to other companies. One only has to look at the building industry to see the large volume of building subcontractors who work their hearts out, provide buildings which are then used by the ultimate customer, with the builder in the meantime having gone broke and many of the subcontractors, who often have been underpaid, as a consequence, also going broke.

The minister's reasonable approach to this and other matters underlines the point that he is too much of a gentleman and is foolish to be leaving or at least endeavouring to move from—I think is the appropriate expression—this chamber to seek fame, and certainly not fortune, in another chamber of this parliament. We will be doing all we can to endeavour to prevent that move, not because we would particularly like to see him continuing here but because we do not want to see him in the other chamber.

But Minister, the point that you make is one which is shared by the opposition: it is important that people recognise that they receive a benefit when they are allowed to limit their liability by the use of the corporate structure. There is no doubt that in this area it is important for there to be a level playing field—and I know that is an unfortunate expression these days; somehow people think that a level playing field is something nasty. But a level field in this area represents fairness and even-handedness, and it is important that a level playing field exist within the corporate structures, particularly amongst competing proprietary companies. This is where the government's attempt to correct the situation has broken down.

There is no doubt that what the government is seeking to do—which is to remove an immense burden on small proprietary companies—is excellent. I am not disputing that. But why I am supporting the opposition's amendment is that the government is now, in fact, making it grossly unfair for some large proprietary companies.

We have a new distinction. If you are a small proprietary company, you are absolved from the great burden of reporting requirements—and we commend that. But Senator Boswell has outlined the criteria by which you are deemed to be a large one: $10 million of turnover, $5 million of assets and 50 employees; if you qualify with two of those, you are hit with the new arrangements. The problem is the government has said that, if you are a large company which hits two of those requirements, you face not a level playing field but an unfair and discriminatory playing field.

What happens is that up until now you may have chosen to have your accounts audited and, therefore, under the old rules, not been obliged to present in public details of your financial statements. In other words, the form you have filled in has allowed you to tick a box which has said `Are your accounts audited?', you have ticked that and said `Yes', and you have not had to reveal anything. On the other hand, if you have not ticked the audited box and you have not had your accounts audited, you have been obliged to reveal the details of your financial accounts—the key financial data. That has been the position until now.

What is the government now going to do? The government is going to make it unfair. In future, under this legislation, the government will say, `Well, if in the past you have been ticking the box, for whatever reason, that you have had your accounts audited, you can keep on ticking the box and reveal nothing,' because the government for some reason wants to grandfather that requirement. Those who have been ticking the box in the past have to reveal nothing. Those who for other various reasons have not ticked the box and have revealed their financial details will not be given that option. They will be obliged not only to have their accounts fully audited at additional expense—considerable expense in some cases—but they will be forced also to reveal their detailed accounts publicly, as Senator Boswell complained. He was complaining about the very fact they have to do it; I am complaining about the unfair, uneven handling of two competitive proprietary companies.

Why is the government doing this? What is the benefit in public policy terms of unfairly discriminating against one set of companies who happen to have ticked one box and another set of companies who happen to have filled in a form? The government does not know what the reason is. It has not presented a reason, except to say, `Oh well, the people who have been ticking the box saying that their accounts are audited are accustomed to that level of privacy'. That, full stop, is the reason. I have heard nothing more ridiculous in my life. If those people are entitled to privacy, why aren't the others given the option of being entitled to privacy?

The whole question is a difficult one. In the days when I would have declared an interest as being a director or having shares in a company, I would have been able to say that, yes, I was a director of public companies which had the misfortune of competing with large proprietary companies. We had to reveal all and the large proprietary companies revealed nothing and, I might say, in many instances seemed to be tailing our pants off—maybe they were better run than ours. But they had a specific advantage; there was no level playing field there.

Nonetheless, this is a question of public policy and the fact remains that a public company does have additional responsibilities, particularly to a wide spread of owners. But a public company has no greater responsibility to people who lend it money—and most of them seem to borrow more than the amount of their capital these days—and no less a responsibility towards borrowers than do proprietary companies; and no greater responsibility to people who are lending money to them than proprietary companies.

There is no doubt that we have to see how we can make this competitive arena as fair and as just and as reasonable as possible. That is the reason for Senator Vanstone's amendments which, in fact, say to the government, `Look, you've got to give the same opportunities to all people'—these are the larger proprietary companies—`Give them the same opportunities. If they want to have their accounts audited, they should be able to tick the box and not reveal the details; if they do not want to have their accounts audited, they have to keep revealing, as now, the details of their key financial statement.' That seems to me to be the fairest way to resolve a difficult problem.

There has been some misunderstanding. There has been a strong question about whether or not this is going to impose an enormous cost burden on people. Obviously, if Senator Vanstone's amendments, on behalf of the opposition, are passed—that is, firstly, allowing them to tick the box or, secondly, put in the information—there is no additional burden. The fact is that, for the great bulk of large companies also proprietary companies, there is unlikely to be any additional burden because they already have audited accounts and tick the audited accounts box because they do not want to reveal their innermost secrets, they do not want to reveal their figures—and neither they should, if they do not want to, in terms of a level playing field.

But the point is that this legislation, even if it goes through in the government's terms, while it will not impose a massive burden on small business by requiring everyone suddenly to employ auditors—because of most of them at the top end already do—it will nonetheless impose some burden which may well not be fair.

My concern is this: if the opposition's amendment is not carried, a series of problems will be created, which I believe this Senate will have to address. If the opposition's making-things-fair amendment is knocked back, we then go to the government's one, which involves a discretion—giving the Securities Commission, in effect, a discretion to determine whether or not it is right or wrong for a `big company', or in the public interest, or too costly in relation to the benefit in the public interest to reveal all; in other words, to meet these requirements. Giving the ASC this discretion to allow people not to meet it seems to me to be a dreadful way to run a company.

One of the most important things in the law is certainty before the law—not depending on the whim, decision or determination of a well-intended bureaucrat, I have no doubt. But it is not a principle I find acceptable—that we are going to give to any bureaucratic body the right to determine—

TALK.START.PARA: —The parliament is where the laws are made.

—The parliament is where it ought to be determined; exactly so. I find unacceptable the right of a body to determine who should or who should not have to meet these onerous—and they are onerous—requirements if our amendment is not passed. The specific task the parliament will then face, if the government's amendment is preferred to the opposition's amendment, is having to determine whether or not the high jump bar—in other words, this qualification: what is big and what is small—is reasonable.

PARA.TAB: The simple facts are self-evident. The high jump bar presented in this legislation is not reasonable if we are going to have the government's amendment passed and not the opposition's amendment. It is not reasonable on several grounds. The first ground is that it will include a lot of small—despite the definition of `large'—proprietary companies entirely owned by families which are financed entirely from internal family sources, as families have reinvested their money by way of lending and so on to the company, with very little external debt for security. It will involve an unfair attack on those companies.

One of the reasons for that is the wrong inclusion of the word `assets' as one of the criteria. The issue here surely should not be assets. There are a whole lot of versions of how you value an asset. I remember the Keating piggery revalued its assets up by $4 million, not by revaluing the land but by revaluing—on its own estimates; not a licensed valuer's estimate—its piggery buildings. In fact, the buildings were steadily deteriorating; one even burnt down. But asset valuation is not the way to go. It should clearly be the level of external liabilities.

There must be a review of this high jump level. I will be moving an amendment at the third reading stage to require this situation to be reviewed. I strongly support Senator Vanstone's amendment. The amendment makes the situation a lot less difficult and a lot fairer than the government's amendment. Perhaps the government has not recognised the significance of the impositions it is imposing on small business. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked a number of questions earlier. Checking back, one still remains to be answered. We recognise that when the failure of a company with a large volume, usually with large assets and capital overheads and usually with large staff numbers, does occur, this can have major impacts on creditors and employees. It does seem that there is a need for providential requirements.

PARA.TAB: The government's claims rest on the argument that an audit would provide significant providential benefit and that this benefit would outweigh `disbenefits' to large volume, low profit enterprises. What we have not heard yet is examples of where this might apply and, specifically, by making these kinds of bottom line audits available, whether or not a medium enterprise or large enterprises defined by this legislation might be able to be assisted out of problems if that information is made public earlier rather than trying to paper over a problem that does not get found out until it is too late.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I briefly respond to Senator Baume's point. It was mainly a policy statement of his, which is a legitimate alternative point of view. He will have the chance to speak again, but I am not encouraging him, and other opposition speakers might respond. I will not claim expertise in this area because I have come to it only recently, not having dealt with it for several years. Reading the opposition's amendment, and on the basis of advice I have received—I am looking at it very quickly—I do not think it solves the problem Senator Baume outlines. There will still be the differential between those who have to comply and those who do not. Companies which newly become large after the four-month period expires will still be in a different situation from the continuing companies.
—Under your arrangements.

—No, under yours, too. I cannot see how not; but I do not want to pursue it. I am very happy to hear an explanation why that is not true. I am not pretending expertise; but that is what it looks like to us on a quick assessment. You may be able to briefly explain to me why that is not the case and I will be happy to listen.

PARA.TAB: Senator Margetts asked me a specific question. I am sorry; I did hear you ask that question before and I missed it in the list to which I was responding. I have a couple of examples. Even though they are all probably publicly known, I am a little hesitant to read out the names. They are not names of individuals but of companies. I will try to do this without reading out the names, if it makes sense.

A company of Melbourne property developers failed and went into liquidation with debts of up to $150 million. A lot of people will work out who I am talking about, but that is different. It has been reported, I think arising from a separate court action, that one of the directors of the company could not explain transactions involving amounts in the vicinity of $720,000. It is likely that, if an auditor had been appointed to such a company, an unexplained transaction of this nature would have been noted and queried. So there is one example. It is a bit general because I do not want to give too much detail.

We have an alternative situation where a manufacturing company failed. It had a reported deficiency of more than $5 million, with 150 creditors and $755,000 in pre-paid orders that had not been supplied. At least 10,000 customers have been affected by the collapse of this company. When it failed, the Victorian ministry of fair trading indicated that it had received more than 600 calls in two days from customers who had ordered and paid for goods but had not received them. In this instance, what you would have had with audits is the likelihood of earlier recognition of the problems of the company. An auditor would have been providing that assessment and analysis and may have assisted in avoiding the collapse.

No-one can pretend that having auditors means no companies will ever fail; we all know that is not true. But often auditors are in a position to point out to the company and, through that, to their customers, subcontractors and suppliers the problems that the company faces. Our position essentially is that it is not an unreasonable burden to require people, in a very general way, to make available the level of information that will enable other small businesses—and some large ones; but, in terms of the tenure of this debate, the other small businesses—and the individual citizens who are the customers, employees, suppliers and subcontractors of these companies to have access to this reasonable, if limited, amount of information.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having heard the minister's explanation why he thinks the government's provisions are necessary, I must say that I find the explanation extraordinary. He cited an unnamed company—
—You want me to name it? I can name it.
—It does not matter. You cited an unnamed company in liquidation which had 600—
—You are making a hero of yourself on the point about it being—
—I listened to you; now you can listen to me.
—Don't be a hero.

—No. You can just listen to me. He cited a company that had 600 people ring up and complain that they had ordered things which had not been delivered. So it had a lot of unsecured creditors. But the fact is that none of those 600 people who ordered things would have gone and looked at the company's accounts beforehand anyway. That is an utter furphy. It is an absolute and utter furphy to suggest that any of the 600 consumers in question would have been any better off. It is also a furphy to suggest that employees would be any better off as a result of the audit provisions that the government seeks to implement.

PARA.TAB: I just happen to know a fair bit about winding up companies. I will tell Senator McMullan, for his own benefit, that what he told the chamber a moment ago was utter garbage. If the government wants to justify the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill, it is about time that it started to resort to a few facts. But the sorts of scare tactics that we just heard from Senator McMullan really do not do him any justice at all. I thought Senator McMullan had a bit more brains than that.

To suggest that 600 people who are ultimately unsecured creditors of a company as they paid for goods that were not delivered because the company went into liquidation would be better off because auditors were appointed to the company is nonsense. Senator McMullan knows, I know and many other senators in this chamber know that there are many companies that trade for a long time when they are insolvent. Having the auditor there does not necessarily fix the problem. Sometimes companies collapse very quickly as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —And I said that.

—Senator McMullan, I can sit here and recite as many scare stories as you can. In fact, I can probably do a damned better job. But what I would like is for you to have the courtesy of listening to me in the same fashion in which I listened to you. Quite frankly, I believe the government is failing the people of Australia and it is failing in respect of its responsibilities to the parliament if it is not going to answer these concerns squarely and honestly. The sorts of scare tactics that we heard from Senator McMullan quite simply will not wash.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I can just respond to Senator McMullan. I have sought further advice with respect to our amendment. I think we are in a position where we are both looking at the same page but you are seeing two faces and I am seeing a candlestick. Our view is that this does cover new companies coming in. The only way we are going to resolve that is if you can make me see where the two faces are or if I can do the other. That might take some time. There may be the possibility of dealing with this bill tonight. Were the Greens of a mind to support our amendment, then it would be vital to check whether they are candlesticks or faces. But, if they were not, then the amendment would be lost.

PARA.TAB: I am in the hands of other contributors here, but the best advice we have is that it does cover new companies coming in. That is certainly our intention. The whole basis of the amendment we are seeking to move is to say, `Look, with exempt proprietary companies there isn't an established case for treating them differently.' As Senator Baume was saying—perhaps in stronger and more colourful language—some made the choice to have auditors; some made the choice to file key financial data. Why on the basis of a choice do you quarantine one and treat the others differently? We just do not see that as being rational. We see that one way of fixing that problem is to put exempt proprietary companies on the same standard—a higher standard than small companies.

Senator Margetts, you might be able to help us in that respect. If you are of a mind to support us, you may be able to tell me whether I am looking at a candlestick or two faces, if you understand the point I am making. If you were to support this amendment, then the only person whom we would need to know about would be Senator Harradine. We would therefore have to confirm whether my advice is correct or not. But, if you are not of a mind to support it, then it is in a sense irrelevant. I put on the record that it is intended to cover all new companies coming in. Were the amendment likely to be passed, I would certainly ensure that it did cover all new companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the benefit of the chamber, we had better make sure what amendment you are moving at this stage. I now have a revised amendment in front of me dated 27 September. So, if it is that amendment, could I suggest that you withdraw the original amendment and then move this one.

—Thank you for your assistance, Mr Acting Chairman. I seek leave of the chamber to withdraw the original amendment and move the revised amendment. I do not know whether the revised amendment is of any assistance because, as I say, I cannot see the faces you are looking at.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Schedule 4, page 64, item 58, proposed subsection 317B(4), omit the subsection, substitute the following subsections:

TAB.TAB: (a)but for this subsection, subsection (1) would apply to a large proprietary company for a financial year; and

(b)but for the amendments (other than this subsection) omitting, repealing or otherwise affecting references to exempt proprietary companies made by subsection 4(2), and set out in Schedule 4, of the First Corporate Law Simplification Act 1995, the company would have been an exempt proprietary company for that year; and
(c)the company has continued to meet the definition of `exempt proprietary' (as in force at 30 June 1994) at all times since enactment of section 45A; and

(d)within 4 months after the end of the first financial year of the company that ends after the commencement of this section the company lodges with the ASC a notice that the company wants this subsection to apply to the company;

PARA.TAB: the company may by the notice referred to in paragraph (d) elect to be treated as an exempt proprietary company for the purpose of lodgment of accounts and financial statements as if:

TAB.TAB: (e)the amendments (other than this subsection) omitting, repealing or otherwise affecting references to exempt proprietary companies, set out in Schedule 4 to the First Corporate Law Simplification Act 1995, had not been made; and
(f)the regulations in force at 30 June 1994 in relation to such lodgment by such a company remain in force.
"(5)The ASC may extend the period referred to in paragraph (3)(e) or (4)(d).".

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not believe that the revised amendment that has been put forward by Senator Vanstone solves the problem. It may still require certain sections to be involved with the cost of an audit. But the whole point of the audit is to make available information so that creditors of various sorts and occasionally employees, considering the level of enterprise bargaining, know whether they have been given accurate information or perhaps incorrect information by the employers in terms of the company's position. There are a number of reasons why the bottom line ought to be available.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps a clarification could be obtained from Senator Vanstone but, if this amendment does not actually make publicly available the bottom line or even the basic audit information through the Australian Securities Commission, then the whole point of having the audits accessible to creditors of various sorts is lost. A lot of those costs still apply to those companies which are still required to provide an audit.

TALK.START.PARA: —The effect of this amendment is to ensure that all large exempt proprietary companies—existing ones and new ones that come onto the pile—maintain the existing reporting requirements. That would mean that either they can choose to have an auditor—if they choose to have an auditor, they can keep all the information to themselves—or they can choose to file what is referred to as key financial data and not have an auditor. They are the choices that they have at the moment and they are the choices that we believe it is appropriate for them to continue to have. In answer to your question, I can say that some would chose an audit and keep all the information to themselves; some would choose, as they are now, to file the key financial data. That relates to the bottom line, profit or loss, net assets and things like that. It is not as complete as full financial statements.

PARA.TAB: That is what we are proposing. We are saying that we should keep all large exempt proprietary companies the same; that we should allow them to maintain the same reporting requirements that they have at the moment; and that we should allow them to make the choice, as we have allowed them to do for some considerable time, of either having an auditor or filing this limited financial data.

That is the system that has been working. Some would say it has been working very well. Of course there are corporate collapses in small business and big business. There is never going to be a formula to keep them all going. That is part of the risk. Of course there will be bad faith as the Skase matter and others showed. No auditor is going to save you from that. We say, `Give these companies a go at keeping at the existing reporting levels.'

TALK.START.PARA: —If I could just add another point. Senator Margetts is very keen to see, as many people quite sensibly are, what the actual money is; what the bottom line is; what the assets are; what the liabilities are; and so on. I think Senator Margetts was making the point that employees in particular should be entitled to see that bottom line. The problem is that, under the government's proposal, the great bulk of these companies will not be obliged to reveal what the bottom line is. They will be grandfathered into the existing situation. The government's arrangements are that the great bulk of public companies which tick the box saying `audited' will not be required to show a thing. But other proprietary companies that are competing against them will be obliged to do so. I think it should be either one in, all in or none in at all. That is what fairness dictates.

PARA.TAB: As a former director of two public companies, I agree that there is a case for saying that large proprietary companies should reveal these things when they are competing with public companies that are sometimes even smaller than they are. That is an argument, but it is not the central issue here. The central issue here is that the government is proposing an arrangement whereby the bulk of these companies will not have to reveal a thing because they are grandfathered. But others will have to reveal their figures because, for a whole variety of reasons, they are not in it at the moment. Either they are providing key financial data or they are not big enough as yet to qualify for the new test. I am certain you would appreciate the fairness of the issue. All I am seeking is for the government to be even-handed in dealing with this matter. You might take the view that the best way to do it—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 6.50 p.m., I will report progress.

PARA.TAB: Progress reported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I note, in particular, the interesting element of this very large annual report of the Commonwealth Ombudsman relating to the Australian Taxation Office. The ombudsman appointed a special tax adviser from 20 April 1995, Mr Peter Haggstrom, who had previously worked in the Commonwealth Ombudsman's office and as a tax manager with KPMG Peat Marwick. His appointment, as this report says, changed significantly following the government's implementation of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts' recommendation that a specialist taxation ombudsman should be established. It is interesting to note that, as a result of that appointment, there has been an enormous upsurge in the volume of tax complaints made to the ombudsman. He notes in the report:

. . . for the period April 1994—June 1994, the office received 191 complaints about the ATO, while for the period April 1995-June 1995, the figure was 529. The post Special Tax Adviser rate of complaint is about 280 per cent that of the previous rate.
The report goes on:
Although it is difficult to draw strong inferences from this short period, it seems taxpayers are having difficulty with:
.the ATO's debt recovery actions;
.remission of penalties, especially those relating to incorrect returns, underestimation of provisional income and late payment of tax;
.disputes about the ATO's audit settlement practices;
.the operation of the provisional tax system;
.conduct of income tax and sales tax audits;—
I have heard plenty of complaints about those—
and
.the ATO's compliance function in the Superannuation Guarantee area.

We have not received many individual complaints about the operation of the private rulings system, however we presume this is because taxpayers are not yet aware that we handle these types of complaints.

Obviously, they are expecting a fair volume of such complaints. There has been an interesting outcome as a result of the special tax adviser's inquiries into the question of fringe benefits tax and the confusion that had entered this area as a result of government activities and the extraordinary way people were being penalised for genuinely misunderstanding a massively confusing situation. The ombudsman's report stated:
The ATO has responded very positively to the Special Tax Adviser's inquiries. The Commissioner provided the following commitment in relation to penalties:

"It is acknowledged that a number of taxpayers have had difficulty in applying the law in this area to their particular situations. For that reason the ATO will, unless special circumstances apply, generally remit the total culpability component of any incorrect return penalties arising out of errors made by taxpayers in the 1994 and 1995 years of income tax.

I welcome that, but it underlines how confusing, complicated and, some people would say, ridiculous some of the fringe benefits tax arrangements have been under this government. This is the government that came in saying that it was going to simplify the tax system when at that stage the tax act was 1,136 pages thick. It is now 3,378 pages thick. It has trebled in size and become much more complicated, to the extent that you now need a special tax ombudsman. But that is simply by the way and I suppose could be dismissed as a political point. It is a matter of some substance. The report says:
The Special Tax Adviser will be pursuing some outstanding issues related to the public rulings program,—
which I welcome—

including monitoring the ATO's action to finalise old draft rulings and how public rulings are applied in practice, but his focus will shift to the private rulings system where he would be looking at the systemic problems associated with turnaround times for private ruling requests.

This area of private ruling is a very complicated one and one that does need correction. I am overjoyed to see that the special tax adviser will be looking at this because there has been an upsurge in complaints about debt recovery. I welcome the fact that the ATO's debt management system is also being examined by the commissioner, because there are real problems. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, want to offer some comments on the Commonwealth Ombudsman's annual report, in my case so far as it relates to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The report comments on eight areas within the jurisdiction of the department and the minister. I want to comment on several of those. A constant theme in the complaints received by the ombudsman was delays in processing applications and refusals of visas and entry permits. However, unfortunately, the ombudsman has not covered this in any further detail in the report other than raising it as a constant theme in the complaints. It is a matter that does require some further monitoring and follow up because it does suggest, at least prima facie, a sloppiness in administration, which we would not want to see continue.

PARA.TAB: There are also complaints of delays in responding to correspondence to the department. The ombudsman pursued these complaints with the department, in many cases because the complaints themselves took an unreasonably long time to resolve. I am pleased to note that the ombudsman believes the situation has improved. Again, this is another area of administration that requires careful monitoring.

Another item touched on by the ombudsman related to the transfer of immigration detainees to state prisons. The migration legislation allows immigration detainees to be held in state prisons or other facilities authorised by the minister as immigration detention centres. So the law therefore allows detainees to be transferred from immigration detention centres to state prisons or other facilities for behavioural or management reasons. The ombudsman followed up three cases of detainees who were transferred to the prison system. All three were transferred because their behaviour in detention was unsatisfactory.

The ombudsman supports a recommendation of the Australian Institute of Criminology that only those detainees charged with a criminal offence should be transferred to prisons. It acknowledged that there would be some cases where other reasonable grounds for transfer exist, such as the need to protect other detainees. However, management practices within the immigration detention centres should, so the ombudsman said—I certainly agree—be developed to cope with most situations. Failure to monitor and reassess detainees in the prison system was the ombudsman's main criticism of the present situation. But, again, it obviously is an area which requires careful examination, and a considered response from the department is required at the very least.

One of the other items which is a matter of real concern so far as the administration of the department is concerned is the ombudsman's comments on the question of refunds and reinstatement for entry visas. In 1987 return visas and return endorsement visas—multiple entry visas—were replaced with resident return visas. Because of a major slip-up by the department, a problem has been caused as a result of that. What the government intended to do at the time was to introduce legislation to cancel the two visa arrangements that were being replaced. However, it never got around to doing that; it has never happened. That means that for all permanent residents who have not received a new resident return visa, their old visas are still valid.

The complaint that came to the Ombudsman came about because many people who could have continued to travel on their old visa arrangements exchanged them for the new ones without being told they could have kept the old ones. The new resident return visas cost an applicant $50, whereas the former ones were free. Many people—I am told possibly tens of thousands—had they known that at that time, would have continued to travel on their old visas. The net result of all this is that the department has agreed there is an inequity and has said these people should approach their immigration office to see whether they are entitled to a refund or have their old visas reinstated.(Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen C.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to address a few remarks to one issue that emerges from this quite weighty report—report No. 45 into charitable organisations in Australia. The issue is covered in chapter 12 which relates to taxation arrangements of charitable organisations. One particular concern I have had for some time relates to the use of fringe benefits tax and the exemption that is available to charitable organisations from fringe benefits tax. The report confirms the concern that I have had for some time about potential abuse of the fringe benefits tax exemption enjoyed by not only charitable institutions but also some religious institutions, public benevolent institutions and even some public hospitals that are classified as PBIs.

PARA.TAB: I want to point out early on, Mr Acting Deputy President, that I, like you, share some concerns generally about the approach taken in Industry Commission reports. But on this occasion I find myself in agreement with their conclusions, at least as they relate to fringe benefits tax. The abuse identified goes to the potential for unscrupulous practices and the unethical use of fringe benefits as some of these organisations have sought to move employees from their salaries onto a combination of salary and fringe benefit provisions. These provisions allow the sharing between the employees and the organisations of the benefits of their exemption from fringe benefits. There is potential for enormous cost saving, I will admit, for these organisations. As most of them are under pressure about their funding and have an unending demand for their services, both the organisations and their employees are under real pressures.

As I say, a range of concerns have been identified by the Industry Commission which go to the inequality between employees that some of these practices have encouraged, and the enormous cost to the Commonwealth, which the Industry Commission estimates at $40 million currently and with the potential to extend greatly as the pressure for and knowledge of the ability to use the fringe benefits tax loophole spreads throughout this sector.

There is the concern that these arrangements are not necessarily transparent nor used properly in terms of the costing of services. There is also the serious concern that I have, which is that the whole arrangement can have the effect of undercutting the award system and the proper rights of employees to award conditions. The pressure that can be applied in terms of having to find savings in budgets can force employees into agreeing to fringe benefits tax arrangements which may not be in their interests and certainly may not be in the interests of the taxpayers of Australia.

The Industry Commission identifies these concerns and concludes that perhaps the exemption ought to be removed. I am sure the government will give serious consideration to the whole report. I do not want to pre-empt any decisions that need to be taken when dealing with the totality of the report, but it is of concern that the Industry Commission has identified abuse and unscrupulous practices developing in charitable organisations and other organisations that benefit from this fringe benefits tax exemption. It fits with my concerns about the abuse by the Western Australian state Liberal government of those fringe benefits tax exemptions within the remuneration packages that they are offering to employees of their public benevolent institutions.

With the developments in that field, and with the developments identified in the Industry Commission report that are occurring in charitable organisations, there is a justifiable concern that the Commonwealth is losing revenue and that unequal and inappropriate practices are developing in relation to the avoidance of fringe benefits tax. I think it is something that the government and the parliament ought to give consideration to dealing with and ending the abuse that is occurring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must agree with Senator Chris Evans. I have those concerns. But I say to Senator Evans that one of the problems is that your government has already put out a press release that says this:

SPEECH.PARA: The government also does not accept that the fringe benefits tax exemption for charitable organisations should be removed.

So while I have those concerns, it looks as though the government has already cut off probably one of the parts of this Industry Commission report that I really would have thought would have been of great benefit to us, because I share your concerns, having seen what some of the charitable organisations have done in artificially arranging salary packages. I think you should take this back to the government and say to them that despite their press release, maybe that is one part they ought to look at again.

PARA.TAB: However, I have other concerns in regard to which I am not so supportive of this report. Like Senator Evans, I must say it is a very weighty tome. Let me signal a couple of issues. One that I have been concerned about throughout the whole process of this Industry Commission report is the issue of tendering. I raised only last week the problem that has been created in Victoria through the government there tendering out welfare services such as Meals on Wheels and what that has done to the quality, ethos and the very rationale for Meals on Wheels.

I signal that I still have a great concern in this area of tendering and notice that this is one of the substantial recommendations—in fact, it picks up a number of recommendations—in the report that has remained, despite the fact that it has been signalled by many charitable organisations. Certainly I have indicated to the government that this is one they should leave alone, although not in a total sense, because there are areas in which it is appropriate, but I think that in most cases it is a recommendation that the government ought to leave alone, despite what the Industry Commission says.
