I signal a couple of matters that concern me greatly. For instance, in referring to its recommendation about calling applications by public tender, the Industry Commission report says this:

SPEECH.PARA: Joint ventures and prime subcontracting are common features of tender arrangements in other sectors of the economy.

That highlights the fundamental problem that we have had with this whole approach of the Industry Commission. To describe the charitable sector as one of the other sectors of the economy is the whole problem that we have had with the Industry Commission approach. While there are economic implications to the charity sector—of course, there are—to describe it simply as one of the sectors of the economy underlines the very problem that I have with the approach of the Industry Commission's whole inquiry.

PARA.TAB: Let me signal just one other issue, and it is on page 218 of the report. For community social welfare organisations to receive tax deductibility for donations, they will have to separately incorporate under an act of parliament and change their structures. I hope the government leaves this one totally alone. I will tell you what it could mean. It could mean that church aged care institutions that have millions of dollars invested in assets, if they have to pay stamp duty on the value of those assets in order to reincorporate under another structure, could not even begin to cope with that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: I am fascinated by this report of the Industry Commission on charitable organisations in Australia, in particular, their efficiency and accountability. This, I think, is the very important element of the report. This report outlines that many of these non-government development organisations—fund-raisers—have a national charter and are particularly disadvantaged by interstate disparities and outmoded legislation.

PARA.TAB: For example, World Vision of Australia estimates that its compliance costs under state fundraising legislation are at least $1 million a year. That $1 million which should be going in aid is going in compliance costs because of the different state legislation across Australia. As Amnesty International said, and as is quoted in this report:

SPEECH.PARA: A major problem for Amnesty International Australia is the inability to run an Australia wide raffle . . . on advice from one of our major legal firms and it is clear that although Amnesty International Australia has a presence in all the State capitals and Canberra, State laws prevent a combined raffle.
In relation to disclosure requirements, World Vision of Australia said:

. . . legislative requirements do not recognise that some charities are run as a serious business and do not keep such records in the form that various State legislation requires. For instance in NSW the requirements state that a cash book, register of assets, register of receipt books, register of tickets,

petty cash book, minute book and register of participants must be kept. In Queensland the requirements state that a cash book, petty cash book, register of receipt books and postage stamp record must be kept. Such requirements from incompetent or out-of-touch legislation discriminate against efficient large scale operations . . . Uniformity, closer co-ordination, would help national charities be more efficient.

The Industry Commission believes, in its report, that modernisation and greater uniformity of regulations would have particular benefit for the administrative efficiency of NGDOs. It also notes that there is a high level of interest about the way in which NGDOs raise and spend donations. For this reason, the commission developed ratios which could be used by donors to compare fundraising and program spending performances. I seek leave to table that statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a revelation. The criteria have to be taken with some reservation. The one showing the highest—in other words, the best—project expenditure as against total expenditure, I guess the lowest administrative and other costs, of the top three listed here is the Adventist Development and Relief Agency, which spends 96.6 per cent of its total expenditure on projects. Then there is Australian Catholic Relief, with 90.8 per cent; and then Care Australia with 89.5 per cent. Care Australia is the top of the non-church organisations. Many of the church organisations have the benefit of having reduced administrative expenses because they operate within the structure of the church.

PARA.TAB: One problem is that there is a lack of consistent information on the composition of expenditure and income, which makes it extremely difficult for members of the public to determine how their donations are being spent and to make informed comparisons between them. One donor found, as the report says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in effect it has not been possible for me as a donor to inspect the financial statement of Austcare, and from that statement to work out how much they're spending on fundraising and administration, and I feel that this shows a lack of accountability which is very close to disregard for the interests of donors.
I was not particularly seeking to single out Austcare, but it is simply an example of the problems. The report continues:

PARA.TAB: As World Vision Australia submitted, there are several ways in which overheads are calculated, reported and interpreted in the overseas aid sector.

SPEECH.PARA: A representative of Save the Children Australia said, according to this report, that he had seen NGDOs quote expenses for administration that they would regard as highly questionable. He continued:
At present it's very easy, I think, for organisations to do a sort of snow job on their accounts to hide management expenses.
In any event, this report recommends a significant improvement in the requirements, because it says:

PARA.TAB: There is a broad agreement in the sector that features of NGDOs justify special considerations of accountability for this group of organisations.

SPEECH.PARA: On the face of it, just having looked quickly at these recommendations about greater accountability, I must say that they look sound. For example, there is a recommendation that the Commonwealth government should provide funds to the Australian Accounting Standards Board to develop within two years suitable accounting standards. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: This is a weighty tome. It would take some time to digest. At the outset I must say that I agree with Senator Woodley's concerns about the requirement for charitable bodies to be incorporated so as to get tax deductibility, which is one of the recommendations contained in chapter 12 of the report. It could have unforeseen consequences, which would be highly undesirable. Quite clearly, that is a recommendation that needs to be rethought.

PARA.TAB: At the outset I should state that I have an involvement with a large number of charitable bodies that are involved in fundraising, either educational bodies or bodies for public benefit. One example is Life Education, which is not quite an education body. Another is my rowing club. All of them have problems with fundraising. That was why I was quite interested in chapter 9.

I know the fundraising industry is a substantial industry in Australia today. Some estimates of fundraising put it as high as one per cent of GDP. That does not sound a lot, but that is around $4 billion or more. There is quite a lot of money in fundraising. It is a very big business.

One of the great problems that members of parliament have whenever the issue of fundraising comes up is: what is a reasonable amount of cost to be incurred in the process of fundraising, and what is unreasonable? There is a grave difficulty here because many organisations do not have the in-house expertise in order to run fundraising programs. Sometimes it is more efficient to bring in people from outside to be fund-raisers. In that respect you have to be very careful that, if you limit too heavily the amount of costs that a body can incur in the process of fundraising, they may not actually raise any funds at all. At the same time, people who donate money want to be guaranteed, as far as is possible, that a fair proportion of their money is actually going to the charity which they wish to support. That is the dilemma. I am going to have to look at the chapter in more detail before I form a final view. I believe there is a lot of merit in self-governing of the fundraising industry through the FIA. Ideally, I would like us to go down that track.

In relation to taxation arrangements, I was intrigued to read the recommendation that tax deductibility be given to any body which could meet the definition of `advancement of social welfare' contained in Waterson and Others v. Hendon Borough Council (1959) 1 WLR, page 958. I must admit that it has been a long time since I have read that. I will have to go back to the case to see exactly what it means. I do believe that sometimes we are too tight in our definition of what is charitable and, therefore, attracts tax deductibility. I believe broadening that gives the community at large a better choice of how they wish to apply their money. It may increase the level of public benevolence. That is something we have to consider as well. Given, I am sure, that other people wish to speak on this fairly weighty tome, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—Order! It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak tonight on a matter which I regard as a serious deficiency in Australian public life; that is, our lack of any population policy. I am moved to speak on this subject by a recent news report on immigration to Australia in 1994-95. The Adelaide Advertiser reported on 7 September 1995 that figures released by the Bureau of Immigration, Multicultural and Population Research showed a 25 per cent increase in immigration from the previous year. That is an extraordinary increase in one year. What is also extraordinary is that it was largely ignored by the media and by the parliament. It does appear that immigration is, in fact, a no-go area in Australia.

PARA.TAB: There were 87,428 immigrants in 1994-95 compared with 69,768 in the previous year. The bureau notes that nearly half the immigrants are still going to New South Wales—43 per cent to New South Wales; nearly twice as many as go to the next highest state, Victoria, which received 22 per cent. I think that is quite interesting in the light of New South Wales Premier Carr's recent comments on the population problems, as he sees them, in New South Wales.

The concern raised by the latest figures is the fact that such a big increase in the immigration intake has occurred while unemployment in this country remains so high. We had an MPI on that subject today. Unemployment is still at 8.3 per cent—a very high level. There are still nearly three-quarters of a million Australians who cannot get work but who want it. The economy is slowing down. It is being deliberately slowed down by the government. So the likelihood is that unemployment will at some point start to rise again. Even the government's budget, which one must say is an optimistic document, admits that unemployment will not be less than eight per cent by June next year.

Yet, in the face of all that—three-quarters of a million unemployed—the government is accelerating the immigration program. I am not talking about whether there is immigration or not; I am talking about the pace of the increase in immigration. To have a 25 per cent increase in one year really makes no sense to the Australian community in the face of the very high level of unemployment. It particularly does not make much sense when you note—as I do not think many Australians do—that the unemployment rate for migrants who have arrived in the last five years is 22 per cent. That means that almost one in four of recent migrants who wish to obtain a job cannot get a job and are unemployed.

In fact, the unemployment rate for all migrants who arrived in the last 20 years—that is, since 1976—is above the national unemployment rate of 8.3 per cent. Yet, in the face of all that, the government is proposing another increase. We see that in 1995-96, the current financial year, the government has set aside an extra 14,000 places, which will take immigration back over the 100,000 mark. I just do not know how the government can justify such a rapid increase in immigration when we still have three-quarters of a million Australians who cannot find work. I really wonder what the trade unions think of all this.

The real issue, in my view, is that the government is threatening what is fragile community support for a big immigration program by this sort of rapid increase in the intake. I note that the community has really already given up on Labor on this issue of immigration. The Newspoll survey published on 20 September, which sought the attitudes of people to the handling of various issues by Labor and the coalition, showed that voters think that the coalition can handle the issue of immigration better than Labor.

That is not a surprising finding when you look at what has been an extraordinary roller-coaster ride on immigration under Labor—incredible fluctuations in numbers year by year. The net migration in Labor's first year, 1984, was 49,000; by 1988, only four years later, it was 149,000—an extraordinary increase in four years. In 1989 it was 157,000; in 1990 it went back to 124,000; and in 1991 it went down to 86,000. It is just like the big dipper at Luna Park.

Former finance minister Peter Walsh was very revealing in his book about the way this government conducts immigration policy. He noted in his book that it took five years of this government before it even had a major debate on immigration. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: Early in 1988, the first major cabinet debate on immigration took place.
He then says, in looking back over the five years at that point:
Thus three sequences of blow outs and cave-ins boosted arrivals from 70 to 115 thousand. The next year—
that is 1989—

it blew out again to 140 thousand. Apart from the unplanned and unintended doubling of numbers in four years, the composition at the instigation of the ethnic mafia, also changed towards `family reunion', which debased migrant employability. Frequent Ministerial changes—four Ministers in the first five years—did not facilitate the development of coherent on-going policy.
An understatement, if ever there was one.

PARA.TAB: This is the hopeless adhockery of immigration policy which former Labor minister Peter Walsh complained of and which Barry Jones in his own report—a very interesting report on Australia's population carrying capacity—complained of. The report is by the National President of the Labor Party, and the committee has a majority of Labor members on it. Its recommendation No. 2 is well worth reading in the light of what I regard as this ad hoc approach to immigration. Mr Jones's committee recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Government should adopt a population policy which explicitly sets out options for long term population change, in preference to the existing situation where a de facto population policy emerges as a consequence of year by year decisions on immigration intake taken in an ad hoc fashion, such decisions being largely determined by the state of the economy in the particular year and with little consideration of the long term effects.

There is your own national president—the national president of the party in government—describing his government's policy as ad hoc. I strongly support that committee's recommendation. I note that it was a recommendation from a majority of government members. It is about time the government responded to that report in full, not just the interim report we have had.

PARA.TAB: I want to indicate tonight my personal support for committee option IV in looking at the future for Australia. Option IV was for a stable population in the possible range of 17 million to 23 million, which the committee notes has `strong community support'. I do not think anyone in Australia can read Tim Flannery's outstanding book The Future Eaters and not recognise the significant environmental limits to Australia's population carrying capacity—that is really what was being referred to in the Jones report.
Very interestingly, New South Wales Labor Premier Bob Carr referred to this matter in May. I want to quote what he said about all this. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the debate ought to be about the carrying capacity of the continent—a continent that has lousy soils, fragile vegetation and depleted and degraded river systems.

I do not often agree with Labor premiers, but I must agree with Mr Carr. I suspect that, like me, Premier Carr has read The Future Eaters and been moved by what he read. What was very sad was the condemnation that Mr Carr incurred right across Australia. It was a disgraceful example of the sort of intimidation and intolerance—

PARA.TAB: Senator Bob Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly. The criticism of Mr Carr was not confined to people outside the Liberal Party. I condemn everyone who attacked Mr Carr for making a very sensible contribution to what is an important debate in Australia, and a debate we have to have. It is very sad that in Australia, allegedly a free democracy, a bloke like Bob Carr cannot make those sorts of comments without being attacked from all sides.

PARA.TAB: In my view, both major parties, including my own, need to recognise the need for a population policy and need to recognise that the immigration program that the government, of whatever colour, presides over must be determined within the context of that population policy, which, as Mr Jones says, is not the case at the moment. The population policy that the government has, whether it is Labor or coalition, must recognise the real constraints on our continent's carrying capacity.

TALK.START.PARA: —On previous occasions I have addressed the Senate on the failure of government regulatory agencies in the financial sector to actually implement any of the acts of parliament that they have at their disposal. Primarily supervision is considered to be best served by self-regulation. Credit unions are an excellent example where people of common interest can save their funds for common purpose and it is in their best interests. Credit unions are a practical and workable alternative to banks and often more rewarding for depositors.

PARA.TAB: In Queensland, the management of one credit union is destroying the credibility of other respectable, diligent and hardworking credit unions. The management of one credit union is jeopardising workers' savings. What is the government of Queensland doing—nothing! In Queensland, self-regulation has been reduced to a farce. There is a credit union in Queensland that has behaved in a cavalier manner with depositors' savings—a credit union that is appearing before the Senate Committee of Privileges and is involved in a tax minimisation scheme for its general manager's superannuation.

The Queensland Professional Credit Union appears to be an exceptional case of the failure of good corporate governance in credit union affairs. Unfortunately, they have been advised on the tax minimisation treatment of the general manager's superannuation by KPMG Brisbane and they have on their board a Mr Des Boyland—no novice to superannuation affairs having spent considerable years as the trade union representative on the Queensland State Government Superannuation Board.

Regardless, however, of their accumulated wisdom, the board of the Queensland Professional Credit Union converted the accrued long service leave and annual leave of the General Manager, Mr Rutherford, as a direct deposit to his superannuation. Just in the game of monopoly when you are on the way straight to gaol, they did not have to pass `Go', they did not pay income tax, they did not pay stamp duty, they did not consider whether this was equitable, they did not treat all of their employees equally, and they did not seek a ruling from the ATO on this highly irregular move. They went past `Go' and collected their benefits on the way.

However, there is now an ATO ruling on this form of transaction. It was obtained by one of the credit union members who is outraged at the blatant rort. It is my view that managing the savings of Australians is not a game of monopoly. Confidence in the Australian banking sector was severely shaken by the regulatory failures of the eighties. Confidence was also shaken by the demise of the integrity of corporate governance. To go some way to restoring confidence, directors must exercise care and independent judgment in their management of banking institutions.

In the Queensland Professional Credit Union saga, members have seen corporate governance and government supervision reduced to practices similar to that of the rum corp in the early days of European colonisation of Australia. I believe that the credibility of Treasurer De Lacey, the credibility of the Queensland Office of Financial Supervision and the Queensland government's financial institutions code stands or falls on the way in which they discharge their duty to protect depositors from the activities of the Queensland Professional Credit Union.

This is a case crying out for intervention and enforcement by the regulators. Yet they sit on their hands and they say they have no evidence. I am told that some of the evidence has been formally put before the regulators three times and that they have now been formally invited to hold an inquiry. I wait to see their response.

I am concerned that the members of the QPCU will have to pick up the costs of legal services in defence as well as the unpaid tax bill and fine when it should be reimbursed by Mr Rutherford. To maintain confidence in the savings of credit unions and demonstrate the vigour and independence of the regulator, there needs to be an independent audit of all aspects of the QPCU affairs over the past years.

Let me finally outline the inequity of this situation. We are aware of the diligence of the tax office in chasing up trivial amounts of undeclared bank interest through the income matching system which monitors levels of compliance in this community. I have heard many stories of pensioners being fined on small amounts of interest inadvertently overlooked and receiving a 25 per cent penalty. These overlooked amounts are in the order of $150 or less and at the low tax rate of 21.4 per cent they gather a minor amount of revenue for the Commonwealth. There is also the case of a student who was disallowed on $250 worth of receipts because they were not proper receipts, despite being claims against Austudy for books and study aids.

Let me return to the transaction I am describing. This one transaction on $77,000 worth of transfer to superannuation from long service leave and holiday pay equates to approximately $72,000 in tax and about $15,000 in interest to date on the late payment, up to $25,000 penalty for non-compliance by the credit union and a further $10,000 approximately for non-payment of payroll tax. This is a considerable sum of money in anyone's terms.

I wonder whether the Treasurer (Mr Willis) can advise the Senate as to the extent of this practice and what this practice might represent in terms of lost revenue for the Australian Taxation Office. What guarantee do the members of the QPCU have that the taxation department will pursue this revenue from the transaction that I outlined? What guarantee do the members have that they will not have to foot the bill for taxation, reimbursement, legal fees, payroll tax and penalty that this `super deal'—that is according to the federal Treasurer—is not on? Will the Commonwealth Treasurer draw these matters to the attention of the Queensland Treasurer Mr De Lacey to ensure that the integrity of the Australian financial institutions code is reinstated and that the workers of Queensland can have confidence in their credit unions?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw Sen M.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we all know that in politics not everything that happens fills us with delight or joy. It is a tough game and sometimes hard decisions are made. There are also occasions, as we know, when good decisions come forward from government which make you feel that it is all worth while. I believe the decision made last week by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee and approved by the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) to list the drug pulmozyme on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme was such a decision. I am delighted that that decision has been made.

PARA.TAB: About three months ago, in July, I met a young girl called Jodie Collins, a 19-year-old, who lived in my local area, who suffered from cystic fibrosis. Jodie was campaigning to have this drug listed on the PBS list. She had been prescribed the pulmozyme drug since the beginning of the year and was certainly showing signs of improvement—improvement in that, whereas previously she may have been in hospital on some five occasions, she did not have to be hospitalised once during these months when she was receiving this treatment.

Unfortunately, the cost of pulmozyme was around $1,300 a month—a crippling cost for any patient or their family. Thus it was that Jodie was devoting all of her energies to getting out and being active in the community, urging us, the politicians, and those in the halls of power generally to see whether this drug could be listed.

This matter had been before the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee on two previous occasions. The first was November 1994 when the committee considered an application for the listing of pulmozyme. The committee concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: On the basis of the information submitted, the use of Pulmozyme has only a small measurable impact on the disease for the majority of cystic fibrosis patients. Furthermore, the drug is extremely expensive. In deciding whether Pulmozyme could be recommended for listing as a pharmaceutical benefit, the Committee needed to take into account both the very high cost of the drug and the small benefits demonstrated.

On that occasion the application was denied. A further application went before the PBAC and was dealt with in June of this year. On that occasion more information was provided by the manufacturer and, even though it indicated that the benefits of the treatment for a group of patients that was being trialled seemed to be maintained, the committee did not believe that there was sufficient information before it to support listing on the scheme.

PARA.TAB: In question time today the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, Senator Crowley, answered a question from me on this matter. There was some criticism by way of interjection from the opposition about why this decision to list the drug had not been taken earlier. It is important to remember that the PBAC is an independent body made up of experts whose very difficult job it is to make these sorts of decisions that require a balancing on the one hand of the best way to assist patients suffering from diseases like cystic fibrosis and whether there will be benefits from such drugs, and, on the other hand, the cost to the taxpayer.

In the case of pulmozyme we are talking about many millions of dollars in cost. I do not think anybody envies the people on that committee having to make such decisions. Frankly, whilst we all wish that we could ensure that every single drug that was of assistance to any patient was available through the scheme, no matter how small the number of people who may ultimately benefit, that is just not possible when those drugs are so very expensive. We have to balance various considerations.

Certainly, the committee looked at this situation and requested further information following that decision in June and it indicated that it would be prepared to consider it again. Further information was able to be provided and, as time went on, it became clear that around about a third of the estimated number of people suffering from CF were likely to benefit from pulmozyme. In addition, since that decision in June, the drug had been listed in Canada on its equivalent scheme. So there was new information available to the committee when it met recently. Ultimately, as the minister has announced, it recommended the approval of pulmozyme on the basis that it would be strictly controlled by the relevant medical specialists recommending to whom the drug should be available.

As the minister indicated, it is not something that will provide a cure for all CF sufferers. We are all aware that cystic fibrosis, which is an hereditary disease, is a terrible complaint. People who suffer from it generally have a very short life expectancy. If this drug works, as it appears to do for some of these people, that will be a terrific thing.

I rose to speak tonight because I was delighted to see that decision last week and I know that many of my colleagues across the political spectrum—in particular, my local member, Robert Tickner—have taken up this issue. We should look at this decision as being one that represents the positive side of politics—there are people who will be benefiting from this decision. We also recognise that this was a matter that had to be given the greatest consideration by the committee and, ultimately, by the minister.

I would like to pay tribute to Jodie Collins, her family and all those other people who have been involved in this campaign and to the Cystic Fibrosis Association. I finish by quoting some words that Jodie said in an article:

SPEECH.PARA: In the past six months, Pulmozyme has allowed me to do all the things I ever dreamed of doing. I can duck dive under a wave in the surf and recently I climbed Mount Kosciusko without too much difficulty. My appetite has improved and I have gained 10 kilograms since my last hospitalisation. Even my doctor is thrilled because my lung function has significantly improved. I now have energy to do what I want. For the first time in my life my body can keep up with my spirit.
Jodie and people like her have a great deal of spirit and I hope that this certainly continues to assist them in the future.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Forshaw, you might not have realised that part-way through that quote your time had expired but we on this side of the chamber indicated to the chair that we wanted you to continue because the quote you read out was quite moving and was indicative of the fact that every political party, every individual in this place, was personally involved in the campaign. I want to place on record my appreciation for the decision that was ultimately made.

PARA.TAB: The reason I rise tonight is to talk about two vital industries in my home state of Tasmania that have been adversely affected by the federal government's indecision and politicking. Unfortunately, the government has been sending out conflicting messages and a great degree of uncertainty has been occasioned. As a result, there is no job security and the potential for growth in jobs has been undermined.

The first industry I want to refer to is the aquaculture industry. Today, my friend and colleague from Tasmania, Senator Calvert, raised a question on this vital industry. Senator Calvert, might I add, is a person who has personal experience in the aquaculture industry and has some knowledge of it. He has shown a genuine concern for this industry over many years.

It was therefore highly appropriate that he asked a question at question time today that referred particularly to comments made by Senator Murphy. Senator Murphy had basically said that the federal government would not make a decision in relation to the importation of Atlantic salmon from North America until after the federal election.

Unfortunately, that sent out all the messages that the people in the industry and, in particular, the employees did not want to hear. They did not want the government to play politics with it. Unfortunately, Senator Murphy let the cat out of the bag by making his ill-considered comments. From our side of the Senate, of course, we welcomed his comments because they highlighted the way that the Labor Party really plays with this issue, and that is to be condemned. I also note that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) administered an admonishment to Senator Murphy for his comments by his backhanded comment in his answer, and all credit goes to the minister for that.

The draft risk analysis of AQIS has given a lot of concern to the industry and employees within the industry. Whilst Senator Murphy has sought to gain cheap publicity in Tasmania on a bleeding heart basis, let me simply indicate that when the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee of the Senate was in Tasmania to deal with the question of AQIS there were no Tasmanian Labor Senate representatives. Not a single one of them turned up—let alone Senator Shayne Murphy, who is in fact a member of that committee. You would have thought that simply from his responsibilities as a senator he might have turned up. Apart from that you might think that, given all his bleatings of recent times, he may have also turned up because of his genuine concern for the Tasmanian industry. But on neither count did he turn up. Let me simply add that both Senator Calvert and I put in appearances to ensure that the appropriate questions were asked and the appropriate information was obtained.

Let me simply remind the Senate that currently 2,000 people are employed because of the existence of the aquaculture industry, and it produces $100 million worth of product each year. For my home state of Tasmania, it is a very important industry and one that does need to be looked after. From my point of view and, I know, from Senator Calvert's point of view as well, it needs to retain its disease-free status. That is why so much angst has been occasioned in Tasmania by the draft risk analysis of AQIS, which has basically suggested that the importation of North Atlantic salmon ought be allowed with all its diseases and the risk associated with those diseases spreading, not only to the aquaculture industry but also into our native fish.

The other matter that I wanted to raise, the other vital industry where various signals have been sent out, is in relation to the timber industry. Many thousands of my fellow Tasmanians find gainful employment through the harvesting of the renewable resource that we know as timber. Let me say that in the Tasmanian context in excess of 25 per cent of our land mass is already locked up. It will never have the chainsaw put to it or even be selectively harvested. It is simply locked up.

Yet, while the federal government was determining its approach to the forests, in the last few months of federal-state talks leading up to what will undoubtedly be fully announced in a few days time, up to 12 bureaucrats were arriving in Tasmania every few weeks to discuss the environmental issues. The social and economic issues which the government said it would take into account—the issues dealing with the workers, the families and the communities—were left to a lone Canberra-hired consultant for a mere three days. Yet it had a dozen bureaucrats dealing with the environmental issues, because placating the green movement is so much more important to this Labor government than looking after the welfare of the workers that it is supposed to represent. It is little wonder that people like Martin Ferguson and others are lamenting the fact that people are leaving the trade union movement in droves and are deserting the Australian Labor Party.

There is another issue that I want to raise in this context—that is, the campaign of hate that is being pursued by the extreme green movement in my home state of Tasmania. In recent times, I had a very moving account provided to me of how a young boy aged about eight or nine came home after school. When his father arrived home after a full day's work in the bush, his son asked him, `Why do you murder trees?' When the father asked his son where he had got this outrageous suggestion from, he said, `Well, that's what my teacher said in school today.' Of course, that child is now being ostracised at school by his other classmates because there is the assertion in the class—because teacher said so—that this young boy's father is a tree murderer.

Whilst we talk about the importance of looking after people's rights and ensuring that they are not alienated, this federal government, in its ever increasing attempt to placate the green vote by funding these organisations, has also allowed a campaign to spread throughout the community which seeks to ostracise those people, those families and those communities that earn a genuine income from genuine hard work, earning genuine export dollars for our country. Let me simply say that we on this side of the chamber stand in solidarity with the timber workers, their families and their communities.

I have just a few moments left, and I simply digress very briefly to say that I welcome the federal government's decision to recognise grandparents in the Family Law Act, as announced in recent times. The government response initially was to reject the suggestion of the unanimous decision of the Senate committee that looked into that. I then spoke in the Senate opposing the government's response. I understand a lot of lobbying has been undertaken, and the government has now changed its mind. I congratulate all those involved who lobbied the government to make it change its mind.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 11 July 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does Australia Post have any plans or intentions to close, minimise, reduce staff or expenditure, or impose productivity quotas on any post offices anywhere in New South Wales; if so, which post offices are they and what changes are being proposed for each post office and when are they due to take effect.
(2) Is the Warragamba Post Office to be closed.
(3) Are there any plans to reduce staff, reduce running costs or impose productivity quotas for Jannali Post Office in New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Australia Post has advised that:
(1) Australia Post is in the midst of a five-year program of modernising and reinvigorating its retail network.

This program, known as `Retail Post', is designed to eliminate the significant losses incurred by the network, and improve customer service by providing customers with access to more conveniently located and more diverse retail facilities.

Retail Post comprises a range of initiatives, including the introduction of retail shop-type post offices in convenient locations; the establishment of Business Centres with drive-in access; the relocation of some existing outlets to more accessible locations (eg shopping centres and malls); the conversion of Post Office Agencies to Licensed Post Office operation.
Retail Post is being implemented gradually with full and ongoing consultation with employees, staff associations, local communities and their representatives.
No permanent staff have been retrenched under the Retail Post program. Labour savings are being achieved through natural attrition, redeployment and voluntary redundancy.
To date, 86 post offices in New South Wales have been converted to Licensed Post Office operation following the consultative review process.
A further 14 post offices have been through the consultative review process and are due to be converted to Licensed Post Office operation before the end of the year

A further 70 to 80 post offices are yet to be considered under the consultative review process. These offices will be reviewed over the next 12 to 18 months. Since the conversion of Post Offices to Licensed Post Offices commenced, 97 new Business Centres have also been opened.
(2) Warragamba was previously operating as a Post Office Agency. It commenced operation as a Licensed Post Office on 14 August 1995.

(3) Jannali Post Office will be converted to Licensed Post Office operation in October 1995, and will remain at the existing site. All permanent staff have been catered for in accordance with the Redundancy, Redeployment and Retraining Agreement between Australia Post and the relevant staff association.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 24 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Federal Government entered into an agreement with the Victorian State Government for the establishment of an Academy of Music, to be based in South Melbourne.
(2) Will this academy be located at the South Melbourne Town Hall.

(3) Is the Commonwealth aware that this building currently houses numerous divisions of the council and that, as a result of their forced move from the Town Hall, the council will incur significant relocation costs as well as loss of rental revenue.
(4) What has been the nature of the community consultation that was undertaken prior to any agreement being entered into between the Commonwealth and the Victorian Governments.

(5) Is it a fact that community groups, including the South Melbourne Symphony Orchestra, are now being asked to pay annual rent to the Academy of Music for use of space in the town hall whereas previously no such cost was imposed.
(6) How does the agreement between the Commonwealth and the Victorian State Government ensure the protection of the architecture and heritage significance of the South Melbourne Town Hall.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) The Academy, which fulfils a commitment by the Prime Minister in the Government's `Creative Nation' statement of October 1994, will operate as a national centre of excellence in education and training in musical performance for outstandingly talented musical students.
The Academy is a joint venture with the Victorian Government.
The provision of accommodation for the Academy is the responsibility of the Victorian Government which has nominated the South Melbourne Town Hall for that purpose.

The respective contributions of the Commonwealth and Victorian Governments were formalised in a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) on 21 June 1995, which detailed agreed arrangements relating to the establishment and operation of the Academy.

Under the terms of the MOU, the Victorian Government undertook to provide and arrange for the equipping and maintenance of the South Melbourne Town Hall to a standard necessary to fulfil the functions of the Academy within the limit of funds to be provided by the Commonwealth Government for that purpose. The Victorian Government will also provide security of tenure for the Academy at the South Melbourne Town Hall.

The Victorian Government has negotiated with the City of Port Phillip which has agreed to grant the Academy occupancy rights to part of the South Melbourne Town Hall. The Academy has agreed to this arrangement.

The Academy will occupy the South Melbourne Town Hall rent free but will be charged an occupancy cost for services provided. Arrangements for the Academy's occupancy of the town hall are being formalised in an Agreement between the Port Phillip City Council, the Australian National Academy of Music, the University of Melbourne and the Victorian Government.
(3) The provision of council amenities to South Melbourne is the responsibility of the City of Port Phillip.

(4) and (5) The MOU includes a requirement that the two governments ensure that consultation occurs with the local South Melbourne community relating to the Academy's operation within the South Melbourne Town Hall, with a view to continued community use of the building's facilities to the maximum extent practicable.

I am advised that there has been consultation concerning the Academy's use of the South Melbourne Town Hall at the local level. A meeting, arranged by the Commissioners of the City of Port Phillip, was held in May between representatives of the University of Melbourne, the Victorian Government and a community panel and there have been further meetings between Academy representatives and community interest groups.
The Commissioners of the City of Port Phillip were requested to provide information about regular users of the facilities so that plans could be made to accommodate their interests.
I am advised that the City of Port Phillip has made provision in its budget for a scheme to assess requests from community organisations for subsidised use of the town hall.

I am also advised that the City of Port Phillip has agreed that there will be no net charge to the South Melbourne Symphony Orchestra for its use of the South Melbourne Town Hall to stage four concerts per year and hold weekly practice sessions.

Some matters which have been raised by members of the community, such as the community's continuing access to town hall facilities, could only be dealt with at a very general level until the Academy itself had been established and could deal with them. Sir Zelman Cowen, Chair of the Academy Board, with other Academy representatives, has recently met on two occasions with members of the local community and I understand that significant progress has been made.

(6) The South Melbourne Town Hall is one of Victoria's grandest town halls. It is listed on the Historic Buildings Register and has been added to the Register of the National Estate. The town hall is also registered with the National Trust of Australia (Victoria).

The Commonwealth Government has undertaken to provide up to $1.5m for the refurbishment and equipment of the South Melbourne Town Hall to house the Academy. The refurbishment is being supervised by the University of Melbourne which has considerable expertise with heritage buildings.
I am advised that this process included the preparation of a Conservation Management Plan which is now completed. Local community involvement in the preparation of the plan was encouraged.
The plan will govern the use of significant spaces in the South Melbourne Town Hall and determine the manner in which renovation of the Town Hall for Academy purposes, might take place.

The plan is subject to comment and consultation by the Academy, the City of Port Phillip and the Historic Buildings Council. It will then form part of a planning application which will be subject to public notice and comment.
The Historic Buildings Council has been fully involved in consultations about possible building modifications.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Industry, Science and Technology: Sponsorship of Book Publication

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, upon notice, on 24 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the relationship between Dr Andrew Ross and the department.
(2) Is the book entitled Armed and Ready, written by Dr Andrew Ross, officially endorsed by the Minister and the department.
(3) What support was given by the department to the publication and launch of Dr Ross' book.
(4) What is the total value of support and assistance for the department given to Dr Ross for the publication and launch of Armed and Ready.
(5) How many copies of Armed and Ready have been purchased by the department and or other government departments and agencies.
(6) Who will receive proceeds and/or royalties from the sale of copies of the book.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The department provided $10,000 to sponsor the publication of Dr Ross' book Armed and Ready as part of its contribution to the Australia Remembers commemoration. The sponsorship was an appropriate commemorative activity as the book is a history of industry, science and technological development in the years leading up to and during WW2.

The department's decision to sponsor publication of the book was made after consultation with a number of prominent referees. These included: Dr Peter Stanley, Head, Historical Research, Australian War Memorial; Associate Professor John McCarthy, Australian Defence Force Academy; Professor Ian Rae, Deputy Vice Chancellor, Victorian University of Technology; Mr Jeff Moran, Immediate Past President, Institute of Industrial Engineers; and Professor Roy MacCleod, Professor of History, University of Sydney.

(2) The views expressed in Dr Ross' book are those of Dr Ross. They do not necessarily reflect the views of myself or my department. I launched the book on Monday, 31 July. In the foreword of the book I state, `Not all may agree with the main thesis that Australia saved itself from the threat of Japanese invasion, but there can be no doubt that Dr Ross has come up with a coherent, thorough and detailed evaluation of acts and figures about science and industry of the kind that we have never seen before. His thesis can only be refuted by an equally scholarly approach.'

(3) As already stated sponsorship of $10,000 was provided. The department also employed Dr Ross for five weeks at the cost of $8,517 to complete the preparation of his manuscript and to advise the department in preparing a photographic display of Australian industry's contribution to the war effort. In this period Dr Ross also selected photographs which were used in the book. The sum of $4,130 was provided to hire the Australian War Memorial Annex Treloar Centre. An additional sum of $560 was also provided for catering at the launch.
(4) The total value of support and assistance given by the department for the publication and launch of Armed and Ready was $24,007. A breakdown is as follows;
Sponsorship of the printing and publication of the book—10,000
Dr Ross' salary for 5 weeks employment within the department—8,517
The cost of hire of the Treloar Centre, Mitchell—4,130
Catering—560
Pamphlet used as part of media kit for launch—800
Articles were also run in the department's Ascent Technology Magazine.

(5) The Department of Industry, Science and Technology purchased 60 copies of Armed and Ready for $39.95 each, less a 33.3% discount, a total of $1,598.00. We have no knowledge of how many copies other departments purchased.
(6) The book was published and sold by Turton and Armstrong Pty Ltd. Proceeds and royalty arrangements are a private matter between Dr Andrew Ross and Turton and Armstrong Pty Ltd.
